During the day, Gantuya operates a souvenir selling business with her husband in Harhorin soum where tourists travel a lot to see tourist attractions such as Erdenezuu monastery and Frog rock. She sells a variety of Mongolian souvenirs to her many customers and her profit is very high especially during the summer between June and October. However, her profits are not as high during the winter. With her business profits, she built a winter house for her family and she has been able to pay her children's tuition fees. Her family's quality of life is good. 

Gantuya is a very hard working person who has strong selling and communication skills. She says, “I would like to open my own souvenir shop after my children graduate their universities. ” She is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug (~  1475 USD) loan to purchase more souvenirs to resell at a profit.

loans.use: To purchase more souvenirs.

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
Ahmad is a 41-year-old married man and father of one child. From 14 years ago, he opened a linen shop in his town where he buys pajamas, blankets, pillows etc. He cooperates with his wife who works in the village municipality to satisfy the family expenses. He has already received several micro loans from Ameen to improve his business and the final loan has from Kiva to buy inventory in good prices. He’s a punctual client and he has consistently paid on-time. 

Today, Ahmad is planning on taking another Kiva loan from Ameen of $ 2,000 so that he can continue to expand his business and purchase more merchandise.

loans.use: purchase more merchandise

loans.name: Dayawathi

texts.en:
Dayawathi is a 40-year-old married woman living with her two children. Her husband is currently living and working abroad.

Dayawathi sews clothes as her business, and she has been doing this for a year. She is hardworking and very enthusiastic.

Dayawathi has requested a 30,000 LKR loan from BRAC Sri Lanka to purchase cloth to help her business. She is grateful to BRAC Sri Lanka because of the financial support it provides her.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To buy more cloth for her business

loans.name: Bopha's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Bopha M. is a 29 year old, married woman. She is a village bank president who was selected by 11-members, located in Toul Krosang village in Kandal province. The members will use the loan for several different purposes. Mrs. Bopha M. is a shell seller who can earn a small income to support her family living. Her husband, Mr. Veasna Sovann, is a motorcycL. taxi driver. Mrs. Bopha M. is requesting for a loan to add her saving to purchase a new motorbike for supporting her husband business. Mrs. Bopha M. is a mother of three children; two are students in the local school whiL. the youngest one is 2 years old.

loans.use: To add her saving to purchase a new motorbike

loans.name: Adil

texts.en: Adil A., born in 1971, is married and has two children. He and his family live in the Absheron region, where he has been farming for six years. He is now requesting a loan of 2000 AZN to buy fertilizers and seeds to improve his business.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and seeds

loans.name: Leoncia

texts.en: Leoncia C. wishes to find a way to improve her family's quality of living. For this motivation, she joined Kiva and felt very happy to be given a loan and group support. The previous loans she received enabled her to support her husband’s fishing business, maintain her general store and canteen eatery. The profit from these businesses has been the main source of family income and funding for the education of her four children in college. Now that Leoncia has access to funding, her profits are better than before. Therefore, she is now requesting another loan through Kiva for a much bigger amount to purchase fishnet, bamboo, and other raw materials of her fishing business and pay for 120 sacks of charcoal for maintenance of her store . This will allow her to grow their businesses further so that their children can fulfill their dreams of achieving college degree and find good jobs.

loans.use: To purchase fishnet, bamboo, and other raw materials of her fishing business and remaining money will be use to pay for 120 sacks of charcoal for maintenance of her store.

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkadi est composé de dix  femmes (deux veuves et huit) mariées majoritairement dans des grandes familles traditionnelles, ayant une moyenne d’âge de 43 ans et 4 enfants. Elles habitent toutes Darabougou, village situé dans la Commune Rurale de Sakoïba (4ème Région Administrative du Mali). 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de mariage, de voisinage et d’appartenance à une même association traditionnelle d’entraide des femmes du village de Darabougou. 
Ces femmes du groupe Benkadi sont à leur premier prêt solidaire avec Soro Yiriwaso et font le commerce d’articles divers. Certains membres du groupe font l’achat et la vente des choux pommés, du beurre de karité, des calebasses et du henné.  
Madame Yama C. un des membres excelle dans la préparation et la vente des plats alimentaires tels les beignets de mil et les friandises de haricot.
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 50kg de petit mil, 10kg de haricot, 4litres d’huile, 1/2 paquet de levure, 3 kg de sucre et 2kg de sel iodé sur place et à la foire hebdomadaire de Ségou. 
Pour faire les beignets de mil, elle le pile, le débarrasse du son, lave bien et prélève une partie qu’elle écrase qui servira de bouillie pour pétrir la farine obtenue après pilage. Elle ajoute du sel et du sucre et de la levure nécessaire pour le mélange. Cette bouillie est  frite à l’huile très tôt le matin pour obtenir les beignets de mil afin de servir de petit déjeuner. Le haricot, lui est transformé en farine, on y ajoute quelques pincées de sel avant de le battre fortement. Cette pâte obtenue est également frite les après midi. Madame Yama jouit d’une grande réputation due à la bonne qualité de ses friandises. 
Les membres du groupe vendent au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes,  de femmes et d’enfants à domicile. 
Yama espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 10.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour augmenter son fonds de commerce.   
NB: Alimata Traoré est absente de la photo (elle a accouché le jour même du financement).
texts.en:
The Benkadi Group ("Harmony") is composed of ten women (two widowed and eight married). Most of them live in large traditional families and, on average, are 43 years old and have four children. They all live in Darabougou, a village located in the rural municipality of Sakoïba (fourth administrative region of Mali). They know each other through ties of kinship, marriage or neighborhood, or because they are members of the same traditional women's association for mutual aid in their village. This is the first solidarity loan with Soro Yiriwaso for the members of Benkadi Group. The women have various trading activities. A few of them buy and sell firm round cabbages, shea butter, calabashes and henna. One of the members is Mrs Yama C.. She excels in the preparation and sale of food dishes, such as millet fritters and bean tidbits. She will use her loan to buy 50 kilograms of small millet, 10 kilograms of beans, 4 liters of oil, half a package of yeast, 3 kilograms of sugar and 2 kilograms of iodized salt, in her village and at the weekly fair in Ségou. She explained to us how she prepares her dishes: Yama's recipe for millet fritters: Pound the millet, remove the bran and wash thoroughly. Take part of it and mash it. Add this pulp to the flour previously obtained through pounding and knead. Add salt, sugar and yeast to the mixture. Fry the pulp in oil. Do this early in the morning and serve for breakfast. Yama's recipe for bean tidbits: Transform the beans into flour. Add a few pinches of salt and stir vigorously. Fry the batter in oil. Ideally, do this in the afternoon. Mrs Yama enjoys a solid reputation thanks to the high quality of her tidbits. The group members sell from their homes, for cash and credit, to a clientele made up of men, women and children. Yama expects to make a monthly profit of 10,000 CFA francs which she will use to increase her working capital. NB: Alimata Traoré is not pictured. She gave birth to a baby on the very day of the loan disbursement.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy ingredients for her dishes

loans.name: Edward

texts.en: Mr. Edward K., a 34-year-old businessman, has been operating a carpentry workshop business for over six years. He will the loan to purchase more timber, vanishing paint, nails and other tools to increase both the productivity and the success of his business. His future hope is to own a furniture mart.

loans.use: To purchase more timber, vanishing paint, nails and other tools for his business

loans.name: Thoen's Group

texts.en: Mr. Thoen E., 27, is a village bank president of  a 15-member group located in Toul Krosang village in Kandal Province. Each member will use the loan to support a variety of purposes as they work to increase income to better support their families. Mr. Thoen E. is a fisherman and his wife, Mrs. Pov Oeun, is a laborer. With both activiities they can earn a small income to support the family, consisting of three children, two of whom are attending the local school, while the third at the age of four is yet too young to commence education.  Mr. Thoen E. is now requesting a loan to purchase a boat, fishing nets and a boat motor to support his fishing business.

loans.use: To purchase a boat, fishing nets and a fishing boat motor

loans.name: Tièssiri Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Tièssiri comprend dix femmes majoritairement mariées dans des familles polygames avec une moyenne d’âge de 37 ans et 4 enfants. Elles résident toutes à Darabougou, village situé dans la Commune Rurale de Sakoïba (4ème Région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de mariage et de voisinage.
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce de condiments alimentaires (concentrée de tomate, oignons etc), de la restauration et la transformation de la farine de blé en vermicelle qui est la spécialité de Fatoumata M.. 
Afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle, elles ont décidé d’adhérer à Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elles sont à leur 1er  prêt solidaire.
 Fatoumata M.  fait cette transformation de la farine de blé à l’aide d’une machine manuelle  depuis maintenant 5 ans et  elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 25kg de farine de blé, 2kg de sel et d’autres  ingrédients. 
Pour faire du vermicelle chaque jour elle pétrit, 4kg de farine de blé jusqu’à avoir une pâte homogène et lisse et avec sa machine manuelle elle transforme cette pâte en vermicelle d’épaisseurs différentes, qu’elle fait sécher sur des nattes recouvertes de toile de cretonne. Ce vermicelle est protégé par de tissus blancs et légers, une façon d’observer les mesures d’hygiène. Le vermicelle est mesuré à l’aide d’une louche et ensaché, destiné aux ménagères et restaurants. Elle reçoit beaucoup de commandes surtout lors des évènements sociaux. 
Elle se ravitaille hebdomadairement  en matières premières, à la foire du grand marché de Ségou et effectue sa vente à domicile, au marché, généralement au comptant à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 10.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser le prêt et satisfaire certains petits besoins de la famille.
texts.en:
The Tièssiri group is comprised of ten women, the majority of whom are married and in polygamous families. On average, they are 37 years old and have four children. They all live in Darabougou, a village in the rural community of Sakoiba (4th administrative region of Mali). They know each other through parent, marriage, and neighbor connections. This group of women works with condiments (tomato concentrate, onions, etc.), in the restaurant business, and makes pasta from buckwheat flour, Fatoumata M.'s specialty. In order to meet their customers' needs, they decided to join Soro Yiriwaso; they are asking for their first loan together. Fatoumata M. has made wholewheat spaghetti with the help of a manual machine for five years. She plans on using this loan to buy 25 kg of flour, 2 kg of salt, and other ingredients. To make spaghetti each day, she kneads 4 kg of flour until it forms a smooth, homogeneous paste. With her machine, she transforms this paste into spaghetti of varying thickness which she dries on cotton canvas mats. The pasta is protected by a light, white fabric for sanitary purposes. The spaghetti is measured with a ladle, bagged, and sent to restaurants. Fatoumata receives many orders, especially during social events. She stocks up weekly on ingredients at the grand market in Ségou and sells her product from her home and at the market. Her customers are both men and women. She plans on making a monthly profit of 10,000 FCFA which will be used to repay the loan and meet her family's small needs.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of buckwheat flour

loans.name: Isata

texts.en: Isata K. is married to a diamond miner. They have two children in primary school. Isata sells lace and fabrics at a popular market called Roma along Gerehun Road. She needs a loan to buy fabrics that are popular with her customers. She intends to use the proceeds from the loan to pay for her children's schooling and to get materials to start building a house.

loans.use: To buy fabric

loans.name: Loun's Group

texts.en: Mr. Loun L. is 35 years old and the president of an eleven-member loan group located in Toul Krosang village in Kandal province. Each member will use the loan for a different purpose. Mr. Loun L. is a famer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice to support his family. He is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticide for his crop. His wife, Mrs. Pov Sok, is a farm laborer who receives a small salary to contribute to the family income. The couple has three children who all are students in the local school.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and pesticide

loans.name: Hajji Juma

texts.en:
Hajji Juma K. is a successful businessman. He is thirty-five years old and has a retail shop located in Kasubi, Kampala, which he has been operating for over four years.

Hajji Juma is using the loan to purchase items like sugar, posho (maize flour), cooking oil, salt, soap, etc., to expand his business.

Hajji Juma is a hardworking businessman whose future dream is to set up a wholesale shop.

loans.use: To purchase items like sugar, posho, cooking oil, salt, soap, etc., to expand his business

loans.name: Nyamgerel

texts.en:
Nyamgerel is 37 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Bayan-Ulgii province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, the traditional Mongolian nomadic tent.

Nyamgerel operates a carpentry business with her husband in their home province. Her husband manufactures wooden furniture and Nyamgerel helps with the business. They produce a variety of wooden furniture products including doors, windows, sofas, chairs and tables.

Nyamgerel and her husband have gained valuable experience in previous years and have a loyal customer base. Their monthly profit is approximately 200,000 - 400,000 tugrugs (approximately 145 - 290 USD).

Nyamgerel and her husband have been planning to expand their production line and increase their sales. She likes to say “Nothing is impossible.” She is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase timber, nails and other materials for her business.

loans.use: To purchase timber, nails and other materials for her business

loans.name: Aramatou

texts.fr:
Mariée et mère de 4 enfants Madame Aramatou Kanté est âgée  de 35 ans et vit dans une famille polygame dans le quartier Darsalam II de la préfecture de Koutiala (région de Sikasso) avec son mari, sa co-épouse et leurs enfants. 
N’ ayant pas eu la chance de fréquenter l’école,  Aramatou  n’a pas pris du temps pour embrasser le commerce depuis à bas âge, auprès de sa maman.  Après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans réussite, elle finit par opter pour l’achat et la vente des tissus  et divers autres articles depuis maintenant 10 ans. Sa notoriété est bonne car elle vend une grande quantité d’articles dans le mois.  
Pour la bonne satisfaction de sa clientèle en quantité et en qualité, elle décida de  faire recours à l‘institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a 3 ans. Après  6 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) tous payés correctement, elle est à son 1er prêt  individuel.  
Avec ce  financement  elle  compte acheter, 20 pièces de tissus  à Bamako et à Bobo (Burkina Faso). Elle effectue sa vente dans la ville  de Koutiala  à une clientèle  constituée de femmes et d’hommes,  au comptant ou à crédit.  
Elle compte  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 60.000 FCFA  qu’elle envisage utiliser pour  le remboursement du prêt de Soro Yiriwaso, participer aux dépenses quotidiennes de la famille et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Married and the mother of four children, Ms. Aramatou Kanté is 35 years old and lives in a polygamous family in the Darsalam II district of Koutiala Prefecture (region of Sikasso) with her husband, her co-wife, and their children.  Not having had the chance to attend school, she wasted no time embracing commerce at an early age at her mother's side.  After having operated in several kinds of businesses unsuccessfully, she finally opted for buying and selling cloth and various other items about ten years ago now.  Her fame is great because she sells a large quantity of goods in a month.  To satisfy her customers properly with regard to quantity and quality, she decided to turn toward the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso three years ago.  After six solidarity loans (group loans), all correctly repaid, she is now on her first individual loan.  With this financing, she intends to buy twenty bolts of cloth in Bamako and in Bobo (Burkina Faso).  She sells, cash or credit accepted, in Koutiala City to a customer base composed of women and men.  Aramatou plans on making a monthly profit of 60,000 francs CFA that she envisions using for repaying the Soro Yiriwaso loan, for taking part in covering the day-to-day expenses of the family, and for investing the rest in her business.  

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying cloth

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en: Ahmad is a young man of 19 who lives with his family of seven brothers and sisters. His father travels out of Lebanon so he helps support the family. Ahmad began working in the construction business in 2004 when he was very young. He is a freelance worker who specializes in cutting stone for construction. He has built up a good business reputation. Ahmad is asking for $1,100 to expand his business and increase his income.

loans.use: expand his business

loans.name: Samnang's Group

texts.en: Mr. Samnang  O. is 39 years old and the president of a fifteen-member loan group located in Toul Krosang village in Kandal province. Each member will use the loan for a different purpose. Mr. Samnang O. is a fish seller which brings in a small income to support his family. Since his business is going well he wants to expand it, and so is asking for a loan to buy more fish to sell. His wife, Mrs. Kai Nov, sells groceries in her general store. The couple has eight children; two are laborers, five attend the local school (and also support their parent's business) while the youngest one is four years old.

loans.use: To buy more fish to sell

loans.name: Awa

texts.fr:
Mariée et mère de 5 enfants, Madame Awa C. a 46 ans et vit avec son époux et ses enfants  dans le quartier Hamdallaye de la préfecture de Koutiala.(troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). 
N’ayant pas eu la chance de continuer les études primaires, Awa n’a pas pris du temps à s’intéresser aux activités génératrices de revenus auprès de sa maman depuis son jeune âge et l’exerce pour elle-même il y a plus de 20 ans de cela.  Son activité principale est la vente des  articles de fêtes (chaussures, sacs, parures etc), elle fait  également des prestations de services avec la coiffure. Elle est très sollicitée par les femmes de la ville de Koutiala. 
Dans le souci d’augmenter son fonds de commerce  et satisfaire sa clientèle en qualité et en quantité, Madame Awa a fait recourt à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui, elle est à son deuxième prêt individuel. Le premier a été correctement remboursé.  
Avec ce deuxième prêt elle compte acheter,  60 paires de chaussures  et 20 sacs à main. Elle s’approvisionne à Bamako  et effectue sa vente dans la ville de Koutiala à une clientèle composée  de jeunes filles et de femmes mariées  au comptant ou à crédit.  
Avec l’augmentation de son chiffre d’affaire, elle compte sur un bénéfice mensuel de 150.000 FCFA qu’elle envisage utiliser pour le remboursement du prêt de Soro Yiriwaso, satisfaire ses propres besoins, entretenir ses enfants  et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Married and the mother of five children, Ms. Awa C. is 46 years old and lives with her husband and her children in the Hamdallaye district of Koutiala Prefecture (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  Not having had the chance to continue in primary school, Awa took no time at all to become interested in revenue-generating work at an early age at her mother's side.  Awa has been working for herself now for over twenty years.  Her main business is in selling gift items (shoes, bags, fine accessories, etc.).  She also offers a range of hairdressing services.  She is in high demand by women in Koutiala City. Concerned about increasing her working capital and satisfying her customers with regard to quantity and quality, she turned to the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and is now on her second individual loan.  The first one was correctly repaid.  With this second loan, she intends to buy sixty pairs of shoes and twenty handbags.  She gets her supplies from Bamako and sells, cash or credit accepted, in Koutiala City to a customer base composed of girls and married women.  With the increase in her sales, she plans on a monthly profit of 150,000 francs CFA that she envisions using for repaying the Soro Yiriwaso loan, for meeting her own needs, for providing for her children, and for investing the rest in her business. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying shoes and bags

loans.name: Tovuz

texts.en:
Tovuz S. was born in 1960. She is married and has four children but her husband is dead.

Tovuz is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan, Fuzuli town, now settled in Absheron region. She has been in her business for six years.

Now Tovuz S. needs a loan of 2,000 AZN to buy more clothes to sell to improve her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Bernard

texts.en: Mr. N. Bernard is a forty-two year old businessman. He has a retail shop which he has been operating for over four years. He wants to use the loan for increasing his working capital by purchasing retail items such as soap, rice, sugar, cooking oil, salt, and mostly essentials for sale. He expects to own a large wholesale business.

loans.use: Store inventory

loans.name: Fatoumata

texts.fr:
Madame Fatoumata S.  est âgée de 42 ans, mariée et mère de 4 enfants. Elle vit dans une famille polygame dans le quartier Hamdallaye de la préfecture de Koutiala (région de Sikasso) avec son mari, sa co-épouse et leurs enfants. 
N’ ayant pas eu la chance de fréquenter l’école,  elle n’a pas pris du temps à embrasser le commerce depuis à bas âge  auprès de sa mère et exerce pour elle-même il y a 6 ans . Après avoir mené plusieurs activités, elle finit par choisir l’achat et  la vente des tissus  avec les bazins teintés, de l’atièké et  divers autres articles. De temps à autres elle fait également de la teinture. Sa notoriété est bonne car elle vend une grande quantité d’articles dans le mois. 
 Pour la bonne satisfaction de sa clientèle en quantité et en qualité, elle décida de  faire recours à  l ‘institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a 4 ans. Après  5 prêts  solidaires tous payés correctement, elle est à son 2ème prêt individuel, le précédent a été correctement payé.  
Avec ce  financement  Fatoumata  compte acheter, 5 pièces de bazin moins riche, 10 sacs d’atiéké et autres articles divers. 
Elle s’approvisionne à Bamako (capitale du Mali) et à Bouaké en (Côte d’Ivoire) et effectue sa vente dans le marché Hamdallaye de Koutiala à une clientèle  constituée de femmes et d’hommes, au comptant et à crédit.  
Elle compte  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 90.000 FCFA  qu’elle envisage  utiliser pour  le remboursement du prêt de Soro Yiriwaso, participer aux dépenses quotidiennes de la famille et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mrs. Fatoumata S. is 42 years old, married and the mother of four children. She lives in a polygamous family in the Hamdallaye district of the Kouitala prefecture (the region of Sikasso) with her husband, the other wife of her husband and their children. As she did not have an opportunity to attend school, she lost no time in dedicating herself to working besides her mother from an early age on. She launched an independent business six years ago. After having tried various activities, she settled on the resale of dyed “bazin” cloth [traditional damask-like cloth in West Africa], “atieke” [processed cassava product for a couscous-like dish] and various other items. She sometimes dyes fabric as well. She is well known and sells a large volume of items each month. In order to satisfy the demands of her customers in terms of both quantity and quality, four years ago she decided to seek help from the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso. She had obtained five joint loans as a member of a group, all of which have been properly repaid. This would be her second individual loan, and the previous one was properly repaid as well. With this loan she plans to purchase five pieces of simple "bazin" cloth, 10 bags of “atieke” and various other articles. She purchases her stock in Bamako, the capital of Mali and in Bouaké in Côte d’Ivoire and sells at the Hamdallaye market in Koutiala to a customer base composed of both women and men, for cash and on credit. She plans to achieve a monthly income of 90,000 West African Francs, which she intends to use to repay her loan to Soro Yiriwaso, contribute to the family budget and invest the remainder in her business.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing various articles (for resale)

loans.name: Phal's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Phal P. is 40 years old and the president of a sixteen-member loan group in Toul Krosang village in Kandal province. With the loan, the group members hope to increase their incomes and improve their families' living conditions. Mrs. Phal P. owns a general store where she sells groceries. Her husband is a farmer who rents a small plot of land to cultivate lotus plants. In order to support both businesses, Mrs. Phal P. is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer for her husband's farming as well as more groceries to sell. The couple has four children; one is a farm laborer while the other three attend the local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer  for farming and groceries

loans.name: Kima

texts.en: Kima A. lives in Ijevan with her husband, a son (now serving in the Armenian Army) and a daughter. Kima’s elder daughter is married and lives separate from her parents. For the past 12 years Kima has sold men's, women's, and children's clothes. With the income from her business, she was able to buy her own little shop where she has a section selling toys. Kima needs 1,000,000 AMD loan to renew her inventory of spring season’s clothes.

loans.use: To renew her inventory of spring season’s clothes

loans.name: Salimata

texts.fr:
Âgée de 34 ans et mère d’un enfant, Madame Salimata D. (en instance de divorce avec son mari) vit  chez ses parents dans le quartier Kouloukoro de la préfecture de Koutiala (troisième région du Mali).
N’ayant pas eu la chance de continuer les études primaires, Salimata n’a pas pris du temps à s’intéresser aux activités génératrices de revenus auprès de sa maman depuis son jeune âge et l’exerce pour elle-même depuis maintenant 11 ans. Son activité principale est la vente des bijoux, chaussures, pagnes et autres articles divers. Elle est très sollicitée et appréciée par les femmes de la ville de Koutiala. 
Afin d’augmenter son fonds de commerce  et satisfaire sa clientèle en qualité, Madame Salimata décida de rejoindre  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso en  2007. Après  2 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) tous payés correctement, elle est à son 2ème  prêt  individuel dont le premier fut également correctement remboursé.  
Avec ce financement elle compte acheter, une quantité importante de colliers et 20 paires de chaussures. Elle s’approvisionne à Bamako et souvent au Sénégal  et effectue sa vente dans la ville de Koutiala à une clientèle composée  de jeunes filles et de femmes mariées  au comptant et à  crédit.  
Elle compte sur un bénéfice mensuel de 100.000 FCFA  qu’elle envisage utiliser pour le remboursement du prêt   de Soro Yiriwaso,  satisfaire ses besoins, entretenir son enfant  et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Age 34 and mother of one child, Mrs. Salimata D. (in the process of divorcing her husband) lives with her parents in the Kouloukoro quarter of Koutiala city (3rd region of Mali). Never having had the chance to finish elementary school, Salimata did not have time to take an interest in work except for her mother's business. She has now done the same work for 11 years. Her main business is the purchase of jewelry, shoes, fabrics, and other various items. She is often solicited for her business and appreciated by the women of Koutiala. In order to increase her commercial funds and satisfy her customers with quality work, Mrs. Salimata decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in 2007. After two group loans which are repaid, she is on her second individual loan. The first was repaid in full. With this loan, she counts on purchasing a large quantity of necklaces and 20 pairs of shoes. She gets her stock in Bamako and often in Sénégal. She makes her sales in the city of Koutiala to young girls and married women. Sales are made in both cash and credit. She plans on making a monthly profit of 100,000 FCFA which she will use to repay the loan from Soro Yiriwaso, meet her needs, support her child, and invest the rest in her business.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of necklaces and shoes

loans.name: Yahaya

texts.en: Mr. S. Yahaya M. is forty-three years old. He has a retail shop and he has been operating the business for five years. He will use the loan to purchase soap, eggs, posho, sugar, cooking oil, paraffin, rice and other accessories. His dream is setting up a large whole sale shop.

loans.use: Grocery store inventory

loans.name: Rim's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Rim S. is 54 years old and is the president of this village bank, as she was selected by its 12 members. This village bank is located in Toul Krosang village in Kandal province. The members will use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Rim S. and her husband, Mr. Y. Yim, are laborers who receive a small salary to support their family. In order to increase their income to improve the family's standard of living, Mrs. Rim S. decided to ask for a loan to buy piglets and pig feed for her new business. This couple has five children; two are laborers while the other three are attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy piglets and pig feed

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Buy groundnuts, rice, palm oil

loans.name: In God We Trust Group

texts.en:
This group of entrepreneurs calls their group 'In God We Trust'. Zainab B. is the group’s leader. She is a 38-year-old, born in Bo, a city in southern Sierra Leone. She is married to a driver and they have 5 children – 2 in secondary school, 1 in primary school, and the others are no longer attending school. 

Zainab sells charcoal, firewood, and gara lappers (locally dyed cloth). She has been a businesswoman for 20 years. With this loan, Zainab will improve her business by buying more charcoal, firewood and gara-lapper-making materials like ink, caustic soda, powder etc.

(Attached to this photo is a snapshot of a borrower who was not able to be present for the group photo.)

loans.use: Buy more charcoal, firewood, and gara-lapper-making materials like ink, caustic soda, powder etc.

loans.name: Hope Sisters Group

texts.en:
Forty-year-old Fatu J. is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. They named their group 'Hope Sisters'. They have formed themselves into a group of four in order to seek a loan of SLL 700,000 for each from SMT/Kiva lenders.  With the help of this loan, they can improve their business both in size and quality. In this way, they can make more sales, better profit, and consequently improve their standard of living. 

Their leader Fatu, who was born in Sanda village, northern Sierra Leone, is married and has seven children – two in college, two in secondary school and three businessmen. Fatu sells a wide variety of items at the Makeni lorry park. Some of the items she sells include Maggi cubes (used to give sauce a sweet taste), salt, soap, toothpaste, etc. With her share of this loan, she will buy the above-mentioned items wholesale to add to her current stock.

loans.use: Buy Maggi cubes, salt, soap, toothpaste, etc. wholesale

loans.name: Bothraney Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the 'Bothraney' group from Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They are petty businesswomen who have come together to seek a loan of SLL 500,000 for each member of the group from SMT/Kiva lenders. With the help of this loan, they can expand their businesses, make more sales, and consequently improve their standard of living. 

Memunatu M. who was born in Kono, eastern Sierra Leone, is the leader of the group. The 40-year-old is married to a businessman and they have two children who are attending primary school. For four years now, Memunatu has been selling market food such as Maggi cubes (used to give sauce a sweet taste) and palm oil (the most popular cooking oil). With her share of the loan, she will buy Maggi cubes and palm oil wholesale.

loans.use: Buy Maggi and palm oil wholesale

loans.name: Yaide Street Group

texts.en:
Mabinty K. is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs from Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. She has been selling rice, palm oil (the most popular cooking oil), salt, etc. for six years now. She is a 40-year-old, married with five children. Three of her children are attending secondary school and two are in primary school. 

Like other mothers, she wants to give her children a proper education and a bright future. She depends on her business in order to achieve this. In order to improve her business, she and her group members have applied for a loan of SLL 800,000 for each member of the group from SMT, a partner of Kiva in Sierra Leone. With the help of this loan, Mabinty will buy rice, palm oil, salt and different other types of market-food wholesale to add to her business inventory.

loans.use: Buy rice, palm oil, salt, etc. wholesale to add to her business inventory

loans.name: Tanut Group

texts.en:
Isatu C. is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs from Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. She has been selling different types of clothes and fabrics for many years now. She is a 40-year-old, married to a driver, and they have three children. Two of her children are attending secondary school and the other is a lorry driver. 

Like other mothers, Isatu wants to give her children a proper education and a bright future. She however depends on her business in order to achieve this. She and her group members have thus applied for a loan of SLL 4,400,000 from SMT, a partner of Kiva in Sierra Leone in order to expand their businesses. With the help of this loan, Isatu will buy bales of clothes to add to her business. 

(Attached to this photo are some snapshots of borrowers who were not able to be present for the group photo.)

loans.use: Buy bales of clothes to add to her business

loans.name: Kalomp Group

texts.en:
Sheik Ibrahim K. is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Ibrahim is an owner of a small shop where he sells sugar, soft drinks, biscuits and many more items. He has been a businessman for many years now. The 50-year-old Ibrahim is married and has sixteen children. Four of his children are attending secondary school, seven are attending primary school and five are married and living on their own. 

Ibrahim depends on his little shop to make a living. In order to improve his business, he and members of the group have applied for a loan of SLL 1,000,000 for each person in the group. With the help of this loan, Ibrahim will buy the above-mentioned items wholesale to add to his shop's inventory.

loans.use: Buy sugar, soft drinks, biscuits, etc to add to his shop's inventory

loans.name: Edward B.'s Group

texts.en:
These are teachers at a primary school in Mabonkani village, in northern Sierra Leone. This school was opened in 1972 by the Wesleyan Church of Sierra Leone (WCSL) to educate the children of Mabonkani village and near-by villages. Currently, the school is staffed with eight teachers and has 318 pupils.

School staff from this institution, like many other schools' staff within SMT’s operational areas, come to SMT to apply for loans. With the help of these loans, they can accomplish certain tasks that they would otherwise not have been able to accomplish with their mere salaries alone. But with the help of this loan, some can pay school fees for their children; others can use the loan to buy pieces of furniture, a plot of land, house-building materials, or invest in business. At the end of each month, these teachers can repay the loan out of their monthly salaries. The institution’s bursar is directly responsible for deducting the repayment and pays SMT on their behalf.

Edward B. S. is the leader of this group of teachers. The 60-year-old was born in Mabonkani village. He is married to a teacher and they have five children.  Edward, who has been a teacher for thirty-eight years, is requesting a loan of SLL 1,500,000 in order to pay school fees and other school-related charges for his children. 

(Attached to this photo is the snapshot of a borrower who was not able to be present for the group photo.)

loans.use: Pay school fees and school-related charges for his children

loans.name: Jonathan L.'s Group

texts.en:
These are teachers at a primary school in Kapethe village, in northern Sierra Leone. This school was opened in 1973 by the Wesleyan Church of Sierra Leone (WCSL) to educate the children of Kapethe village and near-by villages. Currently, the school is staffed with 10 teachers and has 205 pupils.

School staff from this institution, like many other schools' staff within SMT’s operational areas, come to SMT to apply for loans. With the help of these loans, they can accomplish certain tasks that they would otherwise have not being able to accomplish with their mere salaries alone. But with the help of this loan, some can pay school fees for their children; others can use the loan to buy pieces of furniture, a plot of land, house-building materials, or invest in business. At the end of each month, these teachers can repay the loan out of their monthly salaries. The institution’s bursar is directly responsible for deducting the repayment and pays SMT on their behalf.

Jonathan L. J. is the leader of this group of teachers. The 53-year-old was born in Kapethe village. He is married to a businesswoman and they have five children.  Jonathan, who has been a teacher for thirty years, is requesting a loan of SLL 500,000 in order to pay school fees and other school-related charges for his children.

loans.use: Pay school fees and other school-related charges for his children

loans.name: Turan

texts.en: H. Turan was born 1990. She is single. Turan live in the Absheron region with her family. She has run a consulting business for 3 years. Now she needs a loan of 2,000 Azerbaijani manat to improve her business by buying a computer.

loans.use: To buy a computer

loans.name: Moeurn's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Moeurn L. is 40 years old and she is the village bank president who has selected by all ten group members who are located in Toul Krosang village in Kandal province. Each member will use the loan for a different purpose. Mrs. Moeurn L. is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate lotus to earn a living. She decided to ask for a loan to purchase fertilizer and gasoline to support her crops. Her husband, Mr. Ros Yin, is a construction worker who receives a small salary to support his family. This couple has five children. Two of the children are construction workers who support their father's business, one is a laborer and the last one is a student in the local school.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and gasoline

loans.name: Sulaiman

texts.en: Mr. S. Sulaiman is forty-nine years old. He has a charcoal store. He is using the loan to expand his business by purchasing bags of charcoal from villages to resell at his store. He has been operating the business for eight years. He expects to own a large wholesale charcoal store to attract as many customers as he can.

loans.use: To buy charcoal

loans.name: Thioro

texts.fr:
Madame Ba née Thioro N. est mère de 2 enfants âgés de 9 ans et 5 ans. Elle est couturière et s’active depuis 2002 dans le commerce pour, dit-elle, diversifier ses activités et suivre aussi les pas de sa famille qui compte de grands commerçants. Elle vend divers produits du genre produits cosmétiques, tissus, habits, poulets, produits aphrodisiaques…... etc. 
Elle est à sa quatrième demande de crédit au niveau de U-IMCEC et souhaitait  avec ce prêt compléter son approvisionnement en produits pour renforcer son commerce.
Enfin, Madame Ba née Thioro N. âgée de 30 ans trouve dans ses activités, une certaine indépendance financière.
texts.en:
Mrs Thioro N. Ba is the mother of two children, aged 9 and 5 years old. She is a dressmaker and has been in this business since 2002 because, she says, she wanted to diversify her business and follow in her family's footsteps of large merchants. She sells a variety of cosmetic products, cloth, clothes, chickens, aphrodisiacs, etc. She is requesting her fourth loan from the micro-finance group U-IMCEC and will use this all of this loan to purchase supplies for her store, in order to strengthen her business. Finally, at the age of 30, Mrs Thioro N. Ba has found a certain financial independence through her business.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase diverse supplies

loans.name: Serigne Mohamed Cheikh

texts.fr: Monsieur Serigne Mohamed Cheikh D. est un père de famille âgée de 59 ans. Il est cultivateur comme tous ses camarades grandis dans son terroir où l’agriculture constituait  le 1er secteur d’activité. Ainsi au fil des années, Monsieur D. s’est formé au métier de chauffeur et s’est transformé en grand chauffeur pendant de longues années. Maintenant, avec son âge avancé, source de problèmes physique, Monsieur D. s’est converti en commerçant de pièces détachées. Il gère actuellement un magasin de pièces détachées dans la gare routière de Bambey. C’est ainsi, pour renforcer  son magasin qu’il sollicite un prêt au niveau d’U-IMCEC. Il souhaite se réapprovisionner  en acide, huile de moteur, liquide de freins, cartouche huile et gasoil….
texts.en:
Mr. Serigne Mohamed Cheikh D. is a family man and father who is 59 years old. Like all his friends who grew up in the same area as him, where agriculture is the primary sector of activity, he is a farmer. Over the years, Mr D. also taught himself how to be a driver and did a lot of driving for many years. Now, at his advanced age, which has brought with it physical problems, Mr. D. has changed profession again and is selling spare parts. He is currently managing a spare parts shop at the bus station in Bambey. In order to build up his shop, he is accordingly requesting a loan from U-IMCEC (a Sénégalese association of mutual loans and savings instititutions). He would like to stock up on acid, engine oil, brake fluid, oil and diesel filters...

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To stock up his shop with spare parts

loans.name: Vaghinak

texts.en:
Vaghinak G. is 36 years old. He lives in Vanadzor city with his wife and three children: two school-aged daughters and a two-year-old son. 
Vaghinak manages his own business, which consists of selling men’s shoes and sweaters. With the income from his business, Vaghinak solves his family's needs. Vaghinak needs a 900,000-AMD loan to buy spring season's shoes for his shop.

loans.use: To buy spring season's shoes for his shop.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of a new motor for a vehicle

loans.name: Félicité

texts.fr: A. Félicité est née le 19 Février 1975 à Comé au Bénin. Félicité est mariée à TOMEDE Louis Charles, et est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Félicité vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari, au quartier Xwlacodji à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Il y a près de 26 ans que Félicité vit dans ce quartier. Le couple assure ensemble les différentes charges familiales. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Félicité mène comme activité la vente d'huile d'arachide et divers autres produits (riz, farine de maïs, etc.) à son domicile. Félicité a 16 ans d'expérience dans l'exercice de cette activité et est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé. Félicité a obtenu déjà six crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qui ont tous été bien remboursés. Félicité désire agrandir un peu plus son activité, pour faire face à la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de sa clientèle. C'est pour cette raison que Félicité sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un autre prêt.
texts.en:
Félicité A. was born on 19 February 1975 in Comé in Bénin. She is married to Louis Charles TOMEDE and is mother to three children, who are all at school. Félicité lives together with her children and her husband in the Xwlacodji district of Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. She has lived in this area for almost 26 years. The couple shares responsibility for the various family expenses. In order to provide for her needs, Félicité has a business selling peanut oil and a variety of other products (rice, cornflour, etc.) from home. She has 16 years of experience in this business and is a regular client of ALIDé. She has already had six loans from ALIDé, all of which have been repaid in full. Félicité would like to expand her business a little in order to meet ever increasing customer demand. It is for this reason that she is requesting another loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of containers of peanut oil, bags of rice and corn.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of ginger to plant

loans.name: Vusal

texts.en: Vusal lives in the Absheron region with his family. Vusal is 33 years old. He is single. Vusal Q. sells the thingss for beach. How you saw in this picture he sell a chaise lounge. Vusal has been in this business for 3 years. Now this young man needs a loan of 2000 Azerbaijani manat to improve his business.

loans.use: Business improvement

loans.name: Dalsi

texts.en:
Dalsi is a 37-year-old married woman living in Kiyanduwa, Akurassa, with her husband and one child.

Dalsi’s husband has a business selling vegetables and fruit from a shop in her town of Akurassa. She is also a partner in his business. She has been operating this business for five years, so she has lots of experience in this type of business. She knows all the local vegetables and fruits very well as a result of her experience.
 
Dalsi has asked for a 50,000 LKR loan from BRAC Sri Lanka in order to further develop her fruit and vegetable business.

Dalsi is honest and careful in the business. She hopes to provide a nutritious diet to her family through the additional income her business generates.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To develop fruit and vegetable business

loans.name: Elisabeth

texts.fr: Née en 1967 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, A. Elisabeth vit depuis environs 26 ans au quartier Xwlacodji à Cotonou. C’est une veuve qui est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Elisabeth vit seule avec ses enfants et assure les différentes charges de la famille. Elisabeth n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants, Elisabeth vend des tissus, de façon ambulante. De plus, Elisabeth prépare et vend également de la nourriture (pâte rouge de Maïs) devant l’école primaire de Xwlacodji.  Elisabeth s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Elisabeth exerce cette activité depuis 15 ans, et est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé. Elisabeth a déjà bénéficié de six crédits auprès de ALIDé, et les a tous bien remboursés. Elisabeth sollicite un autre prêt en vue d’élever davantage le niveau de son activité de vente de tissus et de se faire plus de profits.
texts.en:
Born in 1967 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin, Elisabeth A. has lived for around 26 years in the Xwlacodji district of Cotonou. She is a widow who is mother to three children, all of whom are at school. Elisabeth lives alone with her children and takes responsibility for the family's various expenses. She did not go to school. In order to provide for her needs and those of her children, Elisabeth sells fabric on a door to door basis. Furthermore, she prepares and also sells food (red corn dough) in front of the primary school in Xwlacodji. Elisabeth gets her supplies in Dantokpa, Bénin's international market. She has been carrying out this activity for 15 years and is a regular client of ALIDé. She has already had six loans from ALIDé and repaid them all in full. She is requesting another loan in order to raise the level of her fabric-selling activity and in order to make more money.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of pieces of fabric

loans.name: Nogaye

texts.fr: Madame Nogaye L. est une femme mariée et âgée de 36 ans. Elle s’active dans le commerce de  draps de lit. En effet, elle a été attirée dans ce business  par la beauté des draps que confectionnés  des femmes de Touba (ville religieuse située à  180 Kms de Dakar). Ainsi, pour trouver une source de revenus ces femmes la fournissaient des draps qu’elle vendait à ses connaissances. Et depuis lors, elle s’identifie dans ce commerce de draps de lit. Elle souhaite, cependant, un prêt de 150 000 FCFA pour s’approvisionner auprès de ses fournisseurs et pour développer son activité
texts.en:
Mrs. Nogaye L. is a married lady who is 36 years old. She is active in the sale of bed sheets. She was actually attracted to this business by the beauty of the sheets made by the women in Touba (a religious town 180 miles from Dakar). Accordingly, in order to find a source of income these ladies provided her with sheets which she sold to her acquaintances. Since then she has made a name for herself in this business. She would, however, like a loan of 150,000 FCFA in order to get fresh stock from her suppliers and to build up her business.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of sheets to resell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of bags of flour

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en:
Ibrahim K. is married and has three children, all attending school. He accessed funds from a friend and established a business selling men's wear. As his business continued to progress, he thought it fit to change from the sale of used clothing to the sale of school bags and travel bags.

He was a member of our group-lending program and has a good credit history. Ibrahim is now seeking a loan to buy more stock and generate more income that he will use to cater to his family and to save to construct a house in the future.

loans.use: To buy used school and travel bags

loans.name: Yunus

texts.en: Yunus A. Is married and has 2 children. He was born in 1970. Yunus A. and his family live in the Absheron region. He has been in the taxi business for 5 years. Now Yunus needs a loan of 2000 Azerbaijani manat to buy spare parts to improve his business.

loans.use: To buy spare parts

loans.name: Catherine

texts.fr: M. Catherine est mariée à TOSSAVI Romain, et est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Parmi les enfants, deux restent à la charge de Catherine  et de son mari. Catherine vit avec ses enfants et son mari au quartier Agla à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Le couple se partage les différentes charges familiales. Catherine n’a jamais été à l’école. Pour assurer ses besoins et contribuer aux dépenses de la famille, Catherine vend des bambous à Agla. Catherine s’approvisionne à Dogbo et à Adja au Mono. Catherine a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a tous bien remboursés. Catherine désire augmenter le stock de ses produits et accroître sa clientèle, afin de se faire plus de revenus. C’est pour cette raison que Catherine sollicite un troisième crédit.
texts.en:
Catherine M. is married to Romain Tossavi and is the mother of three children; all of her children attend school. Catherine and her husband still have two of their children at home. Catherine lives with her children and husband in the neighborhood of Agla in Cotonou, the financial capital of Benin. The couple takes care of the family's various needs. Catherine never attended school. In order to take care of her needs and contribute to her family's expenses, Catherine sells bamboo in Agla. She supplies herself in Dogbo and Adja au Mono. Catherine has received two previous loans from ALIDé, both of the loans were fully repaid. She would like to increase the stock of her products and grow her clientele, and therefore earn more money. It is for this reason that Catherine is requesting a third loan.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase bamboo

loans.name: Marie

texts.fr: Née en 1955 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, A. Marie est mariée à KOFFI Barthélémy, un directeur d’école. Le couple a quatre enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. En plus de leurs enfants, le couple a un autre enfant à leur charge. Il y a près de 25 ans que Marie s’est installée avec son mari au quartier Akpakpa Dodomé à Cotonou, où elle y vit également avec ses enfants. Le couple assure ensemble les diverses charges familiales. Marie n’a pas été à l’école. Depuis une quinzaine d’année, Marie mène comme activité, la vente d’«akassa» (aliment local fait à base d’amidon de maïs), qu’elle prépare et vend par le système de distribution. Marie achète son stock de maïs à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà obtenu neuf crédits, qu’elle a tous bien remboursés. Face à la demande de plus en plus importante de sa clientèle, Marie sollicite un autre prêt afin de renforcer son activité.
texts.en:
Born in 1955 in Cotonou, the financial capital of Benin, Marie A. is married to Barthélémy Koffi, a school director. The couple has four children, all of whom attend school. In addition to their own children, the couple has another child in their care. For almost 25 years, Marie and her husband have lived in the neighborhood of Akpaka Dodomé in Cotonou, where they still live with their children. The couple takes care of the family's needs together. Marie did not attend school. For 15 years, Marie has had a business selling "akassa" (a local food made with cornstarch); she makes the "akassa" and sells it through a distribution system. Marie purchases her stock of corn in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. She is an old client of ALIDé and has already had nine loans with the organization - all of the loans were fully repaid. In order to handle the increasing demands of her clientele, Marie is requesting another loan to strengthen her business.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase sacks of corn

loans.name: Femmes Commerçantes N°11 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupement  Femmes Commerçantes (F.C) comme son nom l’indique est un réseau de femmes qui s’activent  dans le commerce.  Il est basé à Grand Thiès et il a été créé depuis 1992 par Madame Maty Niakh l’actuel président du réseau. Cette présidente a eu cette idée  à l’issue d’une formation qu’elle avait bénéficiée  de l’ONG OXFAM à Thiès. Elle connait, ainsi, bien la gestion de groupe, entreprenariat …etc.  Les membres du réseau sont extrêmement dévoués et se rencontrent une fois par mois. Ainsi, après des frais d’adhésion au groupement, chaque membre est tenu de cotiser mensuellement 200 FCFA pour une caisse de solidarité.
Souhaitant se financer, elles décidèrent  d’adhérer à  U-IMCEC. C’est ainsi que,  leur réseau se voit scinder en 19 sous groupes de 5 personnes  pour un meilleur profit des financements. Elles sollicitent pour une deuxième fois un prêt de 100 000 FCFA par membre,  soit 500 000 FCFA par sous groupe afin de développer leurs diverses activités.
Cependant, les règlements sont versés à la présidente assistée par la trésorière du groupe, Madame Coumba S., pendant leurs réunions mensuelles et ces deux se chargent à leur tour de rembourser U-IMCEC. Ce réseau qui, dit la présidente, n’a qu’un seul et noble objectif : combattre la pauvreté dans les ménages. Actuellement, le réseau compte 19 sous groupes avec chacun une présidente et une trésorière.
Ainsi, le sous groupe Femmes Commerçantes N°11 est dirigée par Madame Aïssatou D. commerçante au marché grand Thiès. Cette âgée de 51 ans vend des légumes, poissons fumés, de l’huile de palme et de la pâte d’arachide depuis 13 ans.Son activité s'était commencé avec la vente de tissus. Mais, vue que l'activité à cette époque ne générait pas trop de revenus, Madame Aïssatou D. s'est repentie ainsi sur la vente de légumes et autres cités au début.
 Elle est, enfin, dans ce sous groupe avec Madame Rokhaya D. la trésorière et vendeuse de poissons frais, Madame Diakhère S. vendeuse d’huile de palme et poissons, Madame Dior T.  qui vend du niébé (haricot) et poissons séchés et  Madame Aisse Diallo vendeuse ambulante de tissus et habillements.
texts.en:
The group “Femmes Commerçantes” (F.C.), as its name indicates, is a network of women who are active in commerce. It is based in Grand Thiès and was founded in 1992 by Ms. Maty Niakh, the network’s current president. She got the idea of forming the network after participating in a training session run by the NGO OXFAM in Thiès. She is therefore quite knowledgeable about group management, entrepreneurship, etc. The network members are extremely devoted and meet once a month.  Beyond a membership fee, each member must pay 200 francs CFA monthly into a solidarity fund. Desiring financing, they decided to join U-IMCEC. This is why their network was split into nineteen sub-groups of five persons each to ensure a better profit outcome. For the second time, they are requesting a loan of 100,000 francs per member, that is 500,000 francs per sub-group, to develop their various businesses. However, payments are made at the monthly meetings to the group president, assisted by the group treasurer, Ms. Coumba S., who are then responsible for reimbursing U-IMCEC. In the words of its president, the network has only one single, noble objective: to fight family poverty. The network currently numbers nineteen sub-groups, each with its own president and treasurer. And so, the sub-group Femmes Commerçantes N°11 is headed by Ms. Aïssatou D., a merchant at the Grand Thiès market.  She is 51 years old and has been selling vegetables, smoked fish, palm oil and peanut butter for thirteen years.  Her business had begun with fabric sales.  But, given that this business did not generate a lot of revenues at the time, she turned with regret to selling vegetables and in other districts at first. Ms. Aïssatou D. is actually in this sub-group with Ms. Rokhaya D., the treasurer and a vendor of fresh fish;  Ms. Diakhère S., a vendor of palm oil and fish;  Ms. Dior T., who sells niébé (black-eyed peas) and dried fish; and Ms. Aisse Diallo, an itinerant vendor of fabrics and clothing.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Bolstering their respective businesses

loans.name: Sriyani

texts.en:
Sriyani is a 30-year-old married woman living in the town of Akurassa, in the Galle District of Sri Lanka, with her two sons and husband.

Sriyani has been managing her business by herself, which consists of cultivating a flower garden. She devotes her full effort towards cultivating her flower garden, step by step, and uses the income to help support her family.

Sriyani has managed her business for three years by herself. In her business she works hard and enjoys high quality land for flower growing and favorable weather in her region of Sri Lanka.

Sriyani has asked for a 20,000 LKR loan from BRAC Sri Lanka in order to pay labor costs and to purchase chemicals to promote the fertility of her flower garden.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To purchase chemicals and help pay labor costs

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter K. is 36 and married to Lucy Maingi.  They are blessed with two children, ages 9 and 2. He has been in the transport industry for the last four years in Naivasha town.

This is Peter’s second loan from KADET, and he has never borrowed from any micro finance institution before. He got to know about KADET through various marketing and promotion activities done by KADET in Naivasha town.

Peter will use this loan to buy a new motorbike to replace the current one.  The new motorbike will enhance his services and enable him to cover the entire Naivasha town and its environs.

His future aspiration is to move from motorbike to a taxi operator.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike

loans.name: Femmes Commerçantes N°10 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupement  Femmes Commerçantes (F.C) comme son nom l’indique est un réseau de femmes qui s’activent  dans le commerce.  Il est basé à Grand Thiès et il a été créé depuis 1992 par Madame Maty Niakh l’actuel président du réseau. Cette présidente a eu cette idée  à l’issue d’une formation qu’elle avait bénéficiée  de l’ONG OXFAM à Thiès. Elle connait, ainsi, bien la gestion de groupe, entreprenariat …etc.  Les membres du réseau sont extrêmement dévoués et se rencontrent une fois par mois. Ainsi, après des frais d’adhésion au groupement, chaque membre est tenu de cotiser mensuellement 200 FCFA pour une caisse de solidarité.
Souhaitant se financer, elles décidèrent  d’adhérer à  U-IMCEC. C’est ainsi que,  leur réseau se voit scinder en 19 sous groupes de 5 personnes  pour un meilleur profit des financements. Elles sollicitent pour une deuxième fois un prêt de 100 000 FCFA par membre,  soit 500 000 FCFA par sous groupe afin de développer leurs diverses activités.
Cependant, les règlements sont versés à la présidente assistée par la trésorière du groupe, Madame Coumba Seck, pendant leurs réunions mensuelles et ces deux se chargent à leur tour de rembourser U-IMCEC. Ce réseau qui, dit la présidente, n’a qu’un seul et noble objectif : combattre la pauvreté dans les ménages. Actuellement, le réseau compte 19 sous groupes avec chacun une présidente et une trésorière.
Madame Yarame  N. est la présidente des Femmes Commerçantes N°10. Cette femme est âgée de 58 ANS et a 3 enfants. Elle vend des légumes et poissons séchés et fumés au marché depuis 2 ans. Cependant elle compte acheter avec sa part du prêt un frigo pour se lancer dans la vente de glace. La trésorière est Madame Isseu F. qui vend elle des légumes et des poissons secs.  Et les autres sont Madame Ndeye Fatou C. vendeuse ambulant de tissus, Madame Khady D. qui vend des légumes  et Madame Codou N. vendeuse de légumes et de poulets de chair.
texts.en:
The group “Femmes Commerçantes” (F.C.), as its name indicates, is a network of women who are active in commerce. It is based in Grand Thiès and was founded in 1992 by Ms. Maty Niakh, the network’s current president. She got the idea of forming the network after participating in a training session run by the NGO OXFAM in Thiès. She is therefore quite knowledgeable about group management, entrepreneurship, etc. The network members are extremely devoted and meet once a month. Beyond a membership fee, each member must pay 200 francs CFA monthly into a solidarity fund. Desiring financing, they decided to join U-IMCEC. This is why their network was split into nineteen sub-groups of five persons each to ensure a better profit outcome. For the second time, they are requesting a loan of 100,000 francs per member, that is 500,000 francs per sub-group, to develop their various businesses. However, payments are made at the monthly meetings to the group president, assisted by the group treasurer, Ms. Coumba Seck, who are then responsible for reimbursing U-IMCEC. In the words of its president, the network has only one single, noble objective: to fight family poverty. The network currently numbers nineteen sub-groups, each with its own president and treasurer. Ms. Yarame N. is the president of Femmes Commerçantes N°10. She is 58 years old and has three children. She has been selling vegetables and dried and smoked fish at the market for two years. However, with her part of the loan, she plans on buying a refrigerator to start selling ice. The treasurer is Ms. Isseu F. who sells vegetables and dried fish. And the others are Ms. Ndeye Fatou C., an itinerant vendor of cloth; Ms. Madame Khady D., who sells vegetables; and Ms. Codou N., a vendor of vegetables and fryer chickens.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Developing their respective businesses

loans.name: Parvin

texts.en:
Parvin D. was born in 1966. He is married and has a child. Parvin is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan, Fuzuli town, now settled in the Fuzuli region. 

He has been in the cattle business for 6 years. Now he needs a loan of 2000 Azerbaijani manat to buy 4 calves for improving his business.

loans.use: to buy 4 calves

loans.name: Odette

texts.fr: Née en 1955 à Abomey, dans le département du Zou, A. Odette est mariée à GBOWOUI Lucien et est mère de cinq enfants, tous scolarisés. Mais seulement trois des enfants restent encore à la charge du couple. Il y a une vingtaine d'année que la famille vit au quartier Fidjrossè à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Le couple assure ensemble les différentes charges familiales. N'ayant jamais été à l'école, Odette vend depuis trente ans, des condiments de sauce (tomates fraîches, piments, oignons, etc.), de l'huile d'arachide dans sa boutique à son domicile. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Odette achète ses produits. Odette a déjà obtenu deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qui ont été tous bien remboursés. En vue d'élever un peu plus le niveau de son activité et de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle, Odette sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un troisième prêt.
texts.en:
Born in 1955 in Abomey, in Zou County, Ms. A. Odette is married to Mr. GBOWOUI Lucien and is the mother of five children, who have all attended school. But only three of the children remain in the couple's care. The family has been living in the Fidjrossè district in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, for about twenty years. Together, the couple make sure their various family expenses are covered. Never having attended school, Odette has been selling sauce condiment for thirty years (fresh tomatoes, chili peppers, onions, etc.) and peanut oil in her store located in her home. She purchases her supplies from Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. She has obtained two loans already from ALIDé that have all been repaid. With the aim of raising her level of business bit by bit and satisfying her customers more, Odette is requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying condiments for making sauces; and peanut oil

loans.name: Kanthi

texts.en:
Kanthi is a 29-year-old married woman, living with her husband and two year old child. She is an educated woman.

Kanthi has a vegetable plot in which her husband provides support. She has a lot of experience in this field as she and her husband started the business three years ago. She is a hardworking woman and very happy about her present family situation.

Kanthi and her husband started the business as a very small one, but now it has grown considerably. Her plot has lots of vegetables such as leafy greens, pumpkins, and mushrooms. She can handle the responsibility of managing a family while working very well.

Kanthi is seeking a 20,000 LKR loan from BRAC Sri Lanka to help expand her cultivation. She appreciates BRAC Sri Lanka providing her a loan to help her expand her business.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To develop her vegetable plot

loans.name: Marthe

texts.fr: Née en 1973 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, V. Marthe est mariée à ZOGBLATI Henri, un mécanicien. Le couple a quatre enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Marthe vit depuis près de 15 ans, au quartier Agla à Cotonou, avec son mari et ses enfants. Le couple se partage les différentes charges familiales. Pour assurer ses besoins et ceux de sa famille, Marthe vend du maïs et de la farine de manioc à son domicile. Marthe achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et également à Godomey, dans la commune d'Abomey-Calavi. Marthe exerce cette activité depuis treize ans, et a déjà obtenu deux crédits auprès de ALIDé. Ces deux crédits ont été bien remboursés. Face à la demande de plus en plus importante de sa clientèle, Marthe sollicite un troisième prêt de ALIDé, en vue d'augmenter le stock de ses produits et de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle
texts.en:
Mr. ZOGBLATI Henri, a mechanic. The couple have four children, who are all in school. With her husband and children, she has been living in the Agla district, in Cotonou, for fifteen years. The couple share in meeting their various family expenses. To ensure their needs are met, Marthe sells corn and cassava flour out of her home. She purchases her supplies from Dantokpa, the international market of Benin, and also from Godomey, in the town of Abomey-Calavi. Marthe has been in this business for thirteen years and has already had two loans with ALIDé. These two loans have indeed been repaid. Facing the burgeoning customer demand, she is requesting a third loan from ALIDé with the aim of augmenting her inventory of goods and satisfying her customers more.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying sacks of corn and cassava flour

loans.name: Yasser

texts.en:
Yasser Hassan N. 32 years old, married, and has seven members in his family. Two of his kids are in school. 

Yasser used to work in Israel as he had permission for entrance, but it was revoked because of the political situation here in Palestine. After that he started to buy sheep and sell them for a small profit. He then enlarged his business and started to make yogurt to sell to his neighbors and nearby grocery stores. 

Yasser wants this loan to enlarge his business by buying extra sheep and making more yogurt, which may increase his profits.

loans.use: To buy sheep for yogurt production

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
Stella N. is a 36-year-old lady married to Karanja Kariuki. They are blessed with two children aged ten and four years. Stella has been selling charcoal for the last six years in Naivasha town.

This is Stella’s first loan from KADET, and she has never borrowed from any micro-finance institution before. She got to know about KADET through her friends in Naivasha town.

Stella will use this loan to restock her fast-growing charcoal business. Apart from selling charcoal, her future aspiration is to set up a boutique in Naivasha town.

loans.use: To restock her fast-growing charcoal business

loans.name: Jacinta

texts.en:
Jacinta W. is a 22-year-old single mother of one boy who is in school. She has been in the clothing industry for the last ten years in Naivasha town.

This is Jacinta’s first loan from KADET, and she has never borrowed from any micro-finance institution before. She got to hear about KADET through her neighbor in Naivasha town.

Jacinta will use this loan to restock her fast-growing tailoring business. Her future aspiration is to grow her business and become a supplier of clothing materials to other tailors in Niavasha town and its environs.

loans.use: To restock her business with fabric for tailoring

loans.name: Suvineetha Priyanthi

texts.en:
Suvineetha Priyanthi is a 45-year-old married woman living in the town of Akurassa, with her husband and her six children aged between seven and twenty-three.

Suvineetha has a vegetable-selling business. She has lots of experience in her business as she has been doing it for twenty-four years. In her business she works hard and is honest and careful. She cooperates well with others and is always in a positive mood. 
 
Suvineetha has asked for a 50,000 LKR loan from BRAC Sri Lanka in order to expand her vegetable venture.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To develop her vegetable business

loans.name: Femmes Commerçantes N°12 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupement  Femmes Commerçantes (F.C) comme son nom l’indique est un réseau de femmes qui s’activent  dans le commerce.  Il est basé à Grand Thiès et il a été créé depuis 1992 par Madame Maty Niakh l’actuel président du réseau. Cette présidente a eu cette idée  à l’issue d’une formation qu’elle avait bénéficiée  de l’ONG OXFAM à Thiès. Elle connait, ainsi, bien la gestion de groupe, entreprenariat …etc.  Les membres du réseau sont extrêmement dévoués et se rencontrent une fois par mois. Ainsi, après des frais d’adhésion au groupement, chaque membre est tenu de cotiser mensuellement 200 FCFA pour une caisse de solidarité.
Souhaitant se financer, elles décidèrent  d’adhérer à  U-IMCEC. C’est ainsi que,  leur réseau se voit scinder en 19 sous groupes de 5 personnes  pour un meilleur profit des financements. Elles sollicitent pour une deuxième fois un prêt de 100 000 FCFA par membre,  soit 500 000 FCFA par sous groupe afin de développer leurs diverses activités.
Cependant, les règlements sont versés à la présidente assistée par la trésorière du groupe, Madame Coumba Seck, pendant leurs réunions mensuelles et ces deux se chargent à leur tour de rembourser U-IMCEC. Ce réseau qui, dit la présidente, n’a qu’un seul et noble objectif : combattre la pauvreté dans les ménages. Actuellement, le réseau compte 19 sous groupes avec chacun une présidente et une trésorière.
Les cinq qui composent ce sous groupe Femmes Commerçantes N°12 sont la présidente Madame Mame Issa D. qui vend du petit déjeuner, Madame Fatou D. trésorière vendeuse ambulante  de tissus et chaussures, Madame Khady G.  vendeuse de poissons séchés, Madame Bineta L.  qui commerce le riz, arachide et huile de palme et de Madame Amy D. vendeuse d’oranges et arachide. 
Quant à la présidente, Madame Mame Issa D., elle est âgée de 40 ans et s’est investi dans son secteur depuis 2007. Avec ce financement, elle  veut diversifier son activité. Elle s'est investie dans ce métier dans le but de subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses 2 enfants et sa chère maman
texts.en:
The group “Femmes Commerçantes” (F.C.), as its name indicates, is a network of women who are active in commerce. It is based in Grand Thiès and was founded in 1992 by Ms. Maty Niakh, the network’s current president. She got the idea of forming the network after participating in a training session run by the NGO OXFAM in Thiès. She is therefore quite knowledgeable about group management, entrepreneurship, etc. The network members are extremely devoted and meet once a month. Beyond a membership fee, each member must pay 200 francs CFA monthly into a solidarity fund. Desiring financing, they decided to join U-IMCEC. This is why their network was split into nineteen sub-groups of five persons each to ensure a better profit outcome. For the second time, they are requesting a loan of 100,000 francs per member, that is 500,000 francs per sub-group, to develop their various businesses. However, payments are made at the monthly meetings to the group president, assisted by the group treasurer, Ms. Coumba Seck, who are then responsible for reimbursing U-IMCEC. In the words of its president, the network has only one single, noble objective: to fight family poverty. The network currently numbers nineteen sub-groups, each with its own president and treasurer. The five who compose this sub-group “Femmes Commerçantes N°12 include the president Ms. Mame Issa D., who sells breakfasts; the treasurer Ms. Fatou D., who is an itinerant vendor of cloth and shoes; Ms. Khady G., a vendor of dried fish; Ms. Bineta L., who trades in rice, peanuts, and palm oil; and Ms. Amy D., a vendor of oranges and peanuts. As for the president, Ms. Mame Issa D., she is 40 years old and has been investing herself in her sector since 2007. With this financing, she wants to diversify her business. She invested herself in this trade with the goal of meeting her needs and those of her two children and her dear mother.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Developing their respective businesses

loans.name: Kamalawathi

texts.en:
Kamalawathi is a 41-year-old married woman in Kekanadura, Matara area. She has three daughters. Her husband has a masonry business.

Kamalawathi works on her own. She has a plot of land where she grows various fruits, vegetables and other products. She has been doing this business for three years and is known to be a very hard-worker. 

Kamalawathi has requested a 20,000 LKR loan from BRAC Sri Lanka in order to purchase fertilizer for her land.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Surangika

texts.en:
Surangika is a 27-year-old married woman who has a daughter and lives in Kekanadura, Matara.

With the help of her husband, Surangika has operated a business for five years now producing ice cream. 

She has asked for a loan of 30,000 LKR from BRAC Sri Lanka to buy a deep-freezer and she hopes to buy a vehicle in future to distribute her ice cream.

Thank you for considering supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To buy a deep-freezer

loans.name: Indika

texts.en:
Indika is a 25-year-old married woman who has a daughter and lives in Kekanadura, Matara. Her husband is a driver.

Indika has a tailoring business that she has been running for four years. She is self-motivated and handles all her work by herself to help support her family.

Now, Indika has asked for a 15,000 LKR loan from BRAC Sri Lanka to buy cloth for her business.

Ultimately, Indika hopes to open a new tailoring shop.

loans.use: To buy cloth for her tailoring shop
