loans.name: Femmes Commerçantes N°9 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupement  Femmes Commerçantes (F.C) comme son nom l’indique est un réseau de femmes qui s’activent  dans le commerce.  Il est basé à Grand Thiès et il a été créé depuis 1992 par Madame Maty Niakh l’actuel président du réseau. Cette présidente a eu cette idée  à l’issue d’une formation qu’elle avait bénéficiée  de l’ONG OXFAM à Thiès. Elle connait, ainsi, bien la gestion de groupe, entreprenariat …etc.  Les membres du réseau sont extrêmement dévoués et se rencontrent une fois par mois. Ainsi, après des frais d’adhésion au groupement, chaque membre est tenu de cotiser mensuellement 200 FCFA pour une caisse de solidarité.
Souhaitant se financer, elles décidèrent  d’adhérer à  U-IMCEC. C’est ainsi que,  leur réseau se voit scinder en 19 sous groupes de 5 personnes  pour un meilleur profit des financements. Elles sollicitent pour une deuxième fois un prêt de 100 000 FCFA par membre,  soit 500 000 FCFA par sous groupe afin de développer leurs diverses activités.
Cependant, les règlements sont versés à la présidente assistée par la trésorière du groupe, Madame Coumba Seck, pendant leurs réunions mensuelles et ces deux se chargent à leur tour de rembourser U-IMCEC. Ce réseau qui, dit la présidente, n’a qu’un seul et noble objectif : combattre la pauvreté dans les ménages. Actuellement, le réseau compte 19 sous groupes avec chacun une présidente et une trésorière.
Les Femmes Commerçantes N°9 est dirigé par Oumy N. vendeuse de couscous  à base de mil  depuis 20 ans. Madame Awa G. est mariée mère de 3 enfants âgés respectivement de 28 ans, 25 ans et 20 ans. la marche de son activité lui a maintenu dans le commerce nous confie t-elle.
La trésorière est Madame Awa G. vendeuse de petits déjeuners dans son quartier. Les autres membres sont Madame Fatma D.  qui vend du couscous et du riz, Madame Fatim D. vendeuse de légumes et Madame Maréme D.  qui vend des produits de lessives et de l’huile de palme.
texts.en:
The Association of "Femmes Commercantes" (F. C) as its name indicates is a network of women who engage in trading. It is based in Grand Thies and was set up since 1992 by Madam Maty Niakh, the current chairwoman of the network. This woman got this idea at the end of a training course that she had received from an NGO OXFAM in Thies. Thus, She knows group management, entrepreneurship etc. The members of the network are extremely dedicated and they meet once in a month. So, each member is required to make a monthly contribution of 200 FCFA to a mutual fund after subscription fees to the network. Hoping to finance themselves, they decided to join U-IMCEC. Their network was thus split to 19 sub-groups of 5 individuals in order to take better advantage of the funding. They are each requesting for the second time a loan of 100 000FCFA that is 500 000FCFA for each sub-group in order to grow their various businesses. Meanwhile, payments are made to the chairwoman assisted by the treasurer of the association, Madam Coumba Seck, during their monthly meetings. These two are required, in turn, to repay U-IMCEC. This network, says the chairwoman, has only one noble objective: fight poverty in the household. Currently, the network has 19 sub-groups with each having a chairwoman and a treasurer. Femmes Commercantes No 9 is directed by Oumy N.. She 's been selling couscous made of millet for 20 years. Madam Awa G. is married and the mother of 3 children, aged 28, 25 and 20 years respectively. She confided in us that running of her business kept her in the trade. The treasurer is Madam Awa G. who sells breakfast in her community. The other members are Madam Fatma D. who sells couscous and rice, Madam Fatim D. who sells vegetables and Madam Mareme D. who sells laundry products and palm oil

Translated from French by Cletus Kuunifaa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To supply products

loans.name: Xaver

texts.en:
Xaver G. is 58 years old and is married with a child. She and her family live in Absheron region.

Xaver has been in her business for ten years. Now she needs a loan of 2,000 AZN to buy cakes, biscuits ,candy, and other items to sell in order to improve her business.

loans.use: To buy cakes, biscuits, candy, and other items to sell

loans.name: Malek

texts.en:
Malek is a 43-year-old married man and father of two dependent children. He has owned a butcher shop in his town since 1993. He has taken his first Kiva loan and he's pleased with his decision to take a loan from Ameen. He has repaid his loan successfully and it will be mentioned by the MFI while uploading of the payments. He says that the loan amount was sufficient for his work. 

Today Malek is planning to take a bigger loan of $1,500 to buy more meat for his shop and attract more clients in order to increase his profits and productivity.

loans.use: To buy more meat

loans.name: Raci

texts.en: Raci is single and lives with his family in the Absheron region. He was born in 1990. Raci has been in the farming business for five years. He like his work very much and hopes that his business will improve day by day. Now he is requesting a loan of 2,000 AZN to buy fertilizers and seeds for improving his business.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and seeds

loans.name: Ndèye Astou

texts.fr: Ndèye Astou M. est une femme de 40ans, elle est mariée et mère de 5 enfants en charge. Elle est membre de Banc Villageois depuis 2ans et a de belles performances avec le crédit. Elle fait de la restauration et son nouveau prêt lui permettra de mieux renforcer son activité afin de se procurer plus de bénéfice et de soutenir son mari pour la construction de leur maison familiale.
texts.en:
Ndèye Astou M. is a 40-year-old woman who is married and the mother of five children to support. She has been a member of Banc Villageois for two years and has a great credit history. She is a restauranteur, and her new loan will enable her to do better bolstering her business. This is in order to obtain more profit and to support her husband in building the family house.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Developing and advancing her income-generating work

loans.name: Mar

texts.fr: Monsieur Mar  G. est un commerçant  de 56 ans qui habite à Yoff Dagoudane. Il est marie et père de 5 enfants dont l’âge  varie entre 20 et 29 ans. Il est sociétaire  de la caisse de Yoff  depuis avril 2007 et a déjà bénéficié  d’un prêt antérieur. Aussitôt qu’il a pris sa retraite en aout 2009 il s’est lance dans le commerce de céréales  de toutes sortes et d’aliment de bétail. Il gère  un local qu’il a pris en location en face de son domicile qui partage le même  mur avec la caisse de Yoff. Monsieur G. a choisi cette activité pour trouver une solution a la réduction de ses ressources financières  afin qu’il puisse continuer à supporter les charges familiales. Il sollicite un crédit de 250 000 frs  prévu pour   l’achat de 2 tonnes de mil  destine a la vente. Son  objectif  est d’assurer la dépense quotidienne, d’améliorer  le cadre de vie de sa famille.et de supporter les frais de scolarité de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Mr. Mar G. is a 56-year-old merchant who lives in Yoff Dagoudane. He is married and the father of five children, who range in age from 20 to 29.  He has been a member of the credit association of Yoff since 2007 and has already benefited from a past loan.  As soon as he retired in August 2009, he got started working in the business of all kinds of grains and animal feed.  Mar manages a place which he rents opposite his home and which has a common wall with the Yoff branch.  He chose this business to find a solution to his reduction in financial resources, so that he may continue to cover family expenses.  Mar is requesting a loan of 250,000 francs he plans to use for buying two tonnes of millet destined to be sold.  His goal is to cover day-to-day expenses, to improve his family's living conditions, and to pay for his children's schooling costs.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing his working capital

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase more beverages for her restaurant

loans.name: Wassim

texts.en:
Wassim is a 27-year-old single man living with his family. He has had a men's clothing shop since 2007 and has eight years of experience in this occupation. He profited from his first Kiva loan and he's thankful for its results. He has been very reliable with his repayments to Ameen and has repaid on time the entire loan. 

Today, Wassim is asking for a new loan of 1,200 USD to purchase more merchandise for his business, specifically to increase his selection of new collections and to offer a bigger choice of clothes to his clients for the summer season. And he's certain that with the new loan, his business productivity and his income will increase.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing to sell

loans.name: Rafail

texts.en:
Rafail N. has been in the auto-repair business for nine years. He was born in 1960. Rafail is married and has two children. Rafail and his family live in Baku city. You can see in this picture he is repairing a car. 

Now this man needs a loan of 2000 Azerbaijan New Manats to buy spare parts to improve his business.

loans.use: To buy the spare parts

loans.name: Bakuseka Maggya Group Of  Kampala

texts.en:
37-year-old, N. Hadijah has been selling produce for the last twenty years in Owino market in Kampala. With her kind of business, good customer care skills are vital. With these in tow, she has been able to establish herself a strong niche in her operating area.

Hadijah reveals that, in a month, she makes profits amounting to 100,000 shillings, and it’s with this that she has been able to educate her six children.

Hadijah has faced problems in her business such as the high costs involved in transporting produce to her workplace. On the basis of this, she wants to be empowered by this loan to be able to expand into a wholesale business. A wholesale produce business, she says, involves less transportation costs as, for the most part, farmers bring in deliveries fewer times in a given period.

With the loan, Hadijah  plans the construction of a much bigger food stall for herself and she also wants to foot the costs of increased fruits and vegetable supplies to her workplace.

loans.use: To construct a much bigger food stall and to pay for increased fruits and vegetable supplies

loans.name: Corine

texts.en: Corine is a 19-year-old young woman living with her parents and one brother. In order to help with her family’s expenses, Corine has opened a beauty salon in a room of her home where she offers beauty services to her clients. She has become well known in her village. With the $1,200 loan she has requested, she plans to expand her home business by adding new services and equipment. She says that her business productivity and income will both increase as a result since she will be able to attract new clients.

loans.use: adding new services and equipment

loans.name: Deyvis Alexander

texts.es:
Deyvis tiene 19 años es soltero no tiene hijos, vive en casa de sus padres, labora hace 1 
año como obrero de campo en un fundo de la zona, en el cual se dedica a cultivar 
espárragos, Deyvis se encuentra ahorrando para posteriormente estudiar una carrera 
técnica y poder ayudar a sus padres. El tiene muchos deseos de superación por ese 
motivo es que desea ayudar a construir una parte de la vivienda de sus padres la cual 
fue seriamente afectada por el terremoto. Solicita el crédito para la compra de 
materiales de construcción.
texts.en:
Deyvis is single, 19 years old and has no children. He lives at home with his parents. He's been working for one year as a field worker in a main area, in which he's been growing asparagus. Deyvis is saving money to one day pursue a technical career and to be able to help his parents. He has many aspirations, one of which is to build a part of his parents' house that was seriously affected by the earthquake. He is asking for a loan to buy construction materials.

Translated from Spanish by Jo Longnecker, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy construction materials

loans.name: Edilsa  Del Carmen

texts.es:
Edilsa del Carmen C. D. M.  tiene 56 años y vive en el barrio Ciudadela 20 D. Julio en el sur D. Barranquilla, barrio comercial y bastante transitado donD. coexisten residencias con centros comerciales, supermercados y negocios ambulantes y estacionarios. Edilsa es madre  D. tres hijos en las edades D. 28 a 32 años y tiene varios negocios: preparación y venta D. jugos naturales y D. fritos donD. trabaja con un ayudante desD. la 8 D. la mañana hasta las 8 D. la noche y tambien se dedica a la  venta D. ropa, calzado y cosméticos, que lo realiza D. manera transversal a lo largo D. cada día.
Edilsa y su familia proviene D. San Pedro en el departamento D. Sucre donD. antes trabajaba en casas D. familia, mientras su esposo manejaba maquinaria pesada como operario. Cuando él se quedó desempleado, decidieron trasladarse a Barranquilla a "probar suerte". Edilsa inició el negocio hace 12 años con su esposo, que ahora trabaja en Venezuela; ella aprendió empíricamente viendo a otros elaborar jugos y  teniendo en cuenta los gustos D. su cónyuge. Hace 2 años Edilsa recibió su primer crédito con la Fundación y dice que sus dos  financiaciones le han servido para mejorar su nivel D. vida y el D. su familia y que está saliendo D. los préstamos costosos. El crédito D. $2.000.000 que ahora solicita lo invertirá en la compra D. frutas naturales para los jugos, como zapote, níspero, maracuyá y naranja e insumos para los fritos como harina y aceite; y para su negocio D. mercancias, comprará útiles D. papelería, ropa y cosméticos.
El sueño D. Edilsa es montar una tipografía con su hijo, su novia y un primo. Este sueño es también su mayor desafío porque en adición D. los 2 computadores y vitrina que ya tiene, requiere la compra D. otro computador, una fotocopiadora y una laminadora.
texts.en:
Edilsa del Carmen C. D. M. is 56 years old and lives in the Citadel neighborhood called the 20th of July in the South of Barranquilla, in a commercial, high-occupancy district, where co-exists private residences, businesses, supermarkets and mobile and stationary businesses. Edilsa is a mother to three children, ages 28 to 32, and has several business enterprises: preparing and selling natural juices, and working with assistant selling fried foods, where she works from 8 in the morning until 8 in the evening. She also sells clothing, stockings and cosmetics, during the course of her day. Edilsa comes from San Pedro in the Sucre State where she was previously working in family homes while her husband worked operating heavy machinery. When he became unemployed, they decided to move to Barranquilla to "try their luck." Edilsa started her business twelve years ago with her husband, who now works in Venezuela. She learned by experience watching others and taking into account her customers' tastes. Two years ago, Edilsa received her first loan with the Foundation. She says the financing from the two loans has helped her improve her level of life and that of her family. They are getting out from under their expensive debts. She plans to invest the 2,000 CPO she's requesting to borrow to buy a variety of natural fruits to make juices, as well as to purchase staples such as flour and oil to fry foods, and to buy paper goods, clothing and cosmetics for her merchandise business. Edilsa dreams of having a printing business with her son, his girlfriend and a cousin. This dream is also her biggest challenge because in addition to two computers and a display case that she has, it will require her to purchase another computer, a photocopier and a laminator.

Translated from Spanish by Jo Longnecker, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy natural fruits to make juices, basics for frying (flour and oil)  and to purchase business supplies such as paper, clothing and cosmetics.

loans.name: Pascaline

texts.fr: A. Pascaline est née en 1963 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à ADJANIAN Hubert, Pascaline est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. La famille vit au quartier Aïbatin à Cotonou, depuis sept ans. Le couple supporte ensemble les différentes charges familiales. Pascaline n'a pas été à l'école. Pour faire face à ses besoins quotidiens, Pascaline vend divers céréales (haricot, riz, maïs, mil, etc.) depuis une dizaine d'année. Pascaline s'approvisionne à Sèto et à Allada, dans le département de l'Atlantique. Pascaline a déjà obtenu deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qu'elle a bien remboursés et qui lui ont permis de rehausser son activité. Aujourd'hui encore, Pascaline sollicite auprès de ALIDé un troisième prêt en vue d'augmenter davantage son stock de produits et de mieux satisfaire la forte demande de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
A. Pascaline was born in 1963 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  Married to ADJANIAN Hubert, she is the mother of three children, who have all attended school.  The family has been living in the Aïbatin district in Cotonou for seven years.  The couple jointly cover their various family expenses.  Pascaline did not attend school.  To address her everyday needs, she has been selling a variety of grains (beans, rice, corn, millet, etc.) for about ten years.  She gets her supplies in Sèto and in Allada, in Atlantique County.  She has already had two loans with ALIDé that she repaid and that allowed her to enhance her business.  Today, she is requesting a third loan from ALIDé with the aim of increasing again her stock of goods and satisfying further the strong customer demand.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying sacks of rice, corn, beans, etc.

loans.name: Patricia

texts.es:
Patricia S. P. vive en el barrio Los Almendros del municipio de Soledad, al sur de Barranquilla donde tiene una tienda llamada “Donde Patty” allí vende ranchos, víveres, carnes, refrescos, dulces y otros tipos de miscelánea en general. Es casada y tiene  4 hijos en edades de 8 a 26 años. Aunque este es su primer crédito con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, conoce ya lo significativo y lo útil del crédito para invertirlo en su negocio: su esposo siempre ha tenido vida crediticia y la ha cuidado muy bien, ahora  ella y quiere empezar a construir la suya, con este crédito por valor de $2.300.000 comprará dos mesas con sillas y surtirá su negocio con bebidas y víveres, como arroz y azúcar en mayor volumen.
Patricia proviene de Piedecuesta, municipio del departamento de Santander en el interior del país, una tierra panelera (que produce la panela) donde ella dice, se encuentra gente muy trabajadora y trapichera que “le ponemos el hombro al sol”. Toda la vida trabajó en restaurantes como empleada, hasta que su esposo le propusiera dejar de hacer esta actividad y prestaron un dinero para montar una tienda en Piedecuesta, donde también su esposo trabajaba como técnico de mantenimiento de redes de telefonía y de Internet,  pero  como no le iba muy bien, porque sólo conseguía contratos esporádicamente;  en el año 2001, una empresa importante donde lo contrataron, le propuso venirse a Barranquilla; fue asi vendieron su tienda en Santander y adquirieron la casa en Soledad, donde está  ubicada su nueva tienda. Su desafío más importante es el de hacer unas adecuaciones al negocio para ampliarlo y poder ofrecer servicios a familias mientras consumen en su tienda. Superar este desafío la ayudará a cumplir su sueño de terminar de pagar su casa con sus propios esfuerzos, para vivir estable y contar siempre con buenas condiciones de salud.
texts.en:
Patricia S. P. lives in the Los Almendros neighborhood in the town of Soledad, which is located south of Barranquilla. She has a store called “Donde Patty” where she sells foods, meats, soft drinks, sweets, and other miscellaneous general goods. She is married and has 4 children who range in age from 8 to 26. Even though this is Patricia’s first loan from the Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, she already knows that it is both important and useful to invest the loan in her business; Patricia's husband has a very good credit history, and she now wants to start building her own credit history. She is going to use this loan of 2,300,000 Colombian pesos to purchase two tables and chairs, and to stock her business with beverages and foods such as rice and sugar in large quantities. Patricia comes from Piedecuesta, a town in the department of Santander in the country’s interior. This is panela country (an area that produces panela, which is basically a loaf of unrefined sugar), where, as Patricia says, you can meet people who are very hardworking and innovative who “put our shoulders toward the sun.” Patricia worked in restaurants until her husband proposed to her—she then left her job and the two of them borrowed some money so that they could set up a store in Piedecuesta. Her husband also worked as a telephone network and Internet maintenance technician, though that was not going so well since he only occasionally got contracts. In 2001 an important company hired Patricia’s husband, and he suggested that they move to Barranquilla; they thus sold their store in Santander and purchased a house in Soledad, which is where their new store is located. Patricia’s most important challenge is making some adjustments to her business so that she can expand it and be able to offer services to families who shop at her store. Overcoming this challenge will allow her to fulfill her dream of paying for her house through her own hard work, which will in turn help her to live a stable life and have good health.

Translated from Spanish by Christopher Knutson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing two tables and chairs, and stocking her business with beverages and foods such as rice and sugar.

loans.name: Maria Del Pilar

texts.es: María del Pilar tiene 30 años es madre soltera tiene un hijo de tres años,  vive en casa de de sus padres labora hace 2 años en el fundo Piga S.a.c  la cual realizan trabajos de exportación de espárragos, ella se dedica a cultivar el campo en todo lo que es esparrago y alcachofas, en sus tiempos libres se dedica a cuidar a su menor hijo que queda al cuidado de su madre ella quiere construir su vivienda ya que sus padres le otorgaron una parte de la vivienda y quiere tener su propio cuarto para vivir con su niño y tenga su propio espacio, sus padres son de recursos muy bajos pero con mucho deseos de superación quieren que sus hijas tengan su vivienda propia, Solicita el crédito para la compra de materiales de construcción.
texts.en:
María del Pilar is a thirty-year-old single mother of a three-year-old son. She lives in her parents' home and has worked for a large farm ,Piga S a c, that exports asparagus, for two years. She cultivates land for asparagus and artichokes. When she has free time, she takes care of her young child whom her mother takes care of when she is working. Her parents have given her part of their house and she would like to build her own room to live in with her son so they will have their own space. Her parent's have limited resources but want to better themselves and want their daughters to have their own homes. She is requesting a loan to purchase building materials.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy construction materials

loans.name: Amistad 1 & 2 Group

texts.en:
Santa, 40, lives in Samana, Dominican Republic. She is the coordinator for her loan group, Amistad (Friendship), and her story is representative of those in her group and other Dominican and Haitian borrowers at Esperanza International.

Santa is a single mother who lives with her children in a simple home in Samana, a mountainous rural peninsula in the northeast of the Dominican Republic. Life in rural areas of the Dominican Republic can be rough, with no potable running water, frequent power outages (if one has power to begin with), and inadequate access to healthcare, among other dangers. Despite these difficulties, Santa runs a successful business making housing crafts, embroidery, and home decorations. With this loan, she plans on purchasing a sewing machine, fabric, and other sewing supplies for her business.

This is Santa’s seventh loan with Esperanza International. With her access to capital, she hopes to continue the growth of her business. Santa has used her profits from her sewing business to help pay for food and medicine that would otherwise be too expensive. Santa also has been able to use profits to pay for school supplies, including backpacks, notebooks, and shoes for her children. With her continued income, she hopes to one day purchase a computer for her family and build her own home — two very important symbols in the climb out of poverty. Santa looks forward to taking out larger loans with Esperanza, and is content in knowing that, with her work stability, her children will receive a great education so that they can become professionals in whatever they choose.

Esperanza International seeks to free children and their families from poverty through initiatives that generate income, education and health, restoring self-worth and dignity to those who have lost hope. We have over 8,500 active associates in eleven offices in the Dominican Republic and Haiti. Thank you for lending to Santa and the Amistad group!

loans.use: A sewing machine, fabric, and thread

loans.name: Porvenir Feminino 1 & 2 Group

texts.en:
Flavia, 50, lives in Samana, Dominican Republic. She is the coordinator for her group, Porvenir Femenino (Future Women), and her story is representative of those in her group and of other Dominican and Haitian borrowers at Esperanza International.

Flavia and her husband live with their four children in a simple home in Samana, a mountainous rural peninsula in the northeast of the Dominican Republic. Life in rural areas of the Dominican Republic can be rough, with no potable running water, frequent power outages (if one has power to begin with), and inadequate access to healthcare, among other dangers. Despite these difficulties, Flavia runs a successful business selling coconuts. Coconuts are a popular snack in the Dominican Republic, and can be sold for their milk, meat, and oil. With this loan, Flavia will purchase more coconuts to sell at a small markup to her customers.

This is Flavia’s eighth loan with Esperanza International. With her access to capital, she hopes to continue the growth of her business. Flavia’s profits have helped her purchase food for her family and school supplies for her children as well as supported her efforts to study English. She hopes to one day purchase a computer and build her own home, two very important moves out of the cycle of poverty. 

Esperanza International seeks to free children and their families from poverty through initiatives that generate income, education and health, restoring self-worth and dignity to those who have lost hope. We have over 8,500 active associates in eleven offices in the Dominican Republic and Haiti. Thank you for lending to Flavia and the Porvenir Femenino group!

loans.use: Coconut for resale

loans.name: Julian

texts.es: El señor Ramírez Ramírez tiene 2 años de trabajar con esta institución financiera, actualmente habita en la comarca Salales, caserío Los bordos, El Sauce, se dedica a la actividad agropecuaria contando con su propia finca, asimismo su ganado y tierras dedicadas a  la agricultura específicamente la cosecha de frijoles. Es necesario mencionar que tiene 25 años de experiencia de trabajar en las actividades agropecuarias con la intensión de generar ingresos para la familia y por ende para su sobrevivencia.
texts.en:
Julián Ramírez lives in the Los Bordos area of El Sauce in the Salales region and has worked with CEPRODEL for two years. He is a farmer who owns his own farm, including cattle and fields where he grows beans. It should be mentioned that he has worked as a farmer for 25 years in order to earn an income to ensure his family's survival. He will use this loan to purchase one cow.

Translated from Spanish by Kris Vickery, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of one heifer

loans.name: Genesis 4 Group

texts.en:
Maria is the coordinator of her group, Genesis, and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients in general. Her group is located in El-Seibo, a rural area where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her long-term partner and their three children.

Maria is excited to be seeking her seventh loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and expanded her business in doing so. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business. Specifically, she sells both agricultural and beauty products in her small town, including hair straighteners, creams, deodorants, and hair extensions, as well as charcoal and fertilizer. She will use the profits generated as a result of this loan to improve her home and her family's standard of living. For instance, she would like to add a concrete floor to their home and to purchase shoes for her children and a laundry machine to lighten her domestic burden. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing additional products (e.g., straighteners, creams, deodorants, hair extensions, charcoal, and fertilizer)

loans.name: Soledad Llelma

texts.es: La señora Soledad R. tiene 5 años de trabajar con esta institución financiera, actualmente habita en la comarca Sabana Grande, El Sauce, se dedica a la actividad agropecuaria contando con su propia unidad productiva dedicada a la explotación agropecuaria. Es necesario mencionar que tiene 32 años de experiencia de trabajar en las actividades agropecuarias.
texts.en:
Señora Soledad R. has worked with this financial institution for five years. She currently lives in the Sabana Grande region of El Sauce. She practices farming/cattle rearing and has her own plot of land where she farms productively. Señora Soledad R. has 32 years' experience working with cattle.

Translated from Spanish by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 6 steers

loans.name: Emprendedoras 3 & 4 Group

texts.en:
Ana, 37, is a borrower who lives in L. Alcarrizos, Dominican Republic. She is the coordinator for her group, Emprendedoras (Entrepreneurs), and her story is representative of those in her group and other Dominican and Haitian borrowers at Esperanza International.

Ana and her husband live with their three children in a simple home in L. Alcarrizos, a crowded suburb of S. Domingo, the capital city of the Dominican Republic. Life in urban areas of the Dominican Republic is overcrowded and can be rough, with no potable running water, frequent power outages (if one has power to begin with), and inadequate access to healthcare, among other dangers. Despite these difficulties, Ana runs a successful business selling milk products, specifically yogurt, which is a favorite cold snack in the Dominican Republic. With this loan, she will purchase milk and sugar to make her yogurt.

This is Ana’s very first loan with Esperanza International. With access to capital, she hopes to continue to grow her business. Ana’s dream is to someday finish her home with the profits from her yogurt business. A common construction method in the Dominican Republic is to build in sections as money becomes available, and she looks forward to additional income so that the building process is faster. Ana explains that she dreams not just to have a house, but also to have a true home in every sense where her children can grow up and live securely.

Esperanza International seeks to free children and their families from poverty through initiatives that generate income, education, and health, thereby restoring self-worth and dignity to those who have lost hope. Esperanza International have over 8,500 active associates in eleven offices in the Dominican Republic and Haiti. Thank you for lending to Ana and the Emprendedoras group!

loans.use: To further expand her business by purchasing milk and sugar in order to produce additional yogurt

loans.name: Luis

texts.es: El señor A. V. tiene 3 años de trabajar con esta institución financiera con la responsabilidad de deudor, en esta ocasión se le otorgo un crédito para la compra de terneros de desarrollo. Actualmente habita en la comarca Cofradía, Santa Rosa del Peñón, se dedica a la actividad agropecuaria contando con su propia finca y asimismo su ganado. Es necesario mencionar que tiene 52 años de experiencia de trabajar en las actividades agropecuarias.
texts.en:
Mr. A. V. has been involved with this finance institution for three years as a loaner. This time he is receving a loan to purchase calves to raise. He lives in Santa Rosa del Peñón, in the province of Cofradia, he is a farmer and a cattleman, with his own farm and own cattle, with 52 years of experience in this activities.

Translated from Spanish by MONICA URBAN, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of calves to raise

loans.name: La Buena Union Group

texts.en:
Evangelista is the coordinator of her group, La Buena Union (The Good Union), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients in general. Her group is located in El Seibo, a rural area with an economy based around agriculture, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her husband and five children.

Evangelista is excited to be seeking her eigth loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and expanded her business in doing so. She plans to use this loan to invest in her bread-baking business. Specifically, she would like to purchase flour, butter, and eggs. She will use the profits generated as a result of this loan to improve her family's standard of living by purchasing school supplies for her children as well construction materials to improve her home. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To improve her bread-baking business by purchasing flour, butter, eggs

loans.name: Maximina

texts.es:
En el municipio El Sauce en León, la señora Maximina Z. se dedica a su actividad agropecuaria dando lugar a la crianza de ganado y actividades agricolas que ella misma lleva que es el fruto de sus manos.

Es necesario destacar que ella tiene 26 largos años de dedicarse a esta actividad y se ha convertido en una profesional trabajadora porque ha logrado llevar el sustento a su familia que habita en el municipio. El crédito será invertido para suplir sus necesidades y de esta manera continuar mejorando las condiciones agropecuarias para beneficio propio y de su familia que tanto ama.
texts.en:
Z. A. has been working with CEPRODEL for three years as a co-debtor. On this occasion, she got a loan assuming the debt of Mr. Aler José Ramos. Z. lives in El Chote, in the El Sauce municipality. She works in agriculture and has her own farm and cattle. It is necessary to mention that she has 26 years of experience in this field.

Translated from Spanish by jeffrey hersk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Inversión en la actividad agropecuaria

loans.name: Amos

texts.en: Amos is a 42-year-old married man with five children. His children attend school and this gives him joy as a father. He has a bar where he sells drinks at retail prices. He has been in this business for a long time. Amos, a hard-working man, is seeking a loan of N50,000 to purchase more drinks to sell.  He  thanks all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Oyeleke

texts.en:
Oyeleke is a hard-working woman who is determined to pull her business and family out of poverty. She lives in Ogbomoso, Oyo state, Nigeria. She is 39 years old, and married, with 2 children.  

She sells groceries such as milk, sugar,  and toothpaste and has been in this business for a long time.  Oyeleke loves the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers, and she hopes to own a supermarket in the future. She is a client of LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization).  LAPO is  committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. Oyeleke is requesting a loan of N120,000 to purchase more groceries to sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Los Girasoles 1 & 2 Group

texts.en:
Dulce, 45, is a borrower who lives in Los Alcarrizos, Dominican Republic. She is the coordinator for her group, Los Girasoles (Sunflowers), and her story is representative of those in her group and other Dominican and Haitian borrowers at Esperanza International.

Dulce and her husband live with their children in a simple home in Los Alcarrizos, a crowded suburb of Santo Domingo, the capital city of the Dominican Republic. Life in urban areas of the Dominican Republic is overcrowded and can be rough, with no potable running water, frequent power outages (if one has power to begin with), and inadequate access to health care, among other dangers. Despite these difficulties, Dulce runs a successful business selling produce, chicken, and eggs to her community. With this loan, she will purchase “viveres” (starchy foods such as plantains, yucca, pumpkin and sweet potatoes) fruit, chicken, and eggs to sell at a small markup.

This is Dulce’s first loan with Esperanza International. With her new access to capital, she hopes to continue the growth of her business. Dulce is also excited to be able to save for the first time, giving her access to more financial security during tough times. She takes comfort in knowing that with loans, her business will grow and her profits will increase, giving her family more security, and allowing her children to receive a better education.

Esperanza International seeks to free children and their families from poverty through initiatives that generate income, education and health, restoring self-worth and dignity to those who have lost hope. We have more than 8,500 active associates in eleven offices in the Dominican Republic and Haiti. Thank you for lending to Dulce and Los Girasoles group!

loans.use: To buy fruit, vegetables, chicken, and eggs for resale

loans.name: Runda

texts.en:
Runda L. is a 47-year-old farmer married to Sintagoi Runda. They have four children. He has been in the business of selling livestock for four years. He also grows maize on his farm making approximately 45,000 Kenya Shillings a month.

He was introduced to KADET by an existing client. He has never borrowed from another MFI and wants to use his loan to buy more cows, sheep and goats to sell.

loans.use: To buy cows, sheep and goats to sell

loans.name: Creciendo Juntos 4 Group

texts.en:
Margarita is the coordinator of her group Creciendo Juntos (growing together).  Her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients generally. Margarita's group is located in El Seibo, a rural, agricultural area, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure as a single mother with her child.

Margarita is excited to be taking her fifth loan from Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business of selling clothing.  She intends to travel to the capital to purchase a dozen skirts, pants, blouses and underwear in the main market and then selling them in her community at a profit. She will use the profits to invest in her home by purchasing a stove and school supplies for her child. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To buy clothing to resell

loans.name: Kipas

texts.en:
Kipas is a 36-year-old farmer who is married with three children. He grows maize on his farm and also keeps livestock for resale. He has been selling livestock for a period of two years now. He makes a profit of approximately 40,000 KES per month.
Kipas was introduced to Kiva partner, KADET, by an existing client. He has not borrowed from another microfinance institution (MFI) before. He wants to use his loan to buy more cows, sheep and goats for resale. In the future, he hopes to buy a motorbike in order to supply meat with ease to nearby butcheries.

loans.use: To buy more cows, sheep and goats for fattening and resale

loans.name: Carmen Alicia

texts.es:
Carmen Alicia  L. Bolaño, vive en la ciudadela Metropolitana  de Soledad, barrio en el cual la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo apoyó la construcción de esta comunidad desde procesos de vivienda. Ella es una mujer de gran fortaleza tiene 2 hijos de 22 y 26 años, que estudian  en el SENA carreras técnicas.
Tiene un  taller  de nombre “El Ciclista”, donde presta servicios de mantenimiento y reparación de bicicletas y motocicletas. Con este primer crédito a través de la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo por valor de $2.000.000  comprará de repuestos como llantas, neumáticos, guayas, aceites, pasadores, radios y pastillas para frenos. "Taller El Ciclista" es un negocio familiar heredado de su padre, que para Carmen Alicia representa ademas de sus ingresos familiares, un valor sentimental importante, por eso lo atiende personalmente y tiene un empleado que se encarga de hacer los diferentes trabajos en el taller, donde presta los servicios de mantenimiento reparación y pintura al horno de bicicletas y motos desde hace 5 años.

Su meta principal es sacar adelante a sus hijos mediante el trabajo duro y parejo en su negocio y sueña con que ellos se empleen en una gran empresa. Su  mayor desafio es la innovación de estos vehiculos que frecuentemente salen al mercado, por eso ella debe estar a la altura de la tecnología y muy bien informada al igual que su empleado.
texts.en:
Carmen Alicia L. Bolaño lives metropolitan area of Soledad, a neighborhood whose construction the Mario Santo Domingo Foundation supported. She is a very strong woman, has two sons of 22 and 26 years of age that are working on technical degrees at the SENA. She has a shop called "The Cyclist", where she maintains and repairs bicycles and motorcycles. With this first loan through the Mario Santo Domingo Foundation of $2,000,000(pesos) she will buy replacements parts such as tires, pumps, cables, oil, filters, radios and brake pads. The shop "The Cyclist" is a well known business inherited from her father, that to Carmen Alicia, other than her family income, has also a very sentimental value. Because of this she is personally involved in the business and has an employee that for the last 5 years is in charge of performing the various services at the shop, maintenance, repair and baked on painting of bicycles and motorcycles. Her main goal is to get her children ahead through her hard and consistent work at her business. She dreams of them working for a large company. Her major challenge is the constant innovation in the vehicles that come into the market. She and her employee need to be well informed and current with the new technology.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of replacements parts such as tires, pumps, cables, oil, filters, radios and brake pads.

loans.name: Ramona

texts.en:
Ramona is an individual loan client, and her story is representative of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients generally. She lives in a rural, agricultural area near El Seibo where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her long-term partner and their three children.

Ramona is excited to be taking her third loan from Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business running a "colmado" or small general store by purchasing rice, sugar, coffee, sauces, fish and pasta to stock the store. She will use the profits to invest in her home and to save to replace the roof. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To buy merchandise for her store

loans.name: Union Y Amor 3 Group

texts.en:
Yolanda, 42, is a borrower who lives in El Seybo, Dominican Republic. She is the coordinator for her group, Union y Amor (Union and Love), and her story is representative of those in her group and other Dominican and Haitian borrowers at Esperanza International.

Yolanda and her husband live with their two children in a simple home in El Seybo, a rural town in the agricultural east of the Dominican Republic. Life in rural areas of the Dominican Republic can be rough, with no potable running water, frequent power outages (if one has power to begin with), and inadequate access to healthcare, among other dangers. Despite these difficulties, Yolanda runs a successful business selling gas and motor oil to her community. Since there are no gas stations in the countryside, she can charge a small markup and make a healthy profit.

This is Yolanda’s ninth loan with Esperanza International. With her access to capital, she hopes to continue improving her business. This loan is five times as large as Yolanda’s first loan, a true testament to her hard work and the growth of her business. With profits, Yolanda is hoping to soon add a bathroom to her home. Construction in the Dominican Republic is done in stages as money becomes available. Having a bathroom will add more comfort and provide better sanitation for Yolanda’s family.

Esperanza International seeks to free children and their families from poverty through initiatives that generate income, education and health, restoring self-worth and dignity to those who have lost hope. We have over 8,500 active associates in eleven offices in the Dominican Republic and Haiti. Thank you for lending to Yolanda and the Union y Amor group!

loans.use: Gasoline and motor oil for resale

loans.name: Lekumok

texts.en:
Lekumok N. is a 37-year-old farmer who is married with three children. He grows maize on his farm and also keeps livestock for sale. He has been selling livestock for a period of three years now. He makes a profit of approximately 45,000 KES per month.
Lekumok was introduced to Kiva partner, KADET, by an existing client. He has never borrowed from another microfinance institution (MFI). He wants to use his loan to buy more cows, sheep and goats for resale. In the future, he hopes to buy a hybrid cow in order to increase milk supply to his customers.

loans.use: To purchase more cows, goats and sheep

loans.name: Jacobo

texts.en:
Jacobo is an individual loan client with Esperanza, and his story is representative of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients generally (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti). He is located in El-Seibo where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. He makes his home here in a simple, rented structure with his wife and two children.

Jacobo is excited to be taking his second loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid his previous loan and grown her business. He plans to use this loan to invest in his business running a "colmado" or small general store by purchasing rice, cooking oil, sugar and flour. He will use the profits to invest in his home by adding a concrete floor. He thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: Rice, oil, sugar, flour, coffee, among others (arroz, aceite, azúcar, harina, café, entre otros)

loans.name: Louis

texts.fr: Monsieur Louis M. est  un commerçant  de 40 ans qui vit dans la localité de Baye Laye à Guediawaye. Il est sociétaire de la caisse depuis juillet 2009 ou il a déjà bénéficié  d’un prêt antérieur. C’est un homme marie, père de 2 enfants âgés respectivement  de 9 et 18 ans et ayant aussi en charge 2 autres personnes qui vivent sous son toit. Monsieur M. a une double activité. Il gère depuis presque 20 ans une boutique qui est localisée dans son domicile (Louis M.  représente  celui qui est vêtu  en Lacoste noir sur la photo). Il est assiste par un de ses petits frères ( c’est la deuxième personne sur la photo)  car  Louis  doit aussi  superviser la salle de jeux dont il est propriétaire. Il a démarrai  ses activités  a travers les voyages qu’il faisait pour visiter sa famille en Guinée  Bissau en achetant des chaussures pour les revendre. Ensuite il a acheté  un réfrigérateur pour vendre de la  crème  glace.  C’est a partir de ses recettes qu’il a pu mobiliser un fond pour ouvrir une boutique. Actuellement il sollicite un crédit de 500 000 frs pour renforcer les  marchandises  de cette dernière.  Ses bénéfices  lui permettent de gérer  sa famille et parallèlement  de renforcer son épargne.
texts.en:
Mr. Louis M. is a 40-year-old merchant who lives in the Baye Laye area of Guediawaye. He has been a member of the local branch of U-IMCEC since July 2009, and has already been granted one previous loan. He is married, father of two children aged 9 and 18 years, and also cares for two other persons living under the same roof. Mr. M. has a dual activity. He has managed a home-based store for over 20 years (Louis M. is the person wearing a black Lacoste polo in the picture). He is assisted by his younger brother (the second person in the picture) as Louis must also supervise a game room of which he is owner. He started his commercial activities (while travelling to visit his family in Guinea Bissau) by acquiring shoes for resale. He then bought a refrigerator to sell ice cream. His earnings enabled him to gather enough funds to open a shop. He is currently requesting a loan for 500,000 FCFA to reinforce his stock of merchandise. His profits will enable him to manage his family needs and also build up his savings.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: boost working capital

loans.name: Alice

texts.fr: Née en 1983 à Comé au Bénin, K. Alice est mariée à DJEGBEVI Florent, et est mère de deux enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. La famille vit depuis dix ans environs au quartier Aïbatin à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Le couple supporte ensemble les différentes charges de la famille. Alice a très peu fréquenté. Depuis près de onze ans, Alice mène comme activité la vente de nourriture (riz et pâte de maïs, accompagnés de sauce) à Aïbatin. Parallèlement, Alice a une cabine téléphonique, où elle vend diverses cartes de recharges téléphoniques. Alice s’approvisionne à Cotonou. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà obtenu deux prêts qui ont été tous bien remboursés. Alice désire renforcer son activité et mieux faire face aux exigences de sa clientèle ; raison pour laquelle Alice sollicite un troisième prêt.
texts.en:
Born in 1983 in Comé (Benin), Alice K. is married to Florent DJEGBEVI, and is the mother of two children, both attending school. The family has lived for ten years in the Aïbatin borough of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. The couple jointly shares family expenses. Alice has had very little schooling. For the past 11 years, she has been selling food preparations (rice and corn mush, with accompanying sauce) in Aïbatin. As a second activity, she operates a telephone booth, where she sells various telephone recharge cards. She gets her supplies from Cotonou. She is a regular client of ALIDé, and has already been granted two loans, both of which were fully repaid. She wishes to reinforce her activity and better manage customers’ expectations, which is why she is requesting a third loan.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy bags of rice and corn, and sauce condiments

loans.name: Mariatu's Group

texts.en:
These are teachers of a primary school in Lunsar, a small town in northern Sierra Leone. This school was opened in 1935 by the Catholics. Presently, this school is staffed with eighteen  teachers and has 549 pupils. 

This is the first loan this school is accessing from SMT/Kiva lenders.  School staff from this institution, like many other schools' staff within SMT’s operational areas, come to SMT to apply for loans. With the help of these loans, they can accomplish certain tasks that they would not have been able to accomplish with their salaries alone. But with the help of this loan, some can pay school fees for their children; others can use the loan to buy pieces of furniture, a plot of land, house-building materials, or to invest in business. At the end of each month, these teachers can repay the loan out of their monthly salaries. The institution’s bursar is directly responsible for deducting the repayment and pays SMT on their behalf.

Mariatu K. is the leader of this group of teachers. She has been a teacher for twenty years now. The 42-year-old Mariatu was born in Lunsar, a small town in northern Sierra Leone. She is a widow with three children who are attending school -- one in university, one in secondary school, and the other in primary school. Mariatu is seeking a loan of SLL 1,500,000 in order to buy house-building materials like cement and corrugated zinc.

loans.use: Buy house-building materials like cement and corrugated zinc

loans.name: Chelsea Group

texts.en:
This is a group of small-scale businesspeople in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They named their group 'Chelsea' (named after their favorite English football team). They have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva in Sierra Leone, to seek a loan of SLL 800,000 in order to expand their businesses. 

The leader of the group is Gibo Akim K.. Gibo who was born in Makeni is a 33-year-old. He is married and has two children – one in secondary school and the other is not of school-going age. Gibo has been selling soft drinks for countless years now. With the help of this loan, he will buy more crates of soft drinks to sell.

loans.use: Buy crates of soft drinks to sell

loans.name: Fight For Poor Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are petty businesswomen from Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They named their group “Fight For Poor Group”. They have applied for a loan of SLL 500,000 for each person in the group from Kiva lenders through SMT. With the help of this loan, they can add more goods to their businesses, attract many more customers, make more sales and better profit, and consequently improve their living conditions. 

Hawa K. is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Hawa is a 45-year-old. She is married and has four children. One of her children is in secondary school and the others are married and living on their own. For five years now, Hawa has been selling foofoo (food made out of cassava roots), biscuits, mints, etc. Hawa will use her share of the loan to buy foofoo, biscuits, mints, etc. wholesale.

loans.use: Buy foofoo, biscuits, mints, etc. wholesale

loans.name: Fairness Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the 'Fairness' group from Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. This group of small-scale entrepreneurs has applied for a loan of SLL 2,400,000 from Kiva lenders through Salone Micro Finance Trust. With the help of this loan, they can further develop their businesses, attract many more customers, make more profit, and consequently improve their standard of living.

Rugiatu K., who is a 45-year-old woman, is the leader of this group. She was born in Makeni, is married to a businessman, and they have four children. Two of her children are attending secondary school and two are attending primary school. For quite a number of years now, Rugiatu has been selling dishes, bowls, rice, and palm oil (the most popular cooking oil). With her share of the loan, she will buy the above items wholesale to add to her business inventory.

loans.use: Buy rice and palm oil wholesale

loans.name: Sonia Marina

texts.es: Doña Sonia de 38 años de edad, se dedica a la venta de tortillas desde hace varios años ha sido su fuente de trabajo, el cual inicio motivada para poder apoyar a sus cuatro hijos con la educación y lo necesario para su crecimiento, su esposo trabaja como mensajero. Para ella abecés se le hace cansado ya que desde horas tempranas se levanta a moler el maíz, y luego a palmear para vender las tortillas de la mañana para el desayuno y para entregar  a los comedores. Lo que desea comprar  es una cocina económica para no agitarse mucho. Con este préstamo desea comprar varios quintales de maíz, ya que abecés se pone escaso oh más caro, comprar leña, cal, panas para cargar el maíz para seguir aumentando las ventas y poder cubrir sus gastos. Sus planes a futuro es  poder embaldosar la cocina, ya que a un es de tierra, para lograr mejor higiene, repellar parte de la casa que le falta lo cual espera hacerlo en corto plazo.
texts.en:
Sonia, age 38, has been selling tortillas for several years. It has been her source of work. She was motivated to start in order to be able to support her four children with an education and what they needed to grow. Her husband works as a messenger. Sometimes she gets tired because she gets up early to grind the corn and then pat the tortillas into shape. She sells the tortillas in the morning for breakfast, and she delivers them to restaurants. What she wishes to buy is a large stove so she does not have to move around so much. She wishes to use this loan to buy various “quintales” (a quintal is 100 pounds) of corn because sometimes it is scarce or more expensive. She will buy wood, lime, and bowls to carry the corn in order to keep increasing her sales and be able to cover her expenses. Her plan for the future is to be able to tile the kitchen because it has a dirt floor. She wants to do this for better hygiene. She also wants to plaster the house where it needs it. She hopes to do this in the short term.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy several "quintales" (a quintal is 100 pounds) of corn, lime, and firewood to produce more in her business

loans.name: Ousmane

texts.fr: Monsieur Ousmane N.  est un banquier en retraite depuis 2006. Agé de 57 ans et père de 8 enfants, il sollicite un prêt de 150 000 FCFA pour  régler des frais d’assurance et de mutation d’une voiture qu’il vient  d’acheter.
texts.en:
Mr. Ousmane N. is a retired banker since 2006. He is 57 years old and the father of eight children. He is requesting a loan for 150,000 FCFA to cover the insurance and other acquisition fees for a car he has just bought.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Pay insurance and acquisition fees

loans.name: Agnes Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the 'Agnes' group from Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. These women are small-scale businesswomen who have applied for a loan of SLL 1,000,000 for each person in the group from SMT, a partner of Kiva in Sierra Leone. With the help of this loan, they will be able to improve their businesses both in terms of size and quality. 

Kaday K. is the leader of this group of two. Kaday is approximately 50 years old. She was born in Makeni, is married to a motor-mechanic, and they have six children – two in college and four in secondary school. Kaday has been selling market-food for quite a number of years now. With her share of this loan, she will further expand her business by buying packets of Maggi cubes (used to give sauce a sweet taste), bags of salt and rice, and gallons of palm oil (the most popular cooking oil).

loans.use: Buy packets of Maggi cubes, bags of salt and rice, and gallons of palm oil

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence R. is a 26-year-old businesswoman who is married with three children. She sells kangas and clothes to her customers in the Pangani area. She has been in this business for a period of about one year and makes a profit of about 3,000 KES per month.
Florence walked into the offices of Kiva partner, KADET, and enquired about loan services by herself. She has not borrowed from another microfinance institution (MFI) before. She hopes to expand her business and open a boutique in the city.

loans.use: To buy more kangas for sale

loans.name: Diana Elizet

texts.es:
Diana tiene 19 años de edad, es soltera y vive junto a sus padres en el sector el Romero del distrito de Mórrope, en la provincia de Lambayeque, ubicado a cuarenta minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Desde hace tres años se dedica a la confección y venta de tejidos artesanales. Ella empezó ayudando a su madre con el negocio y poco a poco se fue haciendo conocida. Usualmente confecciona paños y alforjas durante la semana y los fines de semana va al mercado de la ciudad de Mórrope a ofrecer su producto. Eventualmente también ofrece estos tejidos a diversos clientes que le hacen pedidos con anticipación. Los ingresos que percibe de esta actividad los utiliza para solventar sus gastos personales y ayudar a los gastos familiares.

La elaboración de estos tejidos es muy minuciosa y exige de mucha dedicación, sus productos tienen mucha acogida por la calidad con la que los realiza. Diana desea ampliar su negocio con la compra de más material para seguir confeccionando tejidos, por ello se encuentra solicitando por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 700 nuevos soles que le ayuden a lograr su objetivo.

Diana es una joven que gusta mucho de la labor que realiza. Su mayor anhelo es seguir creciendo como empresaria y hacerse mas conocida en el rubro. Sus vecinos y conocidos la estiman mucho y la consideran una persona de confianza.En la imagen aparece junto a su madre mostrando los productos que suelen elaborar.
texts.en:
Diana is 19 years old and single. She lives with her parents in the Romero area of the Mórrope district in the province of Lambayeque. It is forty minutes from the city of Chiclayo. She has worked making and selling handcrafted cloth for three years. She began helping her mother with the business and little by little she started to become known. She usually makes traditional cloths and bags during the week and goes to the market in the city of Mórrope on the weekends to offer her product. She eventually also offers these cloths to different customers who place orders in advance. She uses the income she receives from this work to cover her personal expenses and to help with family expenses. Making these cloths is very detailed work and demands a lot of dedication. Her products are well received for the quality she makes them with. Diana wishes to expand her business by purchasing more material to continue making cloth. That is why she finds herself applying to Edpyme Alternativa for the first time for a loan of 700 PEN which will help her reach her objective. Diana is a young woman who likes the work she does very much. Her biggest desire is to continue to grow as a business woman and become more well known in the trade. Her neighbors and acquaintances have a high regard for her and consider her a trustworthy person. She appears in the picture next to her mother showing the products they usually make.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Haynes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase materials to make traditional cloths and bags.

loans.name: Coumba

texts.fr: Madame  Coumba G. est une demoiselle  de 33ans qui habite dans la localité de baye Laye. Elle est sociétaire  de la caisse depuis décembre  2009. Elle est célibataire  sans enfant et a choisi l’option du  commerce de poissons séchés  et de fruits de mer pour pouvoir gérer  sa propre survie.  Elle a une expérience  de 2 ans dans cette activité. Auparavant elle était vendeuse dans une pharmacie. A cause  du caractère dérisoire du salaire  qu’elle  percevait  dans la pharmacie elle a été appuyée  par sa mère qui s’active dans ce secteur. Selon elle c’est un domaine rentable car elle y trouve son compte. Elle sollicite un crédit de 500 000 frs  destine  a l’achat de produits qu’elle commercialise. Ce crédit lui permettra de gagner son autonomie par la satisfaction de ses besoins personnels et de consolider son épargne  pour des projets futurs dans le secteur du commerce.
texts.en:
Ms. Coumba G. is a young lady, 33 years old, who lives in the town Baye Laye.  She has been a member of the credit association since December 2009.  She is unmarried and has no children.  She has chosen commerce in dried fish and seafood as an option to be able to manager her own life.  She has two years of experience in this business.  In the past, Coumba was a salesperson in a pharmacy.  Due to the paltry nature of her salary she was receiving at the pharmacy, she was supported by her mother, who is active in the this sector of business.  She says it's a profitable one, since she is able to be independent in it.  Coumba is requesting a loan of 500,000 francs for buying products, which she markets.  This loan will allow her to earn her autonomy by meeting her personal needs and by boosting her savings for future projects in the commercial sector. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Bolstering her working capital

loans.name: Cesar

texts.es:
Cesar tiene 32 años de edad, es casado y tiene dos hijos, vive junto a su familia en el caserío Cruz de Medano del distrito de Morrope, en la provincia de Lambayeque, ubicado a 45 minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Usualmente trabajaba como obrero agrícola en los campos de cultivo de la zona, pero como esta actividad no le generaba ingresos estables decidió hace tres años insursionar en el negocio de crianza y venta de animales menores, el cría animales desde pequeños y semanalmente selecciona los mejores ejemplares para venderlos en el mercado Moshoqueque de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Por otro lado eventualmente trabaja vendiendo leña a sus vecinos. Estas fuentes de ingreso son las unicas con la que cuenta su familia por lo que Cesar da lo mejor de si para mantenerse en el negocio. El desea ampliar su negocio con la compra de mas animales menores para criarlos y venderlos, así como en la compra de sus respectivos alimentos, por este motivo se ha visto en la necesidad de solicitar a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1800 nuevos soles que le ayuden a lograr su objetivo.

Cesar es un padre responsable y bastante entragado a su familia, todos los esfuerzos e inciativas que toma tienen la finalidad de sacarlos adelante. El ya ha trabajado anteriormente con Nuestra Institución y ha demostrado ser un cliente puntual y responsable con sus pagos. En la imagen aparece junto a su esposa.
texts.en:
Cesar is 32 years old, married with two children, and he lives with his family in the neighborhood of Cruz de Medano in the Morrope district, in the Lambayeque province, 45 minutes from the city of Chiclayo. He used to work as a farm worker in the local farmlands, but since this didn’t generate stable income three years ago he decided to start a small animal business. He raises farm animals and selects the best specimens weekly to sell in the Moshoqueque market in the city of Chiclayo. He also sells firewood to his neighbors. These sources of income are the only ones his family counts on. This is why Cesar gives his best to keep the business going. He wishes to increase the size of his business by buying more animals to raise and sell, and by buying their respective feed. This is why he finds himself asking for a loan of 1800 soles to Edpyme Alternativa that will help him achieve his objectives. Cesar is a responsible father who completely gives himself to his family. All of the efforts and initiatives he takes have as a goal to help them succeed. He has previously worked with our institution and has shown that he is punctual and responsible with his payments. He appears next to his wife in the picture.

Translated from Spanish by Esteban Riojas, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy animals to raise and sell, and their respective balanced feed

loans.name: Macedonio

texts.es: El señor H. Gonzáles Macedonio identificado con DNI 21549807 domiciliado en  la tinguiña  provincia de ICA ,es casado tiene 1  hijo dependiente  ,se inicio en el rubro de alquiler de equipos de sonido y organizar eventos (bautizo , matrimonio ,etc) hace mas de 5 años aproximadamente hasta la actualidad  , siendo su perspectiva ampliar su negocio y expandirse  a otros distritos .
texts.en:
Mr. H. Gonzáles, Macedonio with ID 21549807 lives in the Tinguiña province of ICA. He is married and has one dependant child. He began renting sound systems and organizing events (baptism, wedding, etc) more than 5 years ago approximately until now. His outlook is to grow his business and expand to other districts.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Haynes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: BUSINESS INVESTMENT

loans.name: Karen Mirella

texts.es: La Sra. O. H.  Karen MIrella tiene 24 años de edad vive con sus padres a su corta edad es madre soltera, su niño tiene 3 años de edad, ella se dedica a la venta de ropa por su barrio, goza de buenas referencias. Tienes mucha ganas de supercaion de salir adelante con su hijo.
texts.en:
Ms. O. H. Karen Mirella is 24 years old and lives with her parents. At her young age she is a single mother, her son is 3 years old. She is dedicated to the sale of clothing throughout her neighborhood, and has good referrences. She wants to succeed and to get ahead in life with her son.

Translated from Spanish by Esteban Riojas, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invesment in her business

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is married with two children and both children go to school. She owns a three-room house where she stays with four people. The family has access to electricity and piped water. Rose takes care of additional family members. The family gets three meals a day. Her monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family. Rose sells second hand clothing in Bwaise market and works six days a week. She rents the shop where she operates.

Rose receives at least 10 customers a day and her customers are mainly women and children but on retail. Rose has been in this business for six years and her monthly challenges include thieves and seasonality. Rose has been with MCDT for a long time, servicing her forteenth loan.  She wants to use this loan to buy more second hand clothes. She hopes to see her business grow bigger and to start importing clothes

loans.use: To buy more second hand clothes

loans.name: Geneviève

texts.fr: M. Geneviève est née le 30 Septembre 1963 à Abomey dans le département du Zou. Mariée à LANLOKOUN Chitou, Geneviève est mère de quatre enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Geneviève vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari au quartier Aïbatin à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Il y a près de quinze ans que Geneviève vit dans ce quartier. Geneviève aide son mari à assurer les différentes charges familiales. Pour y parvenir, Geneviève vend des tissus et des jouets d’enfants à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C’est également à Dantokpa que Geneviève achète ses produits. Geneviève exerce cette activité depuis cinq ans et a déjà obtenu un crédit auprès de ALIDé, crédit qu’elle a bien remboursé. La clientèle de Geneviève s’accroît au jour le jour et elle n’arrive plus à tous les satisfaire. C’est donc pour rehausser le niveau de son activité et mieux répondre aux exigences de sa clientèle que Geneviève sollicite un deuxième prêt.
texts.en:
Geneviève M. was born September 30, 1963 in Abomey, in the department of Zou. Married to Chitou Lanlokoun, Geneviève is the mother of four, all of whom are in school. Geneviève lives with her children and her husband in the Aïbatin neighborhood of Cotonou, Benin's financial center. She has lived in that neighborhood for almost fifteen years. Geneviève helps her husband provide for the various family expenses. To do so, she sells fabrics and children's toys in Dantokpa, Benin's international marketplace. It's also in Dantokpa that Geneviève buys her goods. Geneviève has been in business for five years and has already received one loan from Alidé, a loan which she has fully repaid. Her customers increase every day and she is no longer able to accommodate them all. So it is to enhance her business and better fulfill the demands of her customers that Geneviève requests a second loan.

Translated from French by Jessalyn Pinneo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying fabric and toys.

loans.name: Rosa Amanda

texts.es: La señora Amanda vive en el barrio Villa Austria, de edad de 49 años, durante   su trayectoria de vida ha logrado formar una bonita familia de cuatro hijos de los cuales tres trabajan, y el menor estudia medicina, su esposo se fue de la casa, pero eso no ha sido motivo para seguir motivada ya que tiene el apoyo de sus hijos económicamente y moral, anteriormente trabajaba en tapicería, pero luego renuncio y comienza a comprar ropa nueva para dama, también se afilio en la Avon y vende una variedad de productos en crema, perfumenes, pinturas, vanidades, faciales para el cutis y otros. Vende al contado y al crédito de quincena. Su meta es poder comprar vitrina y poder exhibir sus productos como lograr captar clientes. Con esta inversión lograra comprar ropa ya que tiene poca y tiene unos encargos que comprar. A futuro desea mejorar la infraestructura de su casa ya que las divisiones aun no son de concreto para una mejor seguridad. Como madre desea seguir apoyando a sus hijos, y crecer en su negocio
texts.en:
Amanda lives in the suburb of Villa Austria. She is 49 years old and over the course of her life she has managed to raise a beautiful family of four children - three who work and the youngest who is studying medicine. Her husband left home, but this has not been the reason to keep motivated since she has the support of her children economically and morally. She used to work in upholstery, but then she resigned and started to buy new clothes for women. She is also an Avon representative and sells a variety of products such as creams, perfumes, makeup, beauty products, facials and other things. She sells for cash and two-week credit. Her goal is to be able to buy a display cabinet so that she can display her products and keep winning customers. With this investment she will buy clothes as she does not have many and she has some orders to buy. In the future she would like to improve the structure of her home for better security since the walls are not even made of concrete. As a mother she wants to keep supporting her children, and grow her business.

Translated from Spanish by Catherine Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy clothes and cosmetics

loans.name: Sylvia

texts.en: Sylvia is married with three children and all her children go to school. She owns a two-room house where she stays with six people. The family has access to electricity and piped water. Sylvia takes care of additional family members. She owns a retail shop in Makerere and sells to all categories of people at retail. She works six days a week.  Sylvia receives at least 20 customers a day. She has been in this business for four years. She has been with MCDT for many years, servicing her fifth loan.  Besides this retail shop business, she also owns rental houses. She wants to use this loan to buy bags of sugar, bags of beans, maize flour and rice. She hopes to see her business grow bigger and to sell at wholesale. She joined MCDT because it was near her home and it was giving loans to women in groups.

loans.use: To buy more bags of sugar,maize flour and bags of beans

loans.name: Fe Y Accion 3 Group

texts.en:
Ana, 37, is a borrower who lives in Hato Mayor, Dominican Republic. She is the coordinator for her group, Fe y Accion (Faith and Action), and her story is representative of those in her group and other Dominican and Haitian borrowers at Esperanza International.

Ana and her husband live in a simple home in Hato Mayor, a small rural town in the agricultural east of the Dominican Republic. Life in rural areas of the Dominican Republic can be rough, with no potable running water, frequent power outages (if one has power to begin with), and inadequate access to healthcare, among other dangers. Despite these difficulties, Ana runs a successful business selling clothing to her community. With this loan, she will buy clothing to sell at a small markup.

This is Ana’s sixth loan with Esperanza International. With her access to capital, she hopes to continue the growth of her business. Her profits have so far led to partial construction of her home and other improvements. Ana looks forward to continuing the growth of income so she can finish her house, save, and invest in other areas to make a better life for herself and her husband.

Esperanza International seeks to free children and their families from poverty through initiatives that generate income, education and health, restoring self-worth and dignity to those who have lost hope. We have over 8,500 active associates in eleven offices in the Dominican Republic and Haiti. Thank you for lending to Ana and the Fe y Accion group!

loans.use: Clothing for resale

loans.name: Melody

texts.en: In a big city like New York it can be very difficult to find a babysitter; people generally rely on word of mouth. With her entrepreneurial spirit, Melody saw an unfilled need and decided to launch a babysitting placement service in April, 2008. Melody's business has brought independence to her life. The flexibility of being her own boss allows her to still continue her career as a singer and performer in New York City and spend more time with her son. Melody found traditional bank loans too costly and difficult to acquire. She was recommended to ACCION USA for an affordable, small business loan. Melody will use her ACCION USA loan to purchase another computer for her growing staff, to provide age-appropriate toys for babysitters, and to ramp up her promotional efforts. Her vision is to expand her babysitting service; therefore, creating more jobs and at the same time raising awareness on the importance of child development. About U.S. Microfinance and ACCION USA Have you ever thought about how the new café on your corner and the delivery service that brings the fresh baked goods acquired the financial resources to start their business? Chances are, they drummed up support from their friends and family, dipped into their personal savings, used a high-interest credit card, or all of the above. An estimated 10 million small businesses in the U.S. face difficulty obtaining loans from traditional banks, even prior to the current “credit crisis.” Microfinance institutions, like ACCION USA, support these “unbanked” small businesses by giving them access to fairly-priced capital and business education. Small businesses also help stabilize low- to moderate-income neighborhoods and rebuild the economy through income growth and job creation. Self-employment provides workers with a way to increase their incomes, support their families, and strengthen their communities. As unemployment rises in the U.S., more and more people are turning to self-employment and start-up enterprises as a way to take control of their economic futures and provide employment opportunities in their communities. The need for support of small businesses in the U.S. is great, and it is one that ACCION USA has been striving to meet since 1991.

loans.use: To purchase a new computor and toys and for marketing

loans.name: Jose Alberto

texts.es:
