She is asking for 13,000 meticais, with which she intends to buy construction materials (cement, zinc sheets, sand and other items) in order to continue construction on her house. The previous loans were for 5,000 meticais, 8,000 meticais and 10,000 meticais, all for the same purpose. She dreams of taking out a loan to buy a vehicle. She promises to pay off this loan on time so she may take out more loans.

Translated from Portuguese by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of construction material (cement, zinc sheets, sand and other items)

loans.name: Dorcas

texts.en:
Dorcas is a hardworking and honest woman and she is determined to pull her business and family out of poverty. She is 40 years old and married with five children. She is happy because her children are excelling in school. She lives in Ogbomoso, Oyo State, Nigeria.

Dorcas sells foodstuffs like yam and cooking oil and she has been in this business for a long time. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She hopes to grow her business to become bigger and stronger.

Dorcas is a Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) client. She is requesting a loan of 80,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support.

LAPO is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Sherifat

texts.en:
Sherifat is into selling clothes and underwear. She wants to boost her business and so she is requesting a loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more clothes and underwear to sell. She said buying in bulk will increase her earnings for the family upkeep.

Sherifat has been in business for four years now and, with the proceeds from the business, she is able to support her husband who sells wood for roofing houses to provide for his family’s needs.

Sherifat is 32 years old and has two children. She says thank you to Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and underwear to sell

loans.name: Musili

texts.en:
Musili is a hardworking and honest woman and she is determined to pull her business and family out of poverty. She is 40 years old and married with three children. She is happy because her children are excelling in school. She lives in Ogbomoso, Oyo State, Nigeria.

Musili sells foodstuffs like bags of maize, yams and cooking oil and she has been in this business for a long time. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She hopes to grow her business to become bigger and stronger.

Musili is a Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) client. She is requesting a loan of N100,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support.

LAPO is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Madalena

texts.pt:
Madalena Massepula nasceu no Distrito de Boane, Província de Maputo, sul de Moçambique tem 53 anos de idade viuva e mãe de 2 filhos de 36 e 32 anos de idade que já constituíram suas famílias. Não estudou porque os pais não tinham condições e abandonaram na e cresceu na casa dos avós. 
Vive na casa própria e não sustenta ninguém seus filhos já são maiores de idade.
Nunca sai de cidade onde nasceu. Tem um negocio próprio há mais de 35 anos, não possui nenhum empregado e consegue um rendimento de cerca de 3.200.00mt por mês que aplica nas despesas de casa e tem ajuda dos seus filhos. Poupa algum na sua conta bancária (BARCLAYS).
Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de seu irmã que também é cliente desta instituição. Este é o seu 7º empréstimo no valor de 10.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (cimentos, chapas de zinco e outros) para dar continuidade com a construção sua casa. Os empréstimos anteriores foram de 6.000.00mt, 5.000.00mt, 6.000.00mt, 7.000.00, 10.200.00mt e 10.600.00mt todos para a mesma actividade.
No futuro deseja solicitar mais empréstimos para a conclusão da sua obra.
texts.en:
Madalena Massepula was born in Boane District, Maputo Province, in Southern Mozambique. She is 53 years old, a widow, and the mother of two children who are 36 and 32 years old, and who already have their own families. She never studied because her parents were without means, and left her to be raised by her grandparents. She lives in her own home, and has no other dependents since her children are already adults. Madalena never left the city where she was born. She has owned her own shop for more than 35 years. She has no employees, and earn around 3200 MZN per month, which she uses for household expenses along with help from her children. She saves a little in her (Barclay's) bank account. She has never taken out loans through other banks, and learned about Hluvuku through her sister who is also a client of the organization. This is her 7th loan, in the amount of 10,000 MZN, that she plans to use to purchase construction materials (cement, galvanized roofing, and others) to continue building her house. The earlier loans were for 6,000, 5,000, 6,000, 7,000, 10,200 and 10,600 MZN, all for the same purpose. In the future she wishes to apply for further loans to complete her work.

Translated from Portuguese by David Kaisel, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase construction materials (cement, galvanized roofing, others)

loans.name: Sion Plus Group

texts.en:
Sion Plus is a community bank made up of twenty-eight members whose chairwoman is Dordine M.. These members are united for the same goal: to grow their businesses by loans received from Kiva through micro-finance institute HOPE DRC.

Dordine sells palm oil and purified water in a market located to the west of Kinshasa and has been in business since 1995. Her beginning business capital was $25. With hard work and good management, Dordine’s business has prospered and now generates a profit of $20 per day.

Dordine intends, with this next loan, to purchase forty-five liters of palm oil for resale in order to meet her clients’ needs and to generate additional profits. Her dream is someday to become the company’s palm oil provider.

Dordine is married and has seven children, who are between 4 and 21 years old. Four of them attend school.

loans.use: To buy more palm oil to sell

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Margarida

texts.pt:
Margarida Paulo Macaringue nasceu no Distrito da Macie, Província de Gaza, sul de Moçambique tem 33 anos de idade casada e mãe de 3 filhos de 11,04 anos e um menor de dois anos de idade, o mais velho vai a escola. 

Tem 10ą classe feita, neste momento frequenta o ensino a distancia Naõ estudou porque os pais não tinham condições e abandonaram lhe ao cuidado dos avós. Vive na casa própria e não sustenta ninguém seus filhos já são maiores de idade. Trabalha de profesora ao mesmo tempo que estuda.

Este e o seu primeiro emprestimo con Hluvuku.
texts.en:
Margarida Paulo Macaringue was born in Macie District, Gaza Province, in Southern Mozambique. She is 33 years old, married, and the mother of three children 11, 4 and 2 years old. The eldest attends school. She completed 10th grade, and currently takes distance learning classes. She didn't study because her parents were without means and abandoned her to the care of her grandparents. She lives in her own house, she doesn't support anyone, her children are all grown up. She works as a teacher at the same time that she studies.

Translated from Portuguese by David Kaisel, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: compra de material de construção (cimentos, chapas de zinco e outros)

loans.name: Lepe

texts.en:
M. is 48 years old and is married with three children. She lives with her family in Lagos State where she sells cement wholesale and retail.

M. is requesting a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more bags of cement directly from the company at a reduced cost. This will enable her to meet her customers’ high demands while her own profit will also increase. She has been in this business for over two years and is doing fine.
 
M. is member in LAPO micro-finance with a good repayment record. She says thank you to all lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of cement to sell

loans.name: Iranete

texts.pt:
Iranete Farinha D. Conceição nasceu na cidade de Maputo, Província do mesmo nome, sul de Moçambique tem 27 anos de idade casaD. e mae de 2 filhos de 09 e 07 anos de idade, todos vão a escola. Fez somente 6ą classe não continuou devido a falta de condições financeiras. Vive na casa própria com sua família e de vez enquanto sustenta seus pais enviando dinheiro e alguns bens de consumo.
Saiu de Maputo para Boane quando casou e tem um negócio próprio há mais de 6 anos não possuem nenhum empregado consegue um rendimento de cerca de 8.000.00mt por Mês que aplica nas despesas de casa e consegue poupar algum na sua conta bancária.
Nunca teve emprestimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de amigas. Este é o seu 1º empréstimo no valor de 10.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar produtos (oleo, sabão, feijão, massa e outros) para aumentar a quantidade D. sua mercadoria.
Compromete se a pagar devidamente este empréstimo para poder aceder a outros, no futuro gostaria de solicitar mais empréstimos para aplicar no seu negócio.
texts.en:
Iranete Farinha D. Conceição was born in the city of Maputo in Southern Mozambique. She is 27 years old, married, and mother of two children 9 and 7 years old. Both go to school. She only completed 6th grade but didn't continue for lack of financial resources. She lives with her family in her own home and occasionally supports her parents sending them money and a few consumer goods. She left Maputo for Boane when she married, and has owned her own store for more than six years. She has no employees, and manages to earn around 8,000 MZN a month which she uses for household expenses as well as saving some in her bank account. She has never taken out a loan with another bank, and learned about Hluvuku through friends. This is her first loan in the amount of 10,000 MZN, with which she plans to purchase items (oil, soap, beans, pasta and others) to increase her merchandise. She intends to pay back the loan in a timely manner so she can receive additional loans. In the future she would like to request additional loans to use for her business.

Translated from Portuguese by David Kaisel, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase and sale of goods (oil, soap, beans, pasta and others)

loans.name: Antonio Elmone

texts.pt:
António Elmone Monteiro Durão nasceu na cidade de Maputo, Provincia do mesmo nome, sul de Moçambique tem 29 anos de idade solteiro e pai de 1 filho de 02 anos de idade, ainda não vai a escola. Fez 12ą classe não continuou devido a falta de condições financeiras. Vive na casa cedida pelos pais com o seu filho e não sustenta mais ninguém.
Nunca saiu de Maputo, tem um negocio próprio há mais de 6 anos e conta com ajuda de um empregado. Consegue um rendimento de cerca de 5.000.00mt por mês, que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda consegue poupar algum na sua conta bancária na.
Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através da sua mãe que também é cliente desta instituição a longa data. Este é o seu 1º empréstimo no valor de 10.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar (cimento, pó de pedra e areia) para o fabrico de blocos e vender no seu estaleiro.
Compromete se a pagar devidamente este empréstimo para poder aceder a outros, no futuro gostaria de solicitar mais empréstimos para aplicar no seu negócio.
texts.en:
António Elmone Monteiro Durão was born in the city of Maputo, Maputo Province in southern Mozambique. He is 29 years old, is single, and is the father of a two-year-old son who does not yet go to school. António finished twelfth grade but did not continue for financial reasons. He lives in his parents' house and does not support anyone else. He has never left Maputo. He has had his own business for more than six years and has one employee. He earns about 5,000 meticais per month, which he uses for household expenses. He also manages to save some money in his bank account. António has never taken out loans from other banks. He learned about Hluvuku through his mother, who is a long-time customer at this institution. This is his first loan. He is asking for 10,000 meticais, which he will use to buy cement, gravel and sand to make concrete brinks and sell them at his stand. He promises to pay off this loan on time so he can take out more loans. In the future he would like to ask for more loans to use for his business.

Translated from Portuguese by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of raw material for manufacture of concrete blocks (cement, gravel and sand)

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet is a hardworking and honest woman and she is determined to pull her business and family out of poverty. She is 45 years old and married with six children. She is happy because her children are excelling in school. She lives in Ogbomoso, Oyo State, Nigeria. Her husband also works to support their home.

Janet sells foodstuffs like bags of garri (cassava flakes) and she has been in this business for a long time. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She hopes to grow her business to become bigger and stronger.

Janet is a Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) client. She is requesting a loan of N100,000 to purchase more more bags of garri (cassava flakes) to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support.

LAPO is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of cement, iron, support beams and other items

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is a hardworking and honest woman and she is determined to pull her business and family out of poverty. She lives in Ogbomoso, Oyo State, Nigeria. She is 40 years old and married with four children. She is happy because her children are excelling in school. Her husband also works to support their home.

Esther sells cooking oil at retail prices and she has been in this business for a long time. Cooking oil in Nigeria is used in the preparation of mouth-watering Nigerian cooked foods. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She hopes to grow her business to become bigger and stronger.

Esther is a Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) client. She is requesting a loan of N100,000 to purchase more cooking oil to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support.

LAPO is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

loans.use: To purchase more cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of constructions materials (cement, iron, beams and other items)

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice sells and supplies drinks for various ceremonies like birthdays, weddings, burial ceremonies and more. She has been in business for the past six years and, with this trade, she assists her husband in taking care of the children.

Beatrice has been borrowing from LAPO micro-finance for the past three years and she is a faithful client. She orders her goods once every two weeks in large quantity at a discount. She is requesting a loan of NGN 80,000 to purchase more drinks to sell which will enable her meet her customers’ demands while increasing her profit.

Beatrice is 48 years old and has four children. She says thank you and promise to pay back her loan promptly.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Castigo

texts.pt:
Castigo Lorino M. nasceu no Distrito de Manjacaze, Província de Gaza, sul de Moçambique tem 31 anos de idade casado e pai de 3 filhos de 8, 6 e 1 anos de idade, destes 2 vão a escola. Fez somente 5ą classe não continuou devido a falta de condições financeiras, mas pretende continuar a estudar. Vive na casa propria com a sua família e não sustenta mais ninguém.
Saiu de Gaza para Boane com os seus pais a procura de melhores condições de vida. Tem um negocio próprio há mais de 8 anos sem nenhum empregado e consegue um rendimento que varia de 2.500.00mt a 3.000.00mt por mês e aplica nas despesas de casa.
Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de amigos que também são clientes desta instituição. Este é o seu 2º empréstimo no valor de 10.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar (fardos de roupa usada diversa) para aumentar a quantidade da sua mercadoria. O emprestimo anterior foi de 6.000.00mt, também foi para a mesma actividade.
Compromete se a pagar devidamente este empréstimo para poder aceder a outros. No futuro gostaria de solicitar mais empréstimos para a conclusão da sua casa.
texts.en:
Castigo Lorino M. was born in the district of Manjacaze, Gaza Province, in southern Mozambique. He is 31 years old, married, and the father of three children 8, 6, and 1 year of age. Two of his children attend school. He lives in his own house with his family, and isn't financially responsible for anyone else. With his parents, he left Gaza for Boane in search of better living conditions. He's had his own business for more than 8 years with no other employees. The business brings in between 2500 and 3000 meticals a month, which she uses for household expenses. She's never received loans from other banks. She learned about Hvuluku from friends who are also Hvuluku clients. This is her second loan, in the amount of 10,000 meticals, which she will use to purchase merchandise (bundles of used clothing) in order to increase the quantity of her stock. Her previous loan was for 6000 meticals, which he needed for the same purpose. He's committed to paying this loan off on time so that he'll be eligible for others in the future. He'd like to request additional loans to finish construction on his house.

Translated from Portuguese by Andrea Rosenberg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase bundles of used clothing

loans.name: Falicia

texts.en:
Falicia is a hardworking and honest woman and she is determined to pull her business and family out of poverty. She lives in Ogbomoso, Oyo State, Nigeria. She is 37 years old and married with five children. She is happy because her children are excelling in school. Her husband also works to support their home.

Falicia sells rubber slippers and shoes at retail prices to her customers. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She hopes to grow her business to become bigger and stronger.

Falicia is a Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) client. She is requesting a loan of N50,000 to purchase more rubber slippers and shoes to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support.

LAPO is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

loans.use: To purchase more rubber slippers and shoes to sell

loans.name: Tunde

texts.en: Tunde is well known as a business man in his community. He sells office stationery and books. He hopes to attract more customers. His greatest challenge is funding and he hopes to overcome the challenge. He is married and has 4 children and he is 50 years old. His wife also works to support their home. He is requesting for a loan amount of NGN50,000 to purchase more stationery and books to boost his business. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders

loans.use: To purchase more stationery and books to sell.

loans.name: Tessy

texts.en:
Tessy sells groceries and food items. She buys goods in large quantities from the market once a week, except on special demands. Tessy has been in business for close to eight years. She assists her husband with the profit from the business and she is a good help mate.

Tessy is requesting for a loan of NGN 170,000 to enable her to increase the quantity of goods that she buys and sells; this in turn will lead to price reduction, meet customers demands and maximize profit.
 
She is 50 years old, married and has four children. With the increase in profit, as a result of this loan, her family's needs will be better fulfilled. She says thank you to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and food items to sell.

loans.name: Lidia Pedro

texts.pt:
Lídia Pedro M. nasceu na Provincia de Gaza, sul de Moçambique tem 46 anos de idade casada e mae de 5 filhos de 27, 20, 17, 13 e 9 anos de idade, destes 4 vão a escola. Fez somente 6ą classe não continuou devido a falta de condições financeiras. Vive na casa propria com a sua família e sustenta a mãe enviando algum valor monetário.
Saiu de Gaza para Boane com os seus pais durante a guerra de desestabilização. Tem um negocio próprio há mais de 6 anos, não possui nenhum empregado e consegue um rendimento de cerca de 2.000.00mt a 2.500.00mt por mês, que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda consegue poupar algum na sua conta bancária.
Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos conheceram a Hluvuku através de amigos que também são clientes desta instituição. Este é o seu 1º empréstimo no valor de 11.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar (fardos de roupa usada diversa) para aumentar a quantidade da sua mercadoria. 
Compromete se a pagar devidamente este empréstimo para poder aceder a outros. No futuro gostaria de solicitar mais empréstimos para aplicar na melhoria de seu estabelecimento.
texts.en:
Lidia Pedro M. was born in the province of Gaza in the south of Mozambique. She is 46 years old, married, and has 5 children who are 27, 20, 17, 13 and 9 years old. Four of her children attend school. Lidia only studied through 6th grade, and didn't continue because of a lack of financial resources. She lives in her own home with her family and supports her mother by sending her money. Lidia left Gaza for Boane with her parents during the Mozambican civil war. She has owned her own business for more than 6 years and doesn't have anyone else working for her. She makes some 2000-2500 Meticales each month. She uses this money to cover household expenses and also saves some in her bank account. Lidia has never taken out loans with other banks. She found out about Hluvuku [the Kiva field partner] through friends who also work with the institution. This is her first loan, for 11,000 Meticales. She plans to use the money to buy packs of used clothing in order to increase her stock of merchandise. She promises to repay this loan back as stated, in order to be eligible for others in the future, She would like to take out more loans to put towards improving her shop.

Translated from Portuguese by Catherine Fountain, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of packs of used clothing to be sold

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth is married with five children and she is 47 years old. She lives in Ogbomoso, Oyo state, Nigeria. She sells mouth watering Nigerian cooked foods in the market and she has been in this business for six years. She hopes to expand her business and attract more customers. 

Ruth is a hard working woman and dedicated to her business. She is requesting a loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell

loans.name: Afon

texts.en:
Afon is married, has a child, and is 40 years old.  His child attends school which gives him joy as a father. He is a hard working man and he is determined to lift his business and family above poverty. 

He lives in Ogbomoso, Oyo state, Nigeria. He sells clothes, bags and shoes at retail prices. With these combined businesses, he hopes to meet the basic needs of his immediate family. He has been in this business for 10 years. 

He is requesting a loan amount of 80,000 NGN to purchase more clothes and shoes to sell. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and shoes to sell

loans.name: Artur Carlos

texts.pt:
Artur Carlos M. nasceu no Distrito de Massingue, Provincia de Inhambane, sul de  Moçambique tem 36 anos de idade casado e pai de 3 filhos de 13, 10 e 06 anos de idade, todos vão a escola. Fez somente 7ą classe não continuou devido a falta de condições financeiras. Vive na casa propria com a sua familia e sustenta a mãe enviando algum valor monetário juntamente com outros seus irmãos.
Saiu de Inhambane para Boane devido a transferência dos serviços, saiu com a sua família. Trabalha na Empresa de construção de estradas como operador de máquinas pesadas, tem também pensão mensal, da desmobilização militar. Não possui empregado, em suma consegue um rendimento de cerca de 4.800.00mt por mês, que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda consegue poupar algum na sua conta bancária.
Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de amigos que também são clientes desta instituição. Este é o seu 2º empréstimo no valor de 8.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material eléctrico (fios eléctricos, contador, tomadas e outros) para electrificar a sua casa.
texts.en:
Artur Carlos M. was born in the district of Massingue, in Inhambane province in the south of Mozambique. He is 36 years old, married, and has 3 children who are 13, 10 and 6 years old. All of his children attend school. Artur only studied through the 7th grade, and didn't continue because of a lack of financial resources. He lives in his own home with his family and along with his siblings he helps to support his mother by sending her money. Artur left Inhambane for Boane with his family due to a job transfer. He works for a road construction company operating heavy machinery and has also collected a monthly pension since being discharged from the army. He does not employ any household help and in all he has a monthly income of 4800 Meticales, which he uses to cover household expenses. He also manages to save some of this income in his bank account. Artur has never taken out a loan with another bank. He found out about Hluvuku [the Kiva Field Partner] through friends who also work with the institution. This is his 2nd loan, for the amount of 8000 Meticales. He plans to use this money to buy materials (electrical wires, a meter, and sockets) in order to wire his house for electricity.

Translated from Portuguese by Catherine Fountain, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of materials for installing electricity (electrical wires, a meter, and sockets)

loans.name: Bolanle

texts.en:
Bolanle sew dresses and also sells women undergarments.  She goes to Lagos Island to buy clothing material as soon as her stock goes down. With this business she makes a living and takes care of other family needs. She has been in this business for over ten years. 

She is requesting a loan of 70,000 NGN to purchase more clothing materials at a reduced cost and also reduce the risk of been on the road more often. In the photo what she is holding is one of her pieces of finished work.

Bolanle is 45 years old and married with four children. Her husband is a plumber who sometimes helps her at the shop. She says thanks to Kiva- LAPO microfinance for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing materials to sew and sell.

loans.name: George Stanley

texts.en:
N. George Stanley has a fascinating business story connected with him. For the last five years, he has defied all odds to keep his coffee and banana sales business afloat. His stock in trade - his calling card, which he has banked on all this while, has been his persistence, patience and strong resolve in the face of envy, losses and uncertain weather seasons that threatened to render his business almost stagnant.

George’s business currently generates him close to 300,000 Ugandan shillings per month. With this he has been able to shoulder the responsibility of taking care of his eight children, principally facilitating their education. His coffee and banana business which he operates in Katooma, Kayonza, Ntungamo, has made enormous strides that he did not envisage at the beginning.

It’s for that reason that this happily-married man wants to consolidate the gains he has made. His dream is to see significant increases in the amount of coffee and bananas he sells to his increasing client base. He also wants to improve on the current welfare of his family. With this loan he wants to buy more coffee and bananas so that he does not run out of stock.

loans.use: To buy more coffee to sell and to store as surplus and to buy more bananas

loans.name: Ayinla

texts.en:
Ayinla is married, has four children and is 43 years old. His children attend school and this gives him joy as a father. He is a hard working and honest man and he is determined to lift his business and family above poverty. He lives in Ogbomoso, Oyo state, Nigeria. 

He sells VCDs (video compact discs) at retail prices to his customers. With this business, he hopes to meet the basic needs of his immediate family. He hopes to grow his business to become bigger and stronger. He has been in this business for nine years. He is requesting a loan amount of 80,000 NGN to purchase more VCDs to sell. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more VCDs to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Resupply her store

loans.name: Bosede

texts.en:
Bosede sells drinks and pepper soup at her shop. She buys drinks in bulk and sells at retail. She gets goods directly from the factory through the company sales representatives. She started this trade in 2003.	

Bosede is a 50-year-old widow with four children. This trade enables her to clothe, feed and take care of the children’s needs.

Bosede is requesting a loan of 100,000 NGN to purchase more drinks to sell. She says thank you and promises to repay promptly.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Barbra

texts.en:
In 2008, this diligently resourceful woman embarked on her first business venture. At its threshold, many financial challenges came her way. She had to come to grips with the prospect of operating her modest retail business with unreliable operating capital.

What was at the root of all this was the initial monthly payment of taxes and other utilities, plus the unstable nature of retail business in that part of the country. She also had not gained that much niche in the market. She refused to buckle under the pressure and as a result this enterprising woman is one of the most forward-striding retailers in Rutare in Ntungamo district.

This is the story of N. Barbra, a 43-year-old married mother of one. Monthly, her business brings in for her profits to the tune of 180,000 Ugandan shillings. Her future reckoning is to give her business a “leaps and bounds” expansion and also to improve on the overall standard of living of her family.

With the aid of this loan, Barbra says she will be able to restock her small retail shop with new garments and other forms of merchandise that she deals in.

loans.use: To purchase additional merchandise to sell

loans.name: Joshua

texts.en:
Joshua is married, has three children, and is 43 years old. His children attend school and this gives him joy as a father. He is a hard working and honest man and he is determined to lift his business and family above poverty. He lives in Ogbomoso, Oyo state, Nigeria. 

He sells motor spare parts at retail prices to his customers. With this business, he hopes to meet the basic needs of his immediate family. He hopes to grow his business to become bigger and stronger. He has been in this business for a long time. He is requesting a loan amount of 50,000 NGN to purchase more motor spare parts to sell. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more motor spare parts to sell

loans.name: Omolade

texts.en: To earn a living in Ogbomosho, Omolade sells colorful sarongs and items made of lace. Her customers are mostly young ladies and married women. She hopes to own a boutique in the future, but for now has applied for a loan for N80,000 to buy more sarongs and lace items to sell at her current location. She is 34 years old, married and has four children. She takes great joy in the fact that they are excelling in school. Omolade and her husband, who also works hard, extend their sincerest thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy more sarongs and lace items to sell

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther makes a living as a seamstress, selling clothes and tailoring materials that her customers use to make various designs on their clothes. She has been in this business for eight years, and has applied for a loan of NGN 100,000 to buy supplies in bulk at a reduced rate. This will also allow her to improve her family's life by producing more items to sell, since buying in bulk means she won't need to travel to her suppliers as often. Esther is 40 years old, married and has four children. She offers her sincerest thanks to all Kiva lenders for their wonderful assistance.

loans.use: To buy more items to sell.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is a hard-working and honest woman who is determined to pull her family out of poverty. She lives in Ogbomoso, Oyo State, Nigeria. For many years now, she has made a living selling drinks and other items, and she works hard because she hopes to grow her business. She is 45 years old, married and has five children. Her husband also works hard to support their family, and both parents are happy because their children are doing well in school. Mary has applied for a loan for N100,000 to buy more drinks to sell, and extends sincerest thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support. She is a client of LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization), a microlending group which is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and other parts of Africa.

loans.use: To buy more drinks to sell

loans.name: Iyabode

texts.en: Iyabode is a hard-working and honest woman who is determined to pull her family out of poverty. She lives in Ogbomoso, Oyo State, Nigeria, where she has made a living for years by selling cooking oil. In Nigeria, this oil is used to prepare many local dishes, including many soups, and to process herbs. Iyabode is 45 years old, married and has five children. Her husband also works hard to support their family. Both parents are happy because their children are doing very well in school. Iyabode has applied for a loan for N50,000 to purchase more cooking oil to sell. She extends sincerest thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support and is happy to be a client of LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization), which is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and else in Africa.

loans.use: To buy more cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy palm trees

loans.name: Janet

texts.en: To earn a living in Ogbomosho, Janet sells colorful sarongs. Her customers are mostly young ladies and married women. She loves this business because of the opportunity it gives her to interact with people, and she hopes to one day have her own boutique where she will continue to sell only sarongs. She has applied for a loan for N150,000 to buy more sarongs to sell. Janet is 32 years old, married and takes great joy in her four children, all of whom are excelling in school. Her husband also works hard to support their family, and the couple extends sincere thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Raphael

texts.en:
Raphael O. O. is 69 years old. He has married two wives, one is a farmer and the other one is a tailor. He has eight children aged between 3 and 41 years. 

His business is located in a residential area in Mombasa, Kenya, and it is well known by the name "Dhobi O. and Water Supply." He supplies water to the local people for home consumption and does laundry services for them. He says although the business is profitable, there is a challenge of consistent water supply. He is therefore taking a loan of 60,000 Kenyan shillings to be able to buy a water storage tank and an ironing table to enable him carry out his business better. 

He says that in the future, he hopes to buy a plot of land and build a residential house for his family. He is hardworking and trustworthy.

loans.use: Water tank, ironing table

loans.name: Dashola

texts.en:
Dashola is 45 years old, married and has a child. She is a trader; she sells groceries like milk, tea, matches, toothpaste, tomato paste and more. She has been managing this business for over nine years. She works hard to make sure her customers' demands are meet and that there is food on her table at the end of the day.

Dashola wants to expand and improve on her business. She is asking for a loan of 80,000 Nigerian naira to purchase groceries in bulk as this will attract a better discount and more profit on each sale. She promises to pay the loan back at the due date and says thanks to Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en:
Fatima sells colorful clothes at retail prices. Her customers are mostly young ladies and married women. She loves this business because of the opportunity to interact with her customers. She hopes to own a boutique in the future. 

She hopes for a loan of 50,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more clothes to sell. 

She is 28 years old and married with two children. Her children are excelling in school and this gives her joy. Her husband also works to support their home. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Kazeem

texts.en: Kazeem is married and he is 32 years old. He is blessed with a child who gives him joy as a father. He lives in Oyo state, Nigeria. He sells medicines at retail prices to his customers.  He has been in this business for 10 years and he uses his experience in business to attract and retain more customers. He is requesting a loan amount of 50,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more medicines to sell. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their assistance.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell

loans.name: Fumilayo

texts.en:
Fumilayo is 52 years old. She is married and has six children. She sells foodstuffs like onions, maize, etc., in bulk to her customers. She buys her goods from the rural market, where she gets them at a cheaper rate. But her challenge now is that she needs additional capital to buy more goods from the market to sell, make more profit and avoid always traveling to the market. She has been in this business for more than 10 years.

Fumilayo is asking for a loan of 50,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more foodstuffs to sell and get more discounts to maximize profit. She expresses her huge gratitude to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Marie

texts.en:
Marie Y. is a very happy and lovely woman. She is 38 years old, married, and has four children: a boy and three girls.The first child is in college and the last three children are in secondary school. Her husband works as a general secretary in one of the motor parks. They live with their children in Grassfield Lumley. 

Marie owns a shop where she sells cooked food and palm oil around Lumley market, an area of Freetown, the capital city of Sierra Leone. Marie has been in this business for 15 years now. She joined LAPO,SL as a client in July 2008. Since then, she has taken three loans.With her previous loans she has been able to open two more centres for her cookery business. She is seeking a loan of 3,000,000 SLL from Kiva lenders through LAPO,SL for her to expand more and more in her business and also to help her family.

loans.use: This loan will be used to buy food items and palm oil.

loans.name: Sarat

texts.en: Sarat is a business man and he loves his business so much. He sells phone accessories at retail prices to his customers to make a living in Ogbomoso, Oyo state, Nigeria. He is married and has 2 children. He is 37 years old and his wife also works to support their home. He has been in this business for 4 years and he hopes to grow his business to become bigger and stronger. Sarat is requesting for a loan amount of NGN50,000 to purchase more phone accessories to sell. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more phone accessories to sell.

loans.name: Isola

texts.en: Isola is a hard working man. He has a motor cycle that he uses for commercial purposes in the evenings. During the day he has a fish pond where he raises fish to sell. He works for long hours to be able to support his home. He is married and has 5 children and he is 45 years old. His wife also works to support their home. Isola is requesting for a loan amount of NGN50,000 to purchase more feed to boost his business. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more feed to boost his business.

loans.name: Abimbola

texts.en:
Abimbola is 32 years old, married and has four children. She is a committed LAPO client. She sells groceries and manages the business with the support of her husband. She assists him in taking care of the family, such as feeding, clothing and payment of the children's school fees. She has been in business for close to twelve years now. 

She wants to improve more on her business and so she is requesting for a loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase groceries in bulk. She will then sell the groceries at a good price thereby increasing profit and meeting customer's demands. She says thank you to all lenders.

loans.use: To purchase groceries in bulk to sell.

loans.name: Philipa

texts.en:
Philipa is a faithful and hard-working businesswoman who sells groceries to her customers. She is married to an electrician. She is thirty years old with three children from age 16 – 22. She spends most of her time taking care of her business and supporting her children in school. She loves selling and enjoys serving customers. She trades in groceries like candies, mineral water, toiletries, hair creams, assorted biscuits, etc. She has operated her shop for the past 8 years in her neighborhood. 

Philipa believes in customer care and her broad smile almost always draws customers to her shop, making her one of the most successful sellers of groceries. She plans to use the loan to purchase more stock of groceries to serve her customers, especially during the Easter festivities. She says that she dreams of being able to generate enough profits that she will be able to educate her children to at least the tertiary school level.

loans.use: To purchase to assorted groceries like candies, toiletries, bottled water, etc.

loans.name: Monsuratu

texts.en:
Monsuratu is 48 years old, married and has four children. Her children are aged 9 to 28 years old. They also assist her in the trade when they are back from school. She hopes to expand more on her business so she can make a good profit for her business and family upkeep. 

Monsuratu buys and sells drinks and also sells cooked food to her customers. She has been in this business since 1998.         
She is requesting for a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase drinks and food items in bulk at a reduced rate so she can sell more and make more profit as well. She says thank to all lenders.

loans.use: To purchase food items and drinks to sell.

loans.name: Nicholas

texts.en: Nicholas M. is sixty years old, married and has five children. His business is located at Tindiyo, a busy market in Kakamega. He has been selling cows, goats and sheep to the butchers, farmers and schools for the last twenty years. He says that this business is very profitable and the only challenge is animals being stolen. He is taking a loan of KES 40,000 to purchase cows and goats to expand his business. He hopes to buy a pick up to transport the animals to the slaughter house. He also hopes to give his children a quality education and also to build a residential house for his family. He is a generous and social man.

loans.use: To purchase 3 cows and 4 goats.

loans.name: Deborah

texts.en:
Deborah sells juice and drinks; the fridges by her are all stocked with drinks. She sells wholesale and retail to her customers. Most of her sales are to retailers who hawk around the marketplace and motor park. She needs a loan of 50,000 nairas to purchase more juice and drinks to sell.

Deborah is 45 years old, married and has four children. She lives in Lagos with her family. Her shop is open from Monday through Saturday from 8 am to 6 pm. She appreciates lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more juice and drinks to sell

loans.name: Tawa

texts.en: Tawa is 44 years old, married and has four children. The entire family lives in Lagos State. Tawa sells drinks and has been in this business for over five years. She hopes to expand her business by buying more drinks to sell. She is requesting for a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more drinks to sell at a discount. This will attract more customers to her business places and to make more profit. Tawa has been a member in LAPO microfinance for some years with good record. She promises to pay back the loan at the due date as she has always done. She says thanks to all lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell.

loans.name: Les Collegues Group

texts.fr:
Farida B. (qui se trouve en bas au coin gauche de la photo) gere une kioske dans le Quartier Bwiza de la ville de Bujumbura ou elle vend divers articles mais principalement y mene l’activite de telephone publique avec la vente des credits d’appels pour la telephonie mobile. En reponse a la demande de ses clients, elle va utiliser le credit Turame pour acheter des produits alimentaires qu’elle n’a jamais vendu jusqu’ aujourd’hui. Elle a confiance que la diversification des produits va augmenter son profit.

Farida a 28 ans. Apres ses etudes secondaires, elle a commence a travailler comme secretaire pour une societe qui vend des telephones mobiles a Bujumbura. En Mai 2009 elle a ouvert sa propre boutique.

Elle est mariee et mere de 2 fillettes.  L’ainee est agee de 5 ans et etudie en 3e maternelle et la cadette a 2 ans. Elle prend en charge deux autres filles  agees respectivement de quinze et quatorze ans qu’elle a emmenees du Congo (DRC) parce que ses parents n’etaient pas a mesure de subvenir a leurs besoins. 

Elle a un souhait pour ses enfants, celui de reussir leur vie et de mener une tres bonne vie.  Elle aimerait aussi continuer ses etudes en Medecine, mais les moyens financiers lui font defaut.  Elle souhaiterait devenir Medecin ou Infirmiere.
texts.en:
Farida B. (who is in the bottom left corner of the photo) has a kiosk in the Bwiza Neighborhood of the town of Bujumbura where she sells various items but principally manages a public telephone booth, also selling charge cards for mobile phones. To respond to her customers' demand, she intends to use her Turame loan to buy foodstuffs that she has never sold before now. She is confident that the diversification of her inventory will raise her profit. Farida is 28 years old. After her secondary studies, she began to work as a secretary for a company selling mobile phones in Bujumbura. In May 2009, she opened her own little shop. Farida is married and the mother of 2 little girls. The older is five and is enrolled in her third year of kindergarden and the younger is two. Farida is responsible for two other girls, aged 15 and 14, whom she brought back from the Congo (DRC) because their parents were not able to support them. Farida has one wish for her children: to see them succeed and live a very good life. She would also like to continue her studies in medicine, but she lacks the funds to do so. She would like to become a doctor or a nurse.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying foodstuffs to diversify her inventory

loans.name: Tunde

texts.en: Tunde is a hard working and honest man. He has a fish pond where he raises fish to sell. He loves this business because of the opportunity to interact with his customers. He works for long hours to be able to support his home. He is married, has 4 children and he is 40 years old. His wife also works to support their home. Tunde is requesting for a loan amount of NGN50,000 to purchase more fingerlings to boost his business. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more fingerlings

loans.name: Aina

texts.en:
Aina is a trader; she buys bread in large quantities and supplies her customers at their business places. She does this trade to make a living and help her husband, who is a commercial driver, take care of the family. She started this business six years ago and before that she sold foodstuffs. She is focused on making sure she meets the demands of her customers, which she says will also lead to increase in profit.

Aina is 34 years old, married and has four children. She is a member of LAPO microfinance with a good record. She is asking for a loan of 100,000 nairas to purchase more bread to sell. This will enable her to get numerous customers and make more profit. She promises to pay back promptly and says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more bread to sell

loans.name: Jacob

texts.en: Jacob is married with four children. He is 48 years old. He lives in Oyo state, Nigeria. He rides a motorcycle for commercial purposes. He hopes to own another motorcycle.  He has been in this business for eight years. Jacob is requesting a loan amount of 50,000 to purchase a motorcycle to boost his business. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle

loans.name: Upendo Kahembe Group

texts.fr:
Masika T. est présidente du groupe de crédit Upendo Kahembe, elle lève la main sur la photo , cliente au 13e  cycle de credit,agée de 41 ans, divorcée.Elle est mère de  7 enfants  parmi lesquels   4   vont à l’école et 1 fait une formation en mécanique,  2 autres n’ont pas l’âge scolaire  .Notons  qu’elle supporte seule la charge de ses enfants car son ancien mari l’a complètement abandonné.
Son business est la fabrication artisanale de boisson traditionnelle appelée “Mandrakwa” issue de transformation de Maïs par une technologie locale.
Elle a commencé ses activités avec un capital propre de 60$  après l’érruption du volcan nyiragongo qui avait complètement detruit  toutes les économies de la ville de Goma en janvier 2002.
il y a 8 ans qu’elle exerce cette activité de fabrication artisanale de boisson traditionnelle “Madrakwa”.  
Avec  le crédit de  l’IMF Hekima, elle souhaite augmenter son chiffre d’affaire en achetant   32 sacs de Maïs et renforcer ses equipements de production.
En outre, elle planifie ouvrir une petite boutique et acheter un minu bus pour le transport urbain étant donné que son fils aine vient de terminer une formation en mécanique auto mobile.
Elle rémércie l’IMF Hekima pour  les crédits  qu’elle recoit sans aucune garantie materielle car grace a ces credits elle parvient a subvenir aux besoins de ses enfants et se realiser progressivement des economies familiales.
Ce groupe est  composé des 12 membres dont 11 femmes et 1 homme sur la photo.
texts.en:
Masika T., who puts up her hand on the picture, chairs the credit group Upendo Kahembe. She is currently on her 13th loan cycle. She is 41 years old, divorced and the mother of seven children: four of them attend school, one is trained as a mechanic and two are too young to go to school. It is worth noting that she provides only for her children, because her ex-husband has completely left her. Masika's business consists of small-scale production of the traditional drink "Mandrakwa", which is made from corn with local technology. She began this activity with a start capital of US$60, just after the eruption of Nyiragongo Volcano in January 2002 had destroyed the whole economic infrastructure in the city of Goma. Thus she produced for 8 years "Mandrakwa" in her traditional production style. She came to the microfinance institution Hekima and applied for this loan, which she will use to buy 32 sacks of corn to bolster her production capacity and increase her turnover. In addition, she wants to open a small store and buy a minibus for city transportation, since her oldest son has just finished his apprenticeship in automobile mechanics. Masika is thankful to MFI Hekima for the loans granted to her without any physical guarantee, because these loans enabled her to provide for her children and gradually build up some savings for her family. This group is composed of 12 members, 11 women and 1 man, all pictured.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 32 sacks of corn

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Amos

texts.en: Amos is a hard working and honest man. He rides a motorcycle. He loves this business because of the opportunity to interact with his customers. He works for long hours to be able to support his home. He is married with four children and he is 50 years old. His wife also works to support their home. Amos is requesting a loan amount of 50,000 NGN to purchase a motorcycle to boost his business. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle

loans.name: Fatai

texts.en: 51-year-old Fatai is married and has four children. Her children are between 14 and 30 years old. She is hard working even at her age. She makes sure she engages herself in a business activity. She sells kpomo (roasted cow skin) which is used as meat. A lot of people see it as an alternative to cow meat. She has been in the business for over four years. Due to high patronage in the business, Fatai wants to buy more kpomo to sell to her customers. Fatai is asking for a loan of NGN 100,000 to buy more kpomo to sell to her numerous customers and make more profit. She appreciates all lenders for their financial empowerment.

loans.use: To buy more kpomo (roasted cow skin) to sell.

loans.name: Aderemi

texts.en: Aderemi is 40 years and married with five children. He is a hard working man and he is determined to lift his business and family above poverty. He lives in Ogbomoso, Oyo state, Nigeria. He is a fashion designer by profession and he sells sarongs. With these combined businesses, he hopes to meet the basic needs of his immediate family. He has been in this business for 20 years. He is requesting a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more tailoring material and clothes to sell. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials and clothes

loans.name: Yaa

texts.en:
Yaa is clearly a hard worker. She is 37 years old and sells bales of used clothes to customers in the busy Central Market of Kumasi. Yaa has been operating her business for sixteen years and is eager to be taking out this loan. She plans to use this loan to purchase bales of assorted used clothes for adults and children to meet customers’ demands. Used clothes are most patronized since brand new ones are expensive for the ordinary man. This has created a market for women like Yaa.

Yaa is married to a gentleman who is also a trader. They have three children from age 5 – 20 years. She says that she dreams of being able to generate enough profits so that she will be able to educate her children to at least the tertiary school level.

loans.use: To purchase assorted used clothes for adults and children

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
O. is 40 years old, married and has three children under her care. She is hard working and has been in LAPO microfinance for the past two years. She styles clothes for both men and women, sells tailoring accessories and drinks. She has been in these businesses since 1995. She makes sure her customers demands are met while indirectly improving herself financially.

O. is requesting a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase a deep freezer and use the balance of the money to purchase tailoring materials to sell. She says thanks to Kiva and LAPO microfinance for this wonderful initiative.

loans.use: To purchase a deep freezer and tailoring materials

loans.name: Familoni

texts.en:
R. is 43 years old, married and has two children. R. sells groceries and has been in this business for the past eight years. She is focused on making sure she meets the demands of her customers which she says will also lead to increase in profit for her.

R. is asking for a loan of 170,000 nairas to purchase groceries to sell as this will enable her to get a better discount and make more profit on each sale. She is a client of LAPO and has been borrowing from LAPO for the past four years. She promises to pay back promptly and says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Shittu

texts.en: Shittu is 45 years old, married with 4 children. She is a hard-working women and she is determined to lift her business and family above poverty. She lives in Ogbomoso, Oyo State, Nigeria. She sells powder, perfume, tailoring materials, etc. With businesses, she hopes to assist her husband with the basic needs of her immediate family. She is requesting the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more powder, perfume, and tailoring materials. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders

loans.use: To purchase more powder, perfume, tailoring materials, etc.

loans.name: Tamaraneh Iii Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the Tamaraneh III group. They are small-scale businesswomen from Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They have come together as a group of three in order to seek a loan from SMT/Kiva lenders. With the help of this loan, this group of entrepreneurs will be able to improve their businesses and consequently their living conditions. 

The leader of this group is Isatu T.. Isatu is thirty-two years old. She was born in Makeni, is married and has three children. Her husband is a businessman and her children are attending school – one in secondary school and two in primary school. Isatu has been selling cosmetics and jewelry for many years now. With her share of the loan, she will improve her business by buying jewelry and Vaseline wholesale.

loans.use: To improve her business by buying costume jewelry and Vaseline wholesale

loans.name: Tataimitha Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the Tataimitha group from the town of Magburaka in northern Sierra Leone. They are small-scale businesswomen who have applied for a loan of SLL 500,000 for each in the group in order to expand their businesses. With the help this loan, they can buy more goods to add to their current ones.

Fatmata T. is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Fatmata is 35 years old. She was born in Magburaka, is married to a policeman, and they have five children – two in secondary school, one in primary school; one is not of school-going age and the other now works for a living. For three years now, Fatmata has been selling rice, oil, and kerosene. With her share of the loan, she will buy rice, oil and kerosene wholesale to add to her current stock.

loans.use: Buy rice, oil and kerosene wholesale to add to her current stock

loans.name: Juan Orlando

texts.es: EL SR. ES CASADO Y SE DEDICA AL TRANSPORTE PUBLICO(TAXI). CON VEHICULO PROPIO, DESDE HACE DIEZ AÑOS Y MEDIO SE DEDICA A ESTA ACTIVIDAD, ESTA EN SU SEGUNDA SECUENCIA, DONDE HA DEMOSTRADO SER RESPONSABLE EN SUS PAGOS. EL SEÑOR VIVE EN ANTICRETICO CON SU ESPOSA Y DOS HIJOS QUE SE ENCUENTRAN EN EDAD ESCOLAR, RECIBE EL APOYO DE SU ESPOSA QUE SE DEDICA AL COMERCIO DE DULCES EN LA PUERTA DE UNA ESCUELA, AMBOS TRABAJAN MUCHO PARA MEJORARA SU CALIDAD DE VIDA DE TODA SU FAMILIA SON PERSONAS JOVENES QUE TIENEN MUCHAS GANAS DE SUPERACION.CON EL DINERO DEL CREDITO COMPRARA LLANTAS PARA SU VEHICULO Y REALIZARA EL MANTENIMIENTO DEL MISMO YA QUE ESTA PRESENTANDO MUCHAS FALLAS Y NO LE PERMITE TRABAJAR CON NORMALIDAD Y REALIZARA EL MANTENIMIENTO PARA PODER  BRINDAR UN MEJOR SERVICIO A SUS CLIENTES. ESTA MUY AGRADECIDO CON EMPRENDER Y KIVA POR LA CONFIANZA BRINDADA EN LA OTORGACION DEL CREDITO.
texts.en:
The client is married and works in public (taxi) transportation, using his own vehicle. He has worked in this field for ten and a half years. He is in his second loan cycle, and he has shown himself to be responsible with his payments. The client lives in rented quarters with his wife and two school-aged children. He receives help from his wife, who sells sweets at the gate of a school. Both of them are working very hard to improve the quality of life for their entire family. They are young people with a great desire to get ahead. With the funds from the loan, the client will buy tires for his vehicle and also carry out maintenance on it, since it has several problems which prevent him from working on a consistent basis. This maintenance will enable him to provide better service to his customers. He is very grateful to Emprender and Kiva for the confidence placed in him in granting the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying tires and servicing his vehicle

loans.name: Good To Good Group

texts.en:
Here are members of the Good To Good Group from Magburaka, a town in Northern Sierra Leone. They have applied for a loan of 500,000 leones each in order to expand their businesses.

37-year-old Hawa T.K. B. is the leader of this group. Born in Magburaka town, Hawa is married to a farmer and they have four children. Three of her children are attending secondary school and one is in primary school. For over 15 years now, Hawa has been selling food at the Magburaka town market. Hawa will use this loan to buy margi (used to give sauce a sweet taste) and groundnuts (peanuts) wholesale to add to her business.

loans.use: To buy margi and groundnuts

loans.name: Love Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the Love Group from Magburaka, a town in Northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of 500,000 leones each from SMT/Kiva lenders. With the help of this loan, they can improve their businesses both in terms of size and quality.

The leader of this group is Mohamed Y. T.. Mohamed is a 39-year-old man who was born in Magburaka town. He is married and has three children who are attending primary school. For seven years now, Mohamed has been selling rice. With his share of this loan, he will buy bags of rice to add to his current stock.

loans.use: To buy bags of rice

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more charcoal

loans.name: Action Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the Action Group from Magburaka, a town in Northern Sierra Leone. They are small-scale businesspeople who have applied for a loan of 500,000 leones each from SMT/Kiva lenders. With the help of this loan, they can buy more goods to add to their businesses and make more sales and profit. Consequently, these entrepreneurs will be able to improve their living conditions including paying school fees for their children and feeding and clothing them.

The leader of the group is Alie K.. Alie is 50 years old. He was born in Kambia, in Northern Sierra Leone. He is married and has four children. Two of his children are attending secondary school and two are in primary school. Alie is a welder. He has been in this profession for many years now. He will use his share of the loan to buy working materials like rods, etc.

loans.use: Buy working materials like rods

loans.name: Adenike

texts.en:
Adenike is 42 years old, married and has four children. She sells adult clothes for both men and women. She has been in this business for over 10 years. Her initial business comprised selling foodstuff. Adenike wants to stock up clothes in her shop to avoid going to the market often.

Adenike is asking for a loan of NGN 100,000 to buy more clothes to sell and increase her profits. In this way, she can support her husband and family financially. She and her family lives in the Lagos state. She hopes to repay her loan on due date and appreciates all lenders for their assistance.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Friends United Group

texts.en:
These entrepreneurs named their group “Friends United”. They are small-scale businesswomen from Magburaka, a town in Northern Sierra Leone. They have applied for a loan of 500,000 leones each from SMT/Kiva lenders. With the help of this loan, they can improve their businesses, make more sales and consequently improving their standard of living. 

Kadiatu K., who is the leader of this group, is 29 years old. She was born in Magburaka town. She is married and has three children. Her husband is a professional worker and her children are attending primary school. For four years now, Kadiatu has been selling items such as toothpaste, sugar, pens, pencils, etc. With this loan, she will buy these items wholesale to add to her current stock.

loans.use: To buy toothpaste, sugar, pens, pencils, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more lappas and used clothes

loans.name: Epmcc Plus Group

texts.en:
EPMCC Plus is a group of 31 owners of small businesses chaired by Jean-Claude. Its members are jointly liable for loans granted by Kiva to grow their businesses.

Jean-Claude, single aged 37, operates a general store while taking care of one younger brother. He began his business in 1996. Jean-Claude has used five loans from Hope (a DRCongo Microfinance Program) to finance the expansion of his inventory. He intends to buy more goods for resale with the next loan to meet clients' demand and generate additional profits. This loan will help him achieve his plans to grow his business.

loans.use: Buy additional goods for his store for resale

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy products like drinks, soaps, candles, batteries, cream and tooth paste

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more drinks to serve customers.

loans.name: Hope Group

texts.en:
Seatta G., holding the sign, is the leader of the group of five borrowers called Hope. She is 43 years old, married, and has two children aged nine and 12. She could not continue her education through 6th grade because her parents did not value education. For five years, Seatta has sold food stuffs such as rice, oil, beef, and soft drinks at Rossville in Bomi County, Liberia. She has a good way with customers which keeps them returning. Seatta started by selling palm oil and her working capital was 1,000.00 Liberian Dollars. She plans to use her 5,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 25,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more rice, oil, seasonings, beef, and salt for sale. Her goal is to grow her business to a store and give her children higher education.

About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy more rice, oil, seasonings, beef, and salt for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more candles, soap, pomade and batteries to sell.

loans.name: Safu

texts.en:
Safu is 50 years old and married, with three children. She sells ground pepper to earn a living in Lagos state. She has been in this business for more than 15 years. Safu is determined to make sure that she meets her customers' demand, and to meet the needs of her family and home. 

Safu is asking for a loan of NGN 70,000 to buy pepper in bulk, as this will allow her to buy at a discount, increasing her profit.  She thanks Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase pepper in bulk to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more palm oil, pepper, seasonings, and soft drinks.

loans.name: God Is Good Group

texts.en:
Stanley G. is the leader of the group of five borrowers called God Is Good.  He is 24 years old and single, with no children. He was only able to attend school through 10th grade due to lack of support from parents.

For 3 years, Stanley has been selling phone recharge cards, phones and foreign exchange at the VOA Junction in Brewerville, Monrovia, Liberia. Stanley started selling with 155.00 Liberian dollars in working capital that he earned by selling rocks for construction. He offers customers with good rates which keeps them returning.

He plans to use his 7,000 Liberian dollar portion of this group loan to buy more recharge cards and phones and to accumulate money for foreign exchange. His goal is to own a factory and educate his children.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Stanley is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy more recharge cards and phones and accumulate money for foreign exchange.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more ampicillin capsules, paracetamol and folic acid for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more sugar, soft drinks, milk, soaps, and cream.

loans.name: Pascual  Epifanio

texts.es:
El Sr. Pascual se dedica al transporte Publico desde hace tres años,como socio activo hace diferente recorrido  cuenta con cuatro paradas de la zona norte al sud de la ciudad de Cochabamba el cliente es soltero pero con muchos deseos de formar una familia muy pronto, viven en alquiler  en un barrio peri urbano, ayuda  a su madre con los gastos de su casa y  a la vez a su hermana con el gasto de sus estudios. Es un cliente de bajos recursos economicos, por eso recurre a nuestra Institucion. Con el dinero del credito comprara un motor para su vehiculo y tambien herramientas de trabajo para el arreglo de su movilidad.
Esta muy agradecida con Emprender y Kiva por la confianza brindada en la otorgacion del credito.
texts.en:
Pascual has worked in public transportation for 3 years. He drives various routes; he has 4 stops from the northern part to the southern part of the city of Cochabamba. He is single but wants very much to start a family soon. He lives in a rental in a semi-urban area. He helps his mother with the household expenses, and at times he helps his sister with her educational expenses. He is a low income individual, and for this reason he came to our institution. With the money from the loan he will buy a motor for his vehicle, and also some tools for his work so that he can do some repairs on the vehicle. He is very grateful with Emprender and Kiva for the trust provided in granting this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy a motor for his vehicle, and tools for his work

loans.name: Memunt

texts.en:
Memunt, 46 years old, is a widow with four children, ages 9 to 20 years old. She sells yams to make sure she meets her family's financial needs. Memunt sells every day of the week except on Sundays. Her biggest priority is that she feed her family and make sure the children’s school fees are paid. As a widow, she does not have support from anyone; hence, she puts in her best to make sure she succeeds in her business.

Memunt wants to expand the size of her business by buying more yams to sell. She is asking for a loan of 170,000 nairas to purchase more yams to sell to her numerous customers. This will enable her to meet the demand of customers and also buy at a cheaper rate which will also increase her profit. She says thanks to Kiva and LAPO microfinance.

loans.use: To purchase more yams to sell

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam is a single mother of four boys and two girls, all of whom attend school.  She has been selling coconut and cassava seasonally for over ten years. She also has a farm which she uses to sustain herself and her family, and she owns her home, which does not have water or electricity.

Mariam’s son was in an accident, and she had to pay his medical costs with her previous loan. With this new 30,000 KES loan, Mariam wants to purchase premature coconuts from farmers, which she will then sell to food vendors and individuals. Her greatest challenge is carrying coconuts, and she cites food, school fees, and business capital as her greatest expenses. She hopes to someday open a shop to support herself and her family more comfortably.

loans.use: Coconuts

loans.name: Magdaline

texts.en:
Magdaline is a married woman with five daughters and one son, who is the oldest at the age of 24. Her daughters all attend school and her son has already finished his education.  She owns her home, which does not have electricity or piped water.  She is the breadwinner in the family.

Magdaline’s greatest monthly expenses are school fees and coconuts, which she has been selling for 19 years. To purchase coconuts, she visits her village, which is an hour away, once a week. She sells them outside, sometimes door-to-door. Her greatest challenge is transporting and at times obtaining coconuts, which can be scarce when the demand is high. As an additional source of income, Magdaline also buys and sells brooms to shops and passers-by.

With her 15,000 KES loan, Magdaline wants to buy more coconuts and pay for her children's school fees.  In the coming years, She hopes to become a wholesaler, improve her standard of living, and further educate her children.

loans.use: Coconuts

loans.name: Eustina

texts.en:
Eustina is a married mother of three boys and one girl, all of whom attend school.  She owns her home, which does not have water or electricity.  She cites her greatest monthly expenses as food, medical costs and school fees.

Eustina’s husband sells juice, and she sells coconuts and brooms.  She has been in this business for 10 years and sells wholesale and retail, at the market, door-to-door and from her home. Her customers are mainly hotel owners, food vendors and individuals.  The dry season is particularly challenging to her business as there are no coconuts. For additional income, Eustina has a shamba (farm) for after the coconuts have been harvested. 

With her 20,000 KES loan, Eustina wants to invest in the cultivation of coconuts and help pay her children's school fees.  Her goal is to start another project, perhaps a water business.

loans.use: Coconuts

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is a married woman with a boy, 10, and a girl, 4, who both attend school. She rents her home and cites school fees, electricity, water, and rent as her greatest expenses.  Her husband is a driver and she is a matatu (taxi van) operator.  She also owns two matatus of her own. 

Florence would like to open another business selling dry fish and mitumba (second-hand clothes) with her 80,000 KES loan.  She hopes to provide her children with a good education and with assets. She decided to join Yehu because she believes that it is a good microfinance institution that can help women who are low-income earners.

loans.use: Dry fish and second hand clothes

loans.name: Abidemi

texts.en:
Abidemi sews and sells cotton blinds, and also sells window blind materials. She has been in this trade for two years. She also has a shop where she sells frozen food items. She is requesting a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase window blinds in bulk from the factory, which she says will reduce transportation costs to the market and increase her profits.  She will be able to serve her clients better and take better care of her family.

Abidemi is 30years old, married and has a child. The family lives in Lagos state. Abidemi says thank you to all lenders.

loans.use: To purchase window blinds

loans.name: Olusade

texts.en:
Olusade has a grinding machine, which she uses to grind foodstuffs like beans, corn, tomatoes, peppers, etc. She also sells foodstuffs like garri, rice and yam flour. She buys in large quantities and sells to retailers. She is very hardworking since she has to leave home as early as 5am to be able to get goods to buy. She has been in this business for six years and with this, she helps her husband in providing for the family. She is requesting a loan of N50,000 to purchase foodstuffs in bulk at a discount to resell.

Olusade is 49 years old, married and has five children. She says thank you to KIVA lenders.

loans.use: To purchase foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Kehinde

texts.en: Kehinde has a shop where she sells groceries and fufu. She buys groceries in bulk and at retail. The fufu is a locally made food, which is derived from the fermentation of cassava and can be eaten with any soup of one's choice. She has been in this business since 1990. Kehinde is 50 years old, married and has three children who are between 32 and 25 years old. With a part of her profit and what the husband brings in, they are able to clothe, feed and take care of their rented apartment, as they are yet to put a finishing touch to their own place. Kehinde is requesting a loan of N50,000 to buy more provisions for sale. She says thank you and promises to repay promptly

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Modupe

texts.en: Modupe has a shop where she sells drinks and provisions. She buys in bulk and sells at retail. She buys goods directly from the company’s trailer, which goes around town supplying big buyers at a discount. She has been in this business since 1984. Modupe is 63 years old, married and has four children who are all in their own homes now. With part of her profit and what her husband, a driver, brings in, they are able to pay their bills. She further said they intend to renovate their building and also help other helpless people around. Modupe is requesting a loan of N50,000 to purchase more groceries and drinks to sell. She says thank you and promises to repay promptly.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and drinks to sell

loans.name: Melitona

texts.es: LA SRA. MELITONA VIVE EN LA LOCALIDAD DE EL TORNO, SU ACTIVIDAD ES LA VENTA Y PRODUCCION DE ESCOBA DE PAJA QUE SE REALIZA MANUALMENTE, TIENE SU PROPIO DOMICILIO YA QUE DESDE MUY JOVEN A TRABAJADO PARA SACAR A SU FAMILIA ADELANTE, ES MADRE SOLTERA YA QUE SE  SEPARADO CON SU ESPOSO, TIENE SOLAMENTE DOS HIJOS A SU CARGO YA QUE LOS DEMAS SON INDEPENDIENTES, Y LE AYUDAN ECONOMICAMENTE, CON EL DINERO DEL CREDITO COMPRARA MATERIALES PARA REALIZAR SUS PRODUCTOS Y ASI INCREMENTAR SU CAPITAL DE TRABAJO, ES CLIENTE ANTIGUA DE NUESTRA INSTITUCION, EL CUAL SE SIENTE AGRADECIDA CON EMPRENDER I KIVA POR LA CONFIANZA BRINDADA EN LA OTORGACION DEL CREDITO.
texts.en:
Sra. Melitona lives in the town of El Torno. She produces and sells straw brooms that she makes by hand. Melitona has her own home where she has worked since she was a very young woman in order for her family to get ahead. She is a single mother who is separated from her husband. Only two of her children are still under her care while the rest are independent and help her financially.

The proceeds of the loan will be used to purchase materials for making her products and increase her working capital. She is a long-time client of our institution. Melitona is grateful to Emprender and Kiva for their trust by providing her with this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase materials for making brooms
