loans.name: Corina

texts.es: La Sra. Corina, es una D. nuestras nuevas emprendedoras, que al igual que muchas mujeres buscan generar ingresos a través D. empleos informales como la compra D. artículos D. ferretería al por mayor del interior del país como Oruro, y la entrega a ferreterías al por mayor. Ella cuenta con 3 hijos, que se encuentran en edad escolar y uno próximo a bachiller,  vive actualmente en la casa D. sus padres, junto a sus hermanos. Ante el incremento del desempleo en nuestro país su esposo  tuvo que dejar su familia  e ir en busca D. trabajo, y mientras el señor trataba D. buscar empleo en España la señora se vio obligada a buscar  actividades que le permitan sostener a su familia, inicialmente su madre le permitió  colocar una tienda D. barrio en su domicilio con el fin D. apoyarla, sin embargo no fue suficiente, ya que las necesidades D. sus hijos crecían D. acuerdo a su edad, por lo cual tuvo que buscar nuevas opciones como a la distribución D. artículos D. ferretería. Ella tiene el sueño D. poder incrementar su capital con el fin D. generar mayor ingreso para poder abastecerse y tener una ferretería propia. Con el dinero del credito comprara mercaderia al por mayor y despues entregar a sus pedidos a sus clientes, esta muy agradecida con Emprender y Kiva por la confianza brindada en la otorgacion del credito.
texts.en:
Corina is one of our new enterprising women. Like many others, she needs to generate income through informal employment such as buying goods at wholesale prices from the markets in the country's interior in places such as Oruro, and reselling them at a profit. Corina has 3 children who attend school, one of whom will soon finish secondary school. Right now, they are living in the home of Corina's parents. With the increase in unemployment in the country, Corina's husband had to leave the family to look for work. While he looked for work in Spain, Corina realized it was her obligation to look for work that could help sustain the family. In the beginning, her mother allowed her to locate a small shop in her house, but this wasn't sufficient to generate the income needed. Corina needed to find new opportunities such as her wholesale business. Corina dreams of being able to increase her income so that she can open her own market. With the loan, she will purchase merchandise at wholesale prices and then resell it to her customers. Corina is grateful to the organization Emprender, and to Kiva, for the confidence they give to her in granting this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Charnes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase more merchandise to help grow her business.

loans.name: Luis Alberto

texts.es: EL SR. LUIS ALBERTO, VIVE EN LA LOCALIDAD DE LA ENCONANDA DISTANTE A 5 KM DE LA CONUNIDAD DE COTOCA Y COTOCA SE ENCUENTRA DISTANTE  A 20 KM DE SANTA CRUZ, AL ESTE DEL DEPARTAMENTO, SU ACTIVIDAD PRINCIPAL ES EL SERVICO DE TRANSPORTE DE PASAJEROS EN LA LINEA 24 DE SEPTIEMBRE EN LA LOCALIADAD DE EL TORNO, ES SOLTERO CON UNA RELACION SERIA CON SU PAREJA, YA QUE PIENSA EN CASARSE EL AÑO ENTRANTE, POR TAL MOTIVO SE ESTA PREPARANDO PARA DICHO ACONTECIMIENTO, EL DESTINO DEL CREDITO SOLICITADO ES PARA EL MANTENIMIENTO DE SU VEHICULO, YA QUE SE ENCONTRABA EN MAL ESTADO PARA REALIZAR EL SERVICO DE TRANSPORTE DE PASAJEROS Y DESEA HACER ARREGLAR SU VEHICULO Y ASI PODER BRINDAR MEJOR SERVICIO A SUS CLIENTES. ESTA AGRADECIDO CON EMPRENDER Y KIVA POR LA CONFIANZA BRINDADA EN LA OTORGACION DEL CREDITO.
texts.en:
Luis Alberto lives in La Escondida, which is 5km from Cotoca, which in turn is 20 km from Santa Cruz, in the east of the department. His main commercial activity is passenger transportation in the 14 de Septiembre route in El Torno. He is single but in a committed relationship with his partner, whom he plans to marry next year. He is, therefore, preparing for this event and will use the funds to service his vehicle because it needs repairs and is not in optimal state to provide transportation services to passengers. He wants to repair the vehicle so that he can provide good service. He is grateful to Emprender and to Kiva for the trust placed in him by granting the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For vehicle maintenance and repair.

loans.name: Rene

texts.es:
EL SR. RENE VIVE EN LA LOCALIDAD DE EL TORNO A DISTANTE 40 KM DE LA CIUDAD DE SANTA CRUZ, TIENE 3 HIJOS CON SU SEÑORA ESPOSA, SU PROFESION ES MECANICO, EL DESTINO DEL CREDITO FUE PARA AUMENTAR UN ANTICRETICO, EL CUAL ESTA AHORANDO PARA PODER CONSTRUIR SU CASA; TRABAJA COMO MECANICO HACE 2 AÑO, COMENZO COMO AYUDANTE, HOY EN DIA YA TIENE SU PROPIO TALLER DE CAMBIO DE ACEITE PARA VEHICULOS, SU ESPOSA SE DEDICA A LAS LABORES DEL HOGAR Y  A  LA EDUCACION DE SUS HIJOS.
SE SIENTE AGRADECIDO CON LA INSTITUCION POR DARLE LA OPORTUNIDAD PARA TRABAJAR Y SEGUIR CRECIENDO ECONOMICAMENTE.
texts.en:
Rene lives in El Torno, 40 km from Santa Cruz. He and his wife have three children. He has been a mechanic for the last two years; he began as an assistant and now has his own shop where he provides vehicle oil changes. His wife is in charge of household chores and the education of their children. He will use the funds to increase his anticretico (Anticretico is a transaction not available in the U.S. whereby a property owner requests a "loan" from you in exchange for housing, which must be paid back to you at the end of your contract); he is saving up to build his house. He is grateful to the institution for giving him the opportunity to work and continue to improve financially.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: House Anticretico (Anticretico is a transaction not available in the U.S. whereby a property owner requests a "loan" from you in exchange for housing, which must be paid back to you at the end of your contract).

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita A. is a 48-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating a general store. She lives in Pta Salong Manapla, Negros Occidental with her husband and their five children who are between 7 and 27 years old. Three of the children are already working and two currently go to school.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon and has improved her family's living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 15,000.

Nenita is now borrowing PHP 17,000 so she can sustain and expand her general store business. This will be her 14th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Nenita aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Rosie

texts.en:
Rosie B. is a 33-year-old married woman who supports her family by engaging in pig fattening and general store businesses. She lives in Pta. Salong Manapla, Negros Occidental with her husband and their two children who are 8 and 10 years old.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2001 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her pig fattening business as well as her general store, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 25,000.

Rosie is now borrowing PHP 21,500 so that she can expand her pig fattening and general store. This will be her 13th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 21,500, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Rosie aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the “Dungganon” way.

Jona is now borrowing PHP 24,500 so that she can expand her pig fattening business and her general store. This will be her 16th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Gloria M. is a married woman who supports her family by running a general store. She lives in Balo Barangay Aguisan Himamaylan City, Negros Occidental with her husband and their 3 children who are between 15 and 20 years of age, all in school.

At 48, she has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2005 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store business, she is gradually making her family M. economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 12,000.

Gloria is now borrowing PHP 16,000 to be used as additional working capital for her general store. This will be her 8th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 14,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Gloria aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and to ensure their future well being by following the “Dungganon” way.

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet P. is a 27-year old married woman who lives in Canlinday Barangay, Culipapa Sipalay City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by engaging in a fishing and fish-vending business.

Juliet’s husband, Roldan, works as a fisherman and they have 5 young children, aged between 8 months & 7 years. The couple work hard to sustain the needs of their family, especially in preparation for the future well-being of their children. 

Juliet joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 in the hopes that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in fishing and fish-vending business. Now she earns an average monthly income of PHP 15,000 from her business activities.

Juliet is a member in good standing. Her previous loan of PHP 19,500 was used to fund operations of her fishing and fish-vending business, and it had a positive impact on both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing, for her 7th cycle loan, the amount of PHP 19,500, which she intends to use on her existing fishing and fish-vending business. Juliet is working hard to achieve the dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:

Ma. Elena is now borrowing PHP 25,000 so that she can access additional capital for her fish vending business. This will be her 7th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Elena aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and to ensure their future well being by following the “Dungganon” way.

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites E. is a 38-year old married woman who lives in Barangay Culipapa Hinobaan, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by fishing and fish vending.

Marites’s husband, Vito, is a fisherman, and they have 6 children who are between 3 mos and 20 years old. 5 of her children are currently going to school and also help their parents in the business as part of their daily chores.

Marites joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in fishing and fish vending. Now she earns an average monthly income of PHP 10,000 from her business activities.

Marites is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000 was used to fund operations of her fish vending and fishing businesses, and it had a positive impact on both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing, for her 16th cycle loan, the amount of PHP 15,000, which she intends to use on her business activities. Marites is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

Jessie is now borrowing PHP 15,000 so that she can have additional working capital for her cosmetic sales business. This will be her 14th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 17,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Jessie aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and to ensure their future well being by following the “Dungganon” way.

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita Q. is a 55 year-old woman living in the town of Bulanon, Brgy. Rafaela Barerra.  She is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Nenita owns & operates a sari sari store selling a variety of different products in the local community. Nenita has been engaged in this business for over 32 years and earns approximately PHP10000 a month from these activities.

In 2001, Nenita joined NWTF to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Nenita has successfully repaid a previous loan of PHP29500  from NWTF. Nenita is now requesting a new loan of PHP29500, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 20th loan taken out by Nenita from NWTF. Nenita plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business  to pay the tuition fees of her children.

She earns her living by running a general store.Mary Joey and her husband work hard to prepare for the future of their family, especially when they have children because they want to provide for a good future for the children.

Mary Joey joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life for their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in a general store business. Mary Joey is a member in good standing. loans.name: Mrs. Thach Soy Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Thach S. de-husks rice to sell in the local market and village. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it. In order to improve conditions for her family, Mrs. Thach S. decided to ask for a loan to buy more rice for milling to sell. Her husband is a farmer who owns 1 hectare of land to cultivate rice for a living. Through this activity, they support a child who has just enrolled in the local public school.

This village bank loan is for 15 people who live in Trapeang Lean village in Takeo province. Mrs. Thach S. is the village bank president who has been selected by all the members. They all use their loan to do something that supports their purposes.

loans.use: To buy more rice for milling to sell

loans.name: Basilia

texts.fr: Née en 1967 à Allada dans le département de l’Atlantique, G. Basilia vit depuis environs 22 ans à Agla, un quartier de Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à VIGNIGBE Sévérin, un chauffeur, Basilia est mère de quatre enfants tous scolarisés. Le couple vit ensemble avec ses enfants. Basilia est secondée par son mari pour assurer les dépenses familiales. En effet, pour contribuer à la scolarisation de ses enfants, Basilia exerce comme activité, la vente de maïs, soja et mil dans sa boutique située non loin de son domicile. Basilia effectue ses achats au marché de Bembèrèkè, dans le nord du Bénin. Basilia n’a pas fréquenté l’école mais exerce depuis fort longtemps son activité. Basilia a déjà bénéficié d’un crédit auprès de ALIDé, crédit qu’elle a bien remboursé. Dans le but de renforcer son activité afin d’accroître ses revenus pour s’acquérir une parcelle, Basilia sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born in 1967 in Allada in Benin's Atlantique department, Basilia G. has spent the last 22 years living in Agla, a district of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Basilia is married to Sévérin Vignigbe, a chauffeur, and she has four children, all of whom attend school. The couple live together with their children. Basilia's husband helps her out with the family expenses. To contribute towards her children's school fees, Basilia sells corn, soya beans and millet in a store near her home. She buys her goods in the market at Bembèrèkè in the north of Benin. Basilia did not attend school, but has been conducting her business activity for a long time. She has already had one loan from ALIDé, which she has fully repaid. Basilia is now requesting a second loan from ALIDé with the intention of strengthening her business in order to increase her revenue and buy a plot of land.

Translated from French by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy corn, soya beans and millet.

loans.name: Mrs. Nhanh Sorn Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This group consists of fourteen people who live in live in Trapeang Lean village in Takeo province. Mrs. Nhanh S. has been selected by the others as the president of their village bank. They each will use this loan in different ways that support their business to improve their living conditions. Mrs. Nhanh S. is a farmer who owns a plot of land to grow rice for supporting her family living. She works hard in her field, but does not earn very much income this way. She wanted to start a new business, but did not have enough money to do it. As a result, Mrs. Nhanh S. decided to seek for a loan to buy some piglets for breeding.
Mrs. Nhanh S.'s husband is a construction worker. She is a mother of five children, one of whom is a seamstress in a garment factory, while the others attend a local public school.

loans.use: To buy some piglets for breeding

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mrs. Roeurn Seng Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan is for nineteen people, who live in Trapeang Thum village in the TaK. province. Mrs. Roeurn S. has been selected by the other members as the village bank president. Each member will use their loan for a different purpose. Mrs. Roeurn S. is a farmer who owns a small piece of land, where she cultivates rice to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Hi Ang, is a duck breeder who earns some money selling ducks and eggs. Her family encountered an obstacle because the ducks are too small to sell, but she did not have enough money to feed them more. So, Mrs. Roeurn S. decided to request for a loan to buy duck food.

She is a mother of three children, one of whom owns a computer to copy songs into ringtones, and the others are studying in local public school. All the members are shown in the photo, although one of them is hidden behind another.

loans.use: To buy duck food

loans.name: Mrs. Huon Sek Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan is for thirteen people I. the Trapeang Thum village I. Takeo province. Mrs. Huon S. is the village bank president, who has been selected by all the members. They will each use the loan I. pursuit of a different goal that will improve their living conditions. Mrs. Huon S. is a dessert seller, and is also a farmer who owns a plot of land to grow rice to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Bou Ren Pech, is a taxi driver who owns an old car. They have a problem, however, because their wheels are too old to use. I. order to improve their family's living conditions, Mrs. Huon S. decided to ask for a loan to buy new wheels to replace the old ones. She is a mother of three children who are attending the local public school.

loans.use: To buy new wheels

loans.name: Kochkorova Burulkan`s Group

texts.ru:
Бурулкан, 59, замужем. Ее супруг работает в местной шахте угольным шахтером. Она мать 3 детей, старшие двое разнополые близнецы. Она занимается производством национального напитка Бозо. Клиент хочет закупить материалы для производства национальных одеял - Тушаков.

Басбубу 51 лет. Она замужем, ее супруг давно уже не работает - он пенсионер. У нее один взрослый сын, который работает в России. Клиент занимается перепродажей  риса в Кадамжае. Этим бизнесом она занимается на протяжении 10 лет. Кредит будет использован для закупа гарнитура.

Чынаре 30 лет. У нее 1 дочь, которая учится на втором классе. Клиент предоставляет услуги общественного питания с арендованного кафе. Кредит будет использован для закупов соков и напитков.

Искендеру 27 лет. Она не женат  и проживает вместе с родителями. Он является солистом местной музыкальной группы. Музыке он учился у своего дяди, который также был музыкантом. Кредит нужен для закупа музыкальных инструментов. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Burulkan is fifty-nine years old, married and a mother of three children, the eldest of whom are twins. Her husband works as a miner at a local coal mine. She makes a national drink called Bozo. She also wants to buy materials to create national blankets – Tushaki's. Basbubu is fifty-one years old. Her husband has not worked for a long time; he is retired. She has one son, who works in Russia. She resells rice in Kadamzhay, a business in which she has been involved for more than ten years. The loan will be use to buy garnitures. Chynare is thirty years. She has one daughter, who goes to second grade. She rents a café where she serves food and drinks. She will use the loan to buy juices and drinks. Iskender is twenty-seven years old. He isn’t married and lives with his parents. He is a soloist for a local music group. He learned music from his uncle, who also was a musician. The loan will be used to buy musical instruments.

Translated from Russian by Alex Kostrubsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sewing materials

loans.name: Mrs. Vanna Sou Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Vanna S. is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to grow rice, not for selling, but to support her family. Her husband is a construction worker. Since her husband’s business is going well, they want to improve it. Thus, Mrs. Vanna S. decided to seek a loan to buy some construction supplies. She is the mother of six children who are enrolled in the local public school.

Mrs. Vanna S. is the village bank president who has been selected by all the members. Nineteen people who live in Kandoeng Thum village in Takeo province make up this village bank. They will use their loan for different purposes.

loans.use: To buy some construction supplies

loans.name: Mrs. Sam Art Soy Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village loan consists of twenty people who live in Kandoeng Thum village in Takeo province. Mrs. S. Art S. is the village bank president selected by all the members, who will use the loan for different purposes.

Mrs. Vanna Sou is a farmer who owns a very small piece of land to grow rice to feed her family. She has a lot of free time, S. she wants to start a new business, but does not have enough money. Thus, Mrs. Vanna Sou decided to apply for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. Her husband is a teacher in the local school. She is the mother of four children, three of whom are enrolled in the local public school, while the fourth is too young to study or work.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding

loans.name: Mrs. Saroem Nhor Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan, which consists of nineteen members, is located in Kandoeng ThU. village in Takeo province. All the members plan to use their loans for different purposes.

Mrs. Saroem N. is the village bank president who has been selected by the other members. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to grow rice to feed her family. Her husband is a dessert seller. Although they work hard at their careers, they still earn little income. They want to start a new business, but they don't have enough money. Thus, Mrs. Saroem N. decided to apply for a loan to buy some piglets, pig food for breeding pigs, and dessert for resale. She is the mother of five children: one attends the local public school, while the others are seamstresses in a garment factory.

loans.use: To buy some piglets and pig food for breeding

loans.name: Mr. Ben Chi Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan, which consists of ten members, is located in Prey Run village in Takeo province. Mr. Ben C. is the village bank president selected by the other members, who all plan to use their loans for different purposes.

Mr. Ben C. is a farmer who owns 2 hectares of land to cultivate rice to support his family. His wife is a wine and gasoline seller in the local village. He is the father of three children, two of whom are teachers, while the third attends the local public school. Mr. Ben C. is facing some obstacles because his rice field is infertile but he does not have enough money to improve it. Thus, Mr. Ben C. decided to request a loan to buy fertilizer. He would use the rest of the loan to start a new business and buy three piglets for breeding . Mr. Ben C. is busy with his rice field so his wife came instead of him to take out the loan .

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Mrs. Pruch Sang Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan consists of fourteen people who live in Prey Run village in Takeo province. All the members plan to use their loans for different purposes. Mrs. Pruch S. is the village bank president selected by all the members. She is a farmer who owns 1-hectare of land to cultivate rice to support her family. Her husband is a battery charger in the local village. She is the mother of two children, one of whom helps with the farming while the other attends the local public school. Although they work hard, the family earns little income. So they want to start a new business, but do not have enough money. Thus, Mrs. Pruch S. decided to ask for a loan to buy some piglets and pig food for breeding pigs. Mrs. Pruch S. is busy with her rice field so her husband came instead of her to take out the loan.

loans.use: To buy some piglets and pig food for breeding pigs

loans.name: Mame Saye

texts.fr: Madame Mame Saye D. vend des produits cosmétiques. En fait, tout à commencer, il y’a 7 ans grâce à l’influence de sa demi-sœur vendeuse de parfums à Dakar. Cette dernière gênée par l’oisiveté de sa sœur, lui offert  à cette époque des marchandises pour qu’elle les commercialise à Bambey  leur ville natale située à 120 Kms de Dakar. Et depuis ce jour là, Madame Mame Saye n’a cessé de mettre de l’avant son business. C’est ainsi, qu’elle vienne solliciter un prêt pour renforcer son business.
texts.en:
Mrs. Mame Saye D. sells cosmetic products. In fact, everything started 7 years ago thanks to the influence of her half sister, a perfume seller in Dakar. Bothered by her sister's idleness she offered her, at that time, goods to take to market in Bambey; their birth place located 120 km from Dakar. Since that, day Mrs Mame Saye has never ceased to put her business first. It's for the reason that she comes to seek a loan to strengthen her business.

Translated from French by Colleen Creegan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of purfumes and lotions

loans.name: Mrs. So Phat Vong Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan consists of fourteen people who live in Sdok village in Takeo province. Mrs. So Phat V. is the village bank president selected by all the members, who will use the loan for different purposes. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice to support her family. She is also a pig breeder. Her husband, Mr. Art Chhe, is a motorbike taxi driver. This family has a problem because their house is too dark. Thus, Mrs. So Phat V. decided to ask for a loan to buy some electrical supplies. She is the mother of six children: two are seamstresses in a garment factory, three attend the local public school, and one is too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy some electrical supplies

loans.name: Birashoboka Group

texts.fr:
Dancile B. a 36 ans. Elle est mariee et mere de 6 enfants dont quatre filles.  L’ainee est age de 13 ans et etudie en 6e primaire et le cadet a 11 mois. Dancile espere que ses enfants finiront leurs etudes avec succes et qu'ils seront des leaders. Elle a tant fait pour eux qu’elle souhaite se promener en ville un jour dans le vehicule de ses enfants et conduite comme une reine.

Dans sa vie quotidienne, elle bute aux defis lies aux depenses de ration, des frais scolaires  et  des medicaments pour soigner ses yeux.  L'argent qu'elle gagne satisfait ses besoins grace au business qu'elle a commence en 2000.  

Depuis lors, Dancile est proprietaire d’une kioske a Gihosha ou elle vend des produits alimentaires et divers.  Parmi eux, les plus lucratifs sont le haricot, l’huile de palme, et le sucre.  Elle cultive aussi des haricots, mais, patates douces et du manioc.  Elle va utiliser ce credit pour acheter des produits destines a son commerce.
texts.en:
Dancile B. is 36. She is married and the mother of 6 children of whom four are girls. The oldest girl is 13 and studies in 7th grade. The youngest is a boy of 11 months. Dancile hopes that her children will finish their studies successfully and that they will be leaders. She has done so much for them so she hopes one day to be driven around town in their car and treated like a queen. In her everyday life, she runs up against challenges relative to feeding the family, paying school fees, and paying for medicine for her eyes. The money she earns is enough to support them thanks to the business she began in the year 2000. Since then, Dancile has been the owner of a kiosk in Gihosha where she sells groceries and various other items. The most lucrative are dried beans, palm oil, and sugar. She also grows beans, maize, sweet potatoes, and manioc. She will use the loan to buy products to sell in her little store.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchasing groceries to sell in her little store

loans.name: Awa

texts.fr: Madame Awa B. âgée de 44 ans est une femme mariée et mère de 3 enfants. Elle s’est investie dans le commerce depuis 10 ans. Elle vend principalement des produits alimentaires et trouve  toujours un extrême plaisir dans la vente. Ainsi, elle vient solliciter un prêt de 150 000 FCFA pour s’approvisionner en marchandises. Elle compte, avec ce crédit, acheter de l’huile de palme, pâte d’arachide, poissons séchés ….
texts.en:
Ms. Awa B., aged 44, is a married woman and the mother of three children. She has been investing her time in commerce for ten years. She mainly sells food items and finds extreme pleasure in making the sale. And so, she has come to request a loan of 150,000 francs CFA for stocking up on merchandise. She intends to use this loan to buy palm oil, peanut butter, dried fish…

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Resupplying herself with various food items

loans.name: Mrs. Chheng Hong Village Bank Group

texts.en:
These fourteen people are villagers in Doung village in Takeo province and all make up a village bank loan. Mrs. Chheng H. is the village bank president who has been selected by all the members.  They will each use their loan for different purposes.

Mrs. Chheng H. is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice for supporting her family and on the side she is a weaver in the local village. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it, so Mrs. Chheng H. decided to seek a loan to buy more silk for weaving. She is a widow with a child who is enrolled in the local public school.

loans.use: To buy more silk for weaving.

loans.name: Srey's Group

texts.en:
This group loan has five people who are villagers in Pou Bay village in Takeo province. Mrs. Srey S. is the group leader who has been selected by the other four members.  They will all use their loan for different purposes.

Mrs. Srey S. is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice for supporting her family and on the side she is also a pig breeder.  Her husband, Mr. Hieng Phrom, is a construction worker.

Although they try to work hard, they earn little income, so Mrs. Srey S. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding to start a new business. She is the mother of a child who is enrolled in the local public school.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding to start a new business

loans.name: Femmes Commerçantes N°14 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupement  Femmes Commerçantes (F.C) comme son nom l’indique est un réseau de femmes qui s’activent  dans le commerce.  Il est basé à Grand Thiès et il a été créé depuis 1992 par Madame Maty Niakh l’actuel président du réseau. Cette présidente a eu cette idée  à l’issue d’une formation qu’elle avait bénéficiée  de l’ONG OXFAM à Thiès. Elle connait, ainsi, bien la gestion de groupe, entreprenariat …etc.  Les membres du réseau sont extrêmement dévoués et se rencontrent une fois par mois. Ainsi, après des frais d’adhésion au groupement, chaque membre est tenu de cotiser mensuellement 200 FCFA pour une caisse de solidarité.
Souhaitant se financer, elles décidèrent  d’adhérer à  U-IMCEC. C’est ainsi que,  leur réseau se voit scinder en 19 sous groupes de 5 personnes  pour un meilleur profit des financements. Elles sollicitent pour une deuxième fois un prêt de 100 000 FCFA par membre,  soit 500 000 FCFA par sous groupe afin de développer leurs diverses activités.
Cependant, les règlements sont versés à la présidente assistée par la trésorière du groupe, Madame Coumba Seck, pendant leurs réunions mensuelles et ces deux se chargent à leur tour de rembourser U-IMCEC. Ce réseau qui, dit la présidente, n’a qu’un seul et noble objectif : combattre la pauvreté dans les ménages. Actuellement, le réseau compte 19 sous groupes avec chacun une présidente et une trésorière.
Ainsi, le sous groupe Femme Commerçantes N°14 est composée de 5 femmes qui habitent dans un même quartier Cité Lamy de Thiès. Il est dirigé par Madame Coumba N., une femme âgée de 41 ans. Elle est, en effet, vendeuse de produits de mer (poissons séchés, poissons fumés, crustacés…) depuis 9 ans. Mère de six enfants, Madame Coumba N. entend comme ses collègues, s’approvisionner en marchandises avec sa part du crédit. Ses collègues sont entre autre Madame Coumba Aïcha S. vendeuse d’habits pour enfants depuis 5 ans, Madame Sokhna N.  qui gère sa propre table de légumes chez elle, Madame Diaretou B. commerçante ambulante d’habits unisex et Madame Fatou N.  trésorière du sous groupe et vendeuse de mil, pain de singe et bissap (oseille)
texts.en:
The group “Femmes Commerçantes” (F.C.), as its name indicates, is a network of women who are active in commerce. It is based in Grand Thiès and was founded in 1992 by Ms. Maty Niakh, the network’s current president. She got the idea of forming the network after participating in a training session run by the NGO OXFAM in Thiès. She is therefore quite knowledgeable about group management, entrepreneurship, etc. The network members are extremely devoted and meet once a month.  Beyond a membership fee, each member must pay 200 francs CFA monthly into a solidarity fund. Desiring financing, they decided to join U-IMCEC. This is why their network was split into nineteen sub-groups of five persons each to ensure a better profit outcome. For the second time, they are requesting a loan of 100,000 francs per member, that is 500,000 francs per sub-group, to develop their various businesses. However, payments are made at the monthly meetings to the group president, assisted by the group treasurer, Ms. Coumba Seck, who are then responsible for reimbursing U-IMCEC. In the words of its president, the network has only one single, noble objective: to fight family poverty. The network currently numbers nineteen sub-groups, each with its own president and treasurer. Desiring financing, they decided to join U-IMCEC. This is why their network was split into nineteen sub-groups of five persons each to ensure a better profit outcome. For the second time, they are requesting a loan of 100,000 francs per member, that is 500,000 francs per sub-group, to develop their various businesses. However, payments are made at the monthly meetings to the group president, assisted by the group treasurer, Ms. Coumba Seck, who are then responsible for reimbursing U-IMCEC. In the words of its president, the network has only one single, noble objective: to fight family poverty. The network currently numbers nineteen sub-groups, each with its own president and treasurer. Thus, the sub-group Femme Commerçantes N°14 is composed of five women who live in the same district, Cité Lamy of Thiès.  The group is headed by Ms. Coumba N., a 41-year-old woman.  She has in fact been a vendor of seafood products (dried fish, smoked fish, shellfish...) for nine years.  The mother of six children, she intends, as her colleagues are doing, to supply herself with merchandise with her share of the loan.  Her colleagues include Ms. Coumba Aïcha S., a vendor of children's clothing for five years; Ms. Sokhna N., who has her own table of vegetables at her home; Ms. Diaretou B., an itinerant merchant selling unisex clothing; and Ms. Fatou N., the treasurer of the group and a vendor of millet, monkey bread (the fruit of the baobab tree) and bissap (dried hibiscus flowers). 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Supplies of merchandise

loans.name: Oeun's Group

texts.en:
The five people who make up this group loan all live in Srae Boeng village in Takeo province. Mrs. Oeun D. is the group leader who has been selected by all the members.  They will all use their loan for different purposes.

Mrs. Oeun D. is a farmer who owns 3.5 hectares of land to grow rice for supporting her family and on the side she is also a pig breeder. Since her pig breeding is going well, she wants to expand it but she did not have enough money. Mrs. Oeun D. decided to request a loan to buy more piglets for breeding.

She a widow with two children, one of whom is enrolled in the local public school and the other is four years old.

loans.use: To buy more piglets for breeding.

loans.name: Mrs. Sruon Srey Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan consists of ten people who live in Pring village in Takeo province. All the members plan to use their loans for different purposes. Mrs. Sruon S. is the village bank president selected by all the members. She and her husband, Mr. Sochy Or, are farmers who own 0.5-hectare of land to grow rice to support their family. They have a problem because their field is ready to be harvested but they do not have enough money to do so. Thus, Mrs. Sruon S. decided to apply for a loan to hire farm laborers to harvest the rice. She wants to use the rest of the loan to start a new business and buy some piglets to breed. She is the mother of four children, three of whom attend the local public school, while the youngest is five years old.

loans.use: To hire farm laborers for harvesting rice

loans.name: Femmes Commerçantes N°13 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupement  Femmes Commerçantes (F.C) comme son nom l’indique est un réseau de femmes qui s’activent  dans le commerce.  Il est basé à Grand Thiès et il a été créé depuis 1992 par Madame Maty Niakh l’actuel président du réseau. Cette présidente a eu cette idée  à l’issue d’une formation qu’elle avait bénéficiée  de l’ONG OXFAM à Thiès. Elle connait, ainsi, bien la gestion de groupe, entreprenariat …etc.  Les membres du réseau sont extrêmement dévoués et se rencontrent une fois par mois. Ainsi, après des frais d’adhésion au groupement, chaque membre est tenu de cotiser mensuellement 200 FCFA pour une caisse de solidarité.
Souhaitant se financer, elles décidèrent  d’adhérer à  U-IMCEC. C’est ainsi que,  leur réseau se voit scinder en 19 sous groupes de 5 personnes  pour un meilleur profit des financements. Elles sollicitent pour une deuxième fois un prêt de 100 000 FCFA par membre,  soit 500 000 FCFA par sous groupe afin de développer leurs diverses activités.
Cependant, les règlements sont versés à la présidente assistée par la trésorière du groupe, Madame Coumba Seck, pendant leurs réunions mensuelles et ces deux se chargent à leur tour de rembourser U-IMCEC. Ce réseau qui, dit la présidente, n’a qu’un seul et noble objectif : combattre la pauvreté dans les ménages. Actuellement, le réseau compte 19 sous groupes avec chacun une présidente et une trésorière.
Le sous groupe Femmes Commerçantes N°13 est dirigé par Madame Khady N.. Elle commerce du maïs, riz et du gombo. Mère de 8 enfants, Madame Khady N. partage ce sous groupe avec Madame Néné D. vendeuses de poissons frais, Madame Fatou N.  vendeuse de poissons séchés, Madame Fatou Y. qui vend des légumes, Omo et Madame Ndeye F. vendeuse de fruits et d’arachide.
texts.en:
As its name suggests, the Femmes Commerçantes group (F.C.) is a network of businesswomen. It is based at Grand Thiès and was created in 1992 by Ms. Maty Niakh, its current president. She got the idea of forming the network after receiving training from the NGO OXFAM at Thiès. Thus she is knowledgeable about group management, running a business, etc. The members of the group are dedicated to what they do, and meet together once a month. Over and above membership dues, each of them pays 200 FCFA a month into a collective fund. Seeking financing, they decided to join U-IMCEC. The network is divided into 19 subgroups of five people to take better advantage of funding. Each subgroup has its own president and treasurer. They now seek, for the second time, a loan of 100,000 FCFA per member or 500,000 FCFA for each subgroup, to grow their various business activities. The members repay their loans to the president and the treasurer, Mrs. Coumba Seck, during their monthly meetings. These two, in turn, are responsible for repaying U-IMCEC. According to the president, the group has only one noble goal -- to fight family poverty. The sub-group Femmes Commerçantes N°13 is led by Ms. Khady N.. She sells corn, rice, and okra. Mother of eight children, she belongs to this sub-group which includes Ms. Néné D., who sells fresh fish; Ms. Fatou N., who sells dried fish; Ms. Fatou Y., who sells vegetables; and Ms. Ndeye F., who sells fruit and peanuts.

Translated from French by Robin Clochard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Develop their respective businesses

loans.name: Abdoulaye

texts.fr: Monsieur Abdoulaye D. âgé de 29 ans est  agent de sécurité et ne travaille que 10 jours dans le mois. Ainsi pour combattre l’oisiveté, Monsieur D. décida en 2005 de s’investir dans le commerce. Ainsi, il s’est lancé dans la vente de téléphones portables comme celui qu'il a sur sa photo. D’ailleurs ce sont des produits qu’il place à sa clientèle jusqu’à la fin du mois. Cependant, cet ancien militaire pense que ce crédit va lui permettre de s’activer pendant ses jours de repos.
texts.en:
Mr. Abdoulaye D., 29, is a security guard and only works ten days each month. In order to avoid being idle, Mr. D. decided in 2005 to get involved in business. Thus, he began selling cell phones such as the one seen in the photo. In fact, these are the last products he will provide his customers until the end of the month. However, this military veteran believes that this loan will allow him to stay busy on his days off.

Translated from French by Robin Clochard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of stock for his business

loans.name: Mr. Lai Boeng Village Bank Group

texts.en: FifteE. people who live in Pring village in Takeo province constitute this village bank loan. Mr. Lai B. is a village bank president who has beE. selected by all the members. They will use the loan for different purposes. He owns a threshing machine that can earn some money for supporting his family, and his wife, Mrs. Lai YE., is a farmer who owns 1.5-hectares of land to grow rice for supporting her family. They have a problem because the rice field is ready to harvest, but they do not have enough money to do it. Thus, Mr. Lai B. decided to seek a loan to hire farm laborers for harvesting his rice. He is the father of four childrE. who all are employed in different positions.

loans.use: To hire farm laborers for harvesting rice

loans.name: Mame Bousso

texts.fr:
Madame Mame Bousso D. âgée de 39 ans est mariée mère de 3 enfants. Elle couturière et teinturière de formation.  Cependant depuis 2007, elle s’est versée dans le commerce de bois de chauffage. C’est son mari qui lui a poussé à vendre le bois. En effet, son mari un chauffeur de camion qui sillonne presque toute la sous région lui achète à bon prix du bois de la Casamance tout en respectant les règles établies par les Eaux et Forêts. 
Ainsi, elle sollicite un prêt de 200 000 FCFA pour se réapprovisionner en bois de Casamance afin de développer son commerce et de satisfaire ses clients.
texts.en:
Ms. Mame Bousso D., 39, is the married mother of three children. She is a seamstress and a dyer by trade. However in 2007, she got into the business selling firewood. It was her husband who strongly encouraged her to sell firewood. In fact, her husband is a truck driver who covers almost all of the southern region and buys Casamance wood for a good price (respecting the restrictions established by the administration of Waters and Forests). Thus, she is seeking a loan of 200,000 francs CFA in order to buy more Casamance wood to grow her business and satisfy her customers.

Translated from French by Robin Clochard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of firewood to sell

loans.name: Artak

texts.en: Artak G. is 32 years old; he lives in Tsovagyugh village, in the region of Sevan. Artak is married and has two school-aged children. Artak worked as a firefighter for 2 years.  He now works as a technician for an ecological company and also manages his own food shop. With the profit from his business, Artak provides for his family's needs. He is also involved in stock breeding and his wife helps him with farming. Artak requires 1,100,000 AMD to buy fresh fish to resell.

loans.use: To buy fresh fish to resell

loans.name: Femmes Commerçantes N°17 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupement  Femmes Commerçantes (F.C) comme son nom l’indique est un réseau de femmes qui s’activent  dans le commerce.  Il est basé à Grand Thiès et il a été créé depuis 1992 par Madame Maty Niakh l’actuel président du réseau. Cette présidente a eu cette idée  à l’issue d’une formation qu’elle avait bénéficiée  de l’ONG OXFAM à Thiès. Elle connait, ainsi, bien la gestion de groupe, entreprenariat …etc.  Les membres du réseau sont extrêmement dévoués et se rencontrent une fois par mois. Ainsi, après des frais d’adhésion au groupement, chaque membre est tenu de cotiser mensuellement 200 FCFA pour une caisse de solidarité.
Souhaitant se financer, elles décidèrent  d’adhérer à  U-IMCEC. C’est ainsi que,  leur réseau se voit scinder en 19 sous groupes de 5 personnes  pour un meilleur profit des financements. Elles sollicitent pour une deuxième fois un prêt de 100 000 FCFA par membre,  soit 500 000 FCFA par sous groupe afin de développer leurs diverses activités.
Cependant, les règlements sont versés à la présidente assistée par la trésorière du groupe, Madame Coumba Seck, pendant leurs réunions mensuelles et ces deux se chargent à leur tour de rembourser U-IMCEC. Ce réseau qui, dit la présidente, n’a qu’un seul et noble objectif : combattre la pauvreté dans les ménages. Actuellement, le réseau compte 19 sous groupes avec chacun une présidente et une trésorière.
Pour les Femmes Commerçantes N°17, Madame Fatou Kiné D. est la présidente. Cette femme âgée de 43 ans et mère de 4 enfants a préféré cessé très tôt ses études pour se lancer dans le commerce. Elle vend actuellement des chaussures, tissus, sacs, seaux et s’approvisionne jusqu’en Gambie. Elle partage ce sous groupe avec la trésorière Madame Ndèye Coumba S. vendeuse de légumes au marché central de Thiès, Madame Khady L. et Madame Ndèye Ngoné D.  qui vendent toutes les deux de la glace et crème à la gare routière ainsi que Madame Fagui D.  qui fait la couture.
texts.en:
As its name suggests, Femmes Commerçantes is a network of businesswomen. It is based at Grand Thiès and was created in 1992 by Ms. Maty Niakh, its current president. She got the idea of forming the network after participating in a training session run by Oxfam at Thiès, in which she became familiar with group organization and running a business. The members of the group are dedicated to what they do, and meet together once a month. Over and above membership dues, each of them pays 200 FCFA a month into a group solidarity fund. Looking for financing, they decided to join U-IMCEC. The network is divided into 19 subgroups of five people so that financing can be better handled. Each subgroup has its own president and treasurer. They now seek, for the second time, a loan of 100,000 FCFA per member or 500,000 FCFA for each subgroup, to grow their various activities. The members repay their loans to the president and the treasurer, Ms. Coumba Seck. They, in turn, are responsible for repaying U-IMCEC. According to the president, the group’s praiseworthy objective is to fight family poverty. Mrs. Fatou Kiné D. is the president of "Femmes Commerçantes N° 17". She is 43 years old and the mother of four children. She chose to interrupt her studies early on to embark upon commercial ventures. Currently she retails shoes, clothing fabric, handbags, buckets, and gets her supplies as far away as Gambia. She shares this sub-group with its treasurer Mrs. Ndèye Coumba S., who retails vegetables at the central market in Thies, Mrs. Khady L. and Mrs. Ndèye Ngoné D. who both sell ice cream at the bus station, and Mrs. Fagui D. who is a seamstress.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Resupply merchandise

loans.name: Kike

texts.en:
Kike sells frozen food like chicken parts, turkey parts and more. She travels to purchase her goods from other towns close to the Lagos border. She has been in business for ten years and, with it, she is able to sustain herself and her family financially.

Kike is requesting a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more frozen food to sell to make more profit. She says thanks to LAPO micro-finance and Kiva lenders who have greatly improved her business and family life. She indeed is very grateful to all.

loans.use: To purchase more frozen food to sell

loans.name: Olaleye

texts.en:
Olaleye sells drinks and she is requesting a loan of NGN 90,000 to purchase more drinks to sell. Having additional capital will boost her business and also go a long way towards affecting the business and her family positively.

Olaleye has been in this business for four years now and with it she supports her husband, who is a mechanic, in providing for their family needs.

Olaleye is 50 years old and has five children. She says thank you to all lenders for the financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more soft drinks to sell

loans.name: Bosede

texts.en:
Bosede is 42 years old, has two children, and they are doing well. When our team visited her shop, she was not around as she took her aged mother to the hospital. Hence, her son is shown in the photo.

Bosede is a trader: she sells drinks at wholesale and retail prices and also supplies drinks for various ceremonies. She goes to the factory twice a month to get goods in large quantity at a discount rate. She has been in business for the past seven years and with this trade she assists her husband, who is into rental services, with the children’s upbringing.

Bosede has been a member of LAPO for the past three years and she is a faithful client. She is requesting a loan of NGN 150,000 to purchase more drinks to sell which will enable her to meet her customers’ demands and increase her profit. She says thank you to Kiva lenders for their support and promises to pay back her loan at its due dates.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Jumoke

texts.en:
Jumoke is 35 years old, married, and blessed with four children. She buys and sells children’s fairly-used clothes. She also supplies clothing materials in bulk to those who retail and she has been in this business since 2007. She manages the business in Lagos where she and her family live.

Jumoke hopes to buy more goods to sell as this will attract more customers to her shop and increase her profit. Jumoke is requesting a loan of NGN 100,000 to enable her to buy more fairly-used clothes in bales as this is cheaper. She appreciates Kiva for its initiative.

loans.use: To purchase more fairly-used clothes to sell

loans.name: Favour

texts.en:
Favour sells clothing materials (sarongs) and has been in business for over ten years. With this trade she is able to assist her husband in running the home. She goes to market once every two weeks to get new stock in large quantity at a discount.

Favour has been a member of LAPO microfinance for the past three years and she is a faithful client. She is requesting a loan of NGN 70,000 to enable her to purchase goods in bulk to sell and this will enable her meet the demand of her customers.

Favour is 48 years old and has two children. She says thank you to Kiva lenders and LAPO micro-finance.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Faiba

texts.en:
Faiba sells jewelry to make a living in Lagos State, Nigeria. She has been in this business for more than ten years now. With this trade she assists her husband in running the home in areas like feeding, clothing and buying school books for the children.

Faiba needs additional capital to invest in her business. She is requesting a loan of NGN 140,000 to enable her to purchase jewelry in bulk. This will enable her to meet the demand of her customers.

39-year-old Faiba is married and has five children; her youngest child is 8 years old and is doing fine. She says thank you to lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more jewelry to sell

loans.name: Ngozi

texts.en:
Ngozi is 42 years old and the mother of three children. She sells notebooks and other writing materials to her customers and does this business in order to make ends meet. She started the business five years ago.

Ngozi joined LAPO three years ago and has a good repayment record. She hopes to expand her business in future. She is requesting a loan of NGN 80,000 to purchase more notebooks at a reduced price to sell. This will enable her meet the demands of students as schools resumes. She says thank you to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To more purchase notebooks to sell

loans.name: Latifat

texts.en:
38-year-old Latifat is married and has five children. She is a hair stylist; she styles hair and sells hair accessories to her customers at her beauty salon. She buys hair accessories from a big distributor and sells retail. She has been in this business since 2006.

Latifat wants to improve her business as this will attract more customers to her salon. She is requesting a loan of NGN 50,000 to buy goods directly from the company at a reduced rate, thereby increasing her profit. She says thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more goods to sell

loans.name: Abed

texts.en:
Abed D. is the 48-year-old married mother of three children. She has been a member of the "Banc Villageois" Diamaguene1 for two years and has always paid back her loans on time.

Madame D. runs a business selling various products, ranging from local food to cloth and paint. The revenues from this activity help her improve her family's living conditions. With this loan, she wants to buy more fruit, fabrics and paint for her store.

loans.use: To purchase more fruit, fabrics and paint for her store

loans.name: Khadiatou

texts.en:
Khadiatou Konaté is 33 years old, unmarried, and responsible for one child. She has been a member of the "Banc Villageois" Diamaguene1 for two years and has always paid back her loans.

Madame Konaté sells a wide range of products, mainly groceries and sanitary products. She will use the loan to bolster her shop with more products, namely rice and oil.

loans.use: To purchase more rice and oil

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose sells firewood and also supplies soup items to retailers at their business places. She also sells spiritual items which are used for prayers by some Christians. She has been in this trade for many years now. Firewood is used for cooking in this part of the world; some people see it as an alternative to kerosene as it is faster to cook with.

Due to an increase in demand for firewood, Rose is requesting a loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more firewood and soup items to sell. This, she said, will reduce her cost price and her transportation costs to market and so will increase her profit. This will also enable her to serve her customers better and help her to care for her family.

Rose is 54 years old and is married with four children. She and her family lives in Lagos State. She says thank you to all lenders for assisting her.

loans.use: To purchase more firewood and soup items to sell

loans.name: Nkem

texts.en:
Nkem is 48 years old, married, and has four children. She sells groceries and drinks to take care of herself and family. She has been in this business for the past six years. She is focused and makes sure she meets the demands of her customers which also leads to an increase in her profits.

Nkem is a member of LAPO micro-finance with a good repayment record. She is asking for a loan of NGN 100,000 to buy groceries in bulk to sell as this will enable her get a better discount and earn more profit on each sale. She appreciates all lenders for their wonderful support.

loans.use: To buy groceries in bulk

loans.name: Musili

texts.en:
Musili sells cosmetics and has been in this business for five years now. She is requesting a loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more cosmetics in bulk. This, she said, will reduce her cost price and her transportation costs to market and will increase her profits as she will be able to serve her customers better.

Musili is 31 years old and is married to Mr. A., a wood seller, The family lives in Lagos State. Musili says thank you to all Kiva lenders for the financial assistance they are giving to people.

loans.use: To purchase more cosmetics in bulk

loans.name: Mabel

texts.en:
Mabel has a shop where she sells children’s ready-made clothes as well as clothing materials for both men and women. She sees this as her means of livelihood and has been in this business for over ten years.

Mabel makes sure her customers’ demands are met while indirectly improving herself financially. With her proceeds from the business, she is able to assist her husband, who is retired officer, in the upkeep of their home.

Mabel hopes to improve and expand on her business. She is requesting a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more children’s ready-made clothes and clothing materials to sell.

50-year-old Mabel is married with four children and they are doing fine. She says thank you to all lenders and promise to repay promptly.

loans.use: To purchase more children's ready-made clothes and clothing materials to sell

loans.name: Ndèye Khoury

texts.en: Ndèye Khoury N. is 59 years old, married, and the mother of six children. She has been a member of the "Banc Villageois" DIAMAGUENE1 for two years and has always paid back her loans. Her main activity consists of selling building materials. She wants to use this loan to buy cement, iron, pipes, etc., which she will resell. The revenues generated by this activity allow her to improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase building materials

loans.name: Evgeniy

texts.en:
Evgeniy runs a small business that sells clothing. He started this business eight years ago.

Evgeniy used to work as an electrician for a coal mine but the job had high risk and low salary. So he decided to quit and became self-employed. Today he has two business locations that sell clothing, shoes, and bags. His main competitive advantage is a big variety and affordable prices.

Evgeniy would like to borrow 15,000 UAH to purchase spring jackets. He hopes to increase his sales and earn additional income.

Evgeniy has a thirteen-year-old daughter who lives with her mother.

loans.use: To purchase spring jackets

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence buys and sells kerosene at retail prices to her customers. She gets kerosene directly from the depot as she is a big dealer and has been in this business since 2000.

Florence is requesting a loan of NGN 150,000 to buy more kerosene to sell. With part of her profit and what her husband brings home they are able to clothe and feed the family and also take care of their house rent as they are yet to have a building of their own.

Florence is 48 years old and is married with six children. She expresses her gratitude to all lenders for their assistance.

loans.use: To purchase more kerosene to sell

loans.name: Monsurat

texts.en:
Monsurat is 47 years old, is married, and has five children. She sells baking items like flour, baking powder, etc., and rechargeable phone cards to make a living. She has been in this business for more than four years. She is determined to make sure that she meets the demands of her customers which she said will also lead to an increase in profit for her.

Monsurat is asking for a loan of NGN 100,000 to buy more baking items to sell as this will enable her to get a better discount and earn more profit. She expresses her love to all lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more baking item to sell

loans.name: Marème

texts.en:
Marème E. is a 41-year-old married mother of five children. She has been a member of the "Banc Villageois" Diamaguene1 for two years and has always paid back her loans.

Marème E.’s main activity consists of selling dried and salted fish and other seafood. She will use the loan to buy more fish which she will resell. The earnings from selling fish allow her to improve the living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To purchase more fish to sell

loans.name: Bola

texts.en:
Bola is 35 years old, is married, and has three children. She is a teacher by profession but also has a shop where she sells snacks and drinks. This serves as additional income at the end of the day and, with this trade, she assists her family with some financial needs.

Bola has been in her business for the past ten years and wants to improve on it. She is asking for a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase a deep freezer to cool her drinks while the balance will be used to purchase more drinks to sell. That will enable her to make more profit.

Bola says thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase a deep freezer and more drinks to sell

loans.name: Nogoye

texts.en:
Nogoye G. is 32 years old, married and the mother of three children. She has been a member of the "Banc Villageois" Diamaguene 1 for two years and has paid back her previous loans on time.

Madame G. sells dyed fabrics and clothes, an activity in which she is very experienced. She wants to use this loan to buy more fabrics which she will dye. The revenues allow her to improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase fabrics

loans.name: Gnilane Madeleine

texts.en:
Gnilane Madeleine N. is 28 years old, married and without children. She has been a member of the "Banc Villageois" Diamaguene 1 for two years and has always paid back her loans. She sells clothes, namely jeans, skirts and shoes.

Madame N. wants to use this loan to purchase more products for her shop. The revenues help her to improve the living conditions of her and her husband.

loans.use: To purchase more products for shop

loans.name: Olabisi

texts.en:
Olabisi has a shop where she sells drinks and dry gin to costumers. She buys in bulk and sells in retail. She likes the business because it gives her the opportunity to interact with her costumers. She buys goods directly from the company sales representative who goes around town supplying big buyers at a discount at their business places.

Olabisi wants to expand her business by buying more drinks and dry gin, so she is requesting a loan of NGN 80,000 to purchase more drinks and dry gin to sell.

Olabisi is 54 years old, married and has six children who are between 23 and 39 years old. At her age, she works hard to assist her husband, who is a driver, to pay their bills, and they intend to renovate their building. She thanks Kiva for their huge support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and dry gin to sell.

loans.name: Uzoma

texts.en: Since 2008, Uzoma has had a shop selling handbags which she buys in bulk at a discount outside of Lagos.  Uzoma is 37 years old, married and has five children; her business allows her to care for her aged parents who are living with her and support her husband in meeting their family expenses. She is now requesting a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more handbags to sell and thanks you for your support, promising to repay her loan on the due date.

loans.use: To purchase more handbags to sell.

loans.name: Mame Diarra

texts.en: Mame Diarra S., a 22-year-old single woman from the region of Mbour, Senegal, has been a member of the "Banc Villageois" DIAMAGUENE1 for two years. Madame S. sells works of art at a stand, the income allowing her to improve her living conditions. Having repaid her previous loans on time, she is now requesting a new loan to buy more objects of art to bolster her sales.

loans.use: To buy works of art

loans.name: Aïda

texts.en: Aïda G., 49 years old, married and the mother of three children, has been a member of the "Banc Villageois" DIAMAGUENE1 for two years and has always paid back her loans on time. Aida runs a small restaurant serving breakfast, lunch and dinner. With this loan, she wants to buy silverware and other equipment for her restaurant. The revenues from this business allow her to improve the living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To purchase equipment for her restaurant

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more engine oil to sell.

loans.name: Khady

texts.en: Khady N. is a 51-year-old widow with three adult children. She has been a member of the "Banc Villageois" DIAMAGUENE1 for two years and has repaid her previous loans on time. Madame N. runs a small restaurant in which she offers breakfast, lunch and dinner. She is using this loan to equip her restaurant with silverware and to pay for the gas needed for cooking. The revenues allow her to improve her and her children's living conditions.

loans.use: To better equip her restaurant

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
Stella is 36 years old, married and blessed with three children. Her husband is a civil servant and the family lives in Lagos state.  Stella sells all kinds of gravel and sand for house building and other construction work. She buys her goods by the riverside and supplies them to builders in town.

Stella is requesting a loan in the amount of NGN 170,000 to enable her to make more trips to obtain gravel and sand to meet the increase in demand. She expresses her gratitude to all lenders.

loans.use: To obtain more gravel and sand to sell

loans.name: Awa

texts.en: Awa S. is 46 years old, married and the mother of eight children. She has been a member of the "Banc Villageois" DIAMAGUENE1 for two years, and has had no problems repaying her loans. She sells various products: mainly groceries such as palm oil and citrus fruits, but also brushes. With this loan, Madame S. will buy more palm oil and lemons to bolster her shop. The revenues from this activity allow her to pay for her eldest children's school expenses .

loans.use: To purchase products

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs

loans.name: Oumy

texts.en: Oumy B. is 56 years old, widowed and the mother of three children. She has been a member of the "Banc Villageois" DIAMAGUENE1 for two years and has repaid her previous loans on time. Her main line of work consists of selling fabrics but, as a second occupation, she sells peanut butter. Oumy B. is using the bulk of this loan to buy fabrics and the remainder to buy peanut butter. The earnings from selling these products help her cover daily expenses.

loans.use: To purchase fabric

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Soukeye

texts.en: Soukeye N. is a 28-year-old single woman from the region of Thiès, Senegal. She has been a member of the "Banc Villageois" DIAMAGUENE1 for two years and has always repaid her loans on time. She uses local fruits to produce juice which she sells at a stand. Soukeye N. will use the bulk of this loan to buy fruits and, with the remainder, buy a necessary utensil.

loans.use: To purchase fruit
